stories.title: Husband rather cash out his 401ks and IRAs and sale the house to prolong his mother life, than accept my inheritance help.
stories.story:
Together 15 years, married 13 years, he is an awesome husband, dotes on me from head to toes. But there just one thing we just forever unsolve is stubbornness on not want to accept my inheritance help.

My father whom was a Shanghai businessman when alive own alot of properties, when my parents died they leave inheritance half to me (their daughter) and half to my brother. The inherence is enough to take care of me for the rest of my life not have to work a day.

Back when I got my inheritance, my husband (whom is my next of kin) force me to write a Will that in event of my dead all my inheritance will go straight to my brother, he sees that as the money go back to my Chinese family as it my biological brother. My husband adamant on not want a single penny of it, or anything to do with it.

I got the Wills done as he wish, but it a Will that I wrote against my will just so my husband can be happy or else we just bickering about this.

\-------

Fast forward, 4 years ago his elderly mother (80 years old) had a spinal cord stroke that leave her quadriplegia paralyze (paralyze both arms and legs), she also has alot of other health problems including kidney failure. She went through multiple big surgeries, as well as alot of specialists treating her conditions, and a team of nurses care about her.

He has been working 84 hours a week, and all his money go to his mother treatments, see specialists, medications, out of pocket cost, and pay for a team of qualify nurses to care for her around the clock as she quadriplegia paralyze (and that alone cost 150K a year).

Three months ago he has to cash out his IRAs with penalty to pay for his mom surgeries hospital bills. The debt collectors were after his mother as it big hospital bills, out of filial he take it on and paid for her debt at the expense of cash out his IRAs with penalty.

Her health recently has turn worst, prolong hospital stays and more specialists treating her, my husband adamant on prolong his mom life as he can, even if it mean he will sale the house to use the money to prolong his mom life.

In all fairness to him, the house is he bought with his Savings from his working money, I didn't put a penny to the house. I have no problem with him sale the house, as I have my inheritance to take care of me for the rest of my life. I even have a house in Shanghai myself that my grandma leave for me.

And yes, I offer to help endless times, I even told him use all my inheritance to care for his mom, but he adamant refused, he even get defensive and shut me out. He said I'm his wife, he is her biological son, it not my job to care for his mom.

I'm at my wits end. I asked him flat out, is he like still hold grudge against my Chinese parents whom discriminate against him because he Sierra Leonean, he not Chinese. My parents till their deaths never accepted my husband.

My husband said No, and he said if there anything he very grateful to my parents leave their inheritance to me, because he knows the inheritance will financially take care of me, so he can concentrate on financially care for his mom and prolong her life (even if that means cash out his 401ks and IRAs and sale the house to use the money to prolong her life).

He just adamant not want a single penny help from my inheritance. At this point I told him just do whatever he wants. He can put the house on the market for sale and use that money to prolong his mom life, and I will use my inheritance to rent for the time being, because after his mom pass away, I want him to go with me to China.

He has the rights to sale the house, he bought the house with his Savings, I didn't put a penny into it. He has no problem to survive without me, he has a Master degree. and makes 6-figures Problem here is for the past 4 years he pour all his working money into his mom medical care and prolong her life. After his mom die he no longer has to pay for her care, all his working money will be his again just like prior to she became paralyze.

Other than the him not want to accept my inheritance issue we don't have a marriage problem, he is awesome, the most faithful loyal man in the 15 years long with him, and he dotes on me alot.

Is there a way to fix this?

stories.title: Need help - elderly man with cancer I help tried to kiss me
stories.story:
Need help navigating this difficult situation. Apologies in advance for the long story.

I am a 51 year old woman, very active in my local theatre community and also a healthcare provider. At an annual theatre camp 3 years ago, I met an elderly couple that took a great liking to me given our shared passion for music and art. Each year at this camp, I have spent short bursts of time with them, but we nonetheless developed a fondness for each other with hugs and sharing nice comments. Last year, they storyed on the group's social media page that the man (I'll call him Remy) was diagnosed with aggressive brain cancer, and this past January underwent surgery and started chemo and radiation. I was very sad when I found this out, and tried to stay in touch with them to keep up with his progress and see when I could plan a visit (my work schedule is very complicated and requires travel). A few weeks ago, I met them for breakfast and the wife (I'll call her Julie) asked that since I had a few weeks off of work while in rehearsal for a show, if I could come to their house twice a week for a couple of hours to take Remy to the park for walks, to the pool to swim and play piano, and that they would pay me. This would help Julie have some breathing room, even though she says he is OK being alone (he is fully ambulatory and cognitively intact, just slightly forgetful and relies heavily on wife for all medical questions/appointments/meds/etc.). I felt very awkward about being paid to help, but she insisted that they value my time, and after I asked her to come up with a number, I eventually agreed to the lowest end of the range she provided. I feel for her as she has said she really needs a break from caregiving, so I felt good that I would be helping them both by doing this, even though I am also taking some classes and am pretty busy during this time.

I started visiting them/him 2 weeks ago, and the 2 hours slowly stretched into 2.5-3 hours given the prolonged goodbyes and him saying each time that he is sad to see me go. Julie is not in the house when I visit (goes to sewing class or brunch with friends), but I have been calling her when I leave to let her know how he felt and what we did, also so she knows exactly what time I depart for the sake of the payment. First visit we walked in the park, then I drove him home. We walked arm in arm for a bit at the park, which I thought was sweet and fatherly. Second visit ended up being a trip to the ER that they insisted on for a mild rash. Third visit he felt fatigued, so he said he wanted to lie down...in his bedroom. We walked to the bedroom, he lay down and after setting down my mug, I said I would go get a chair, to which he replied, "oh, it's not like I'm going to jump your bones!" I brushed it off and said matter-of-factly that sitting sideways on the bed would bother my back, and came back with the chair placed at the far side of the bed away from where he was lying. I then brought up a topic of discussion from one of my classes and a video, which we started watching on my phone. This led to my having to sit up/lie next to him to show him the video. He did not do anything weird then. We said goodbye and I left.

This past week, we went to the park again, and when walking, the arm in arm thing happened again (can't remember if I started it or him), and then he somehow found a way to turn it into us holding hands. I again thought "oh how sweet," but nonetheless felt a bit weird about it (the hand holding was palm to palm, not fingers interlaced). I walked away to use the restroom, and when I returned, he just went and resumed the handhold. I just went with it but still thought it was unusual. We got in the car and left to his house.

We arrived and I walked inside to see if he needed any last things and say my goodbyes, and after expressing again he was sad I was leaving I went to hug him, and he straight up went in for a kiss (like a wifely peck) on the lips, which I was not expecting. I abruptly turned my face and he landed the kiss on the corner of my mouth. I have been totally weirded out since that day, and now I don't want to go back. I don't want to discuss this in detail with his wife, as it is certain he will probably die in the next few months, and I don't want to create even more strife for her and them, and it's incredibly awkward to even contemplate doing it. I feel like making something up as a reason I can't come around any more and just cutting off contact, all the while feeling bad because he is a dying man. But he has made me super uncomfortable. I have been sexually harassed and also sexually assaulted with a whole lot of trauma in the past, and the more I talk about this, the more I notice that this is causing me seemingly unreasonable levels of anxiety, but I recognize the connection.

Any thoughts and insight would be greatly appreciated. Thank you in advance.

stories.title: Do I need a lawyer?
stories.story:
Situation: 80 y.o. mother sent to rehab facility (nursing home) 3 months ago due to severe cellulitis wounds on her feet & infections. Otherwise healthy. No dementia or disease. 

One foot is 100% healed which is a miracle because they were convinced they‚Äôd have to amputate. The other foot is ‚Äúalmost there‚Äù. But the doctors never gave orders for her to be fully weight-bearing, so PT has never gotten her out of bed. 

In 3 months she has lost 40-50 lbs. Her dentures no longer fit and hurt her mouth from sliding around. So she hasn‚Äôt been wearing them and can‚Äôt eat much. They have not put her on a soft diet. 

Medicare denied her last appeal and the 100 days has passed anyway. However, I just arrived from out of town for the 3rd time in 3 months. Her last appeal denial was full of lies. For example, it said that her ‚Äúplan‚Äù was to go home with help of family. um? Her nearest family is ‚Äúme‚Äù and I live 900 miles away. 

Anyway, the facility convinced her to sign up for a hospice-like plan. SHE IS NOT DYING!!! But apparently it‚Äôs some program that will allow them to keep getting paid as they wait for her Medicaid to get approved. 

In the meantime, she isn‚Äôt getting any PT or care since she‚Äôs considered ‚Äúhospice‚Äù. When all she needs is the PT to help her get on her feet so she can go home. 

She is so depressed. She will lose her apartment when medicaid starts taking her social security check, then she won‚Äôt even have the option to go home. 

But how can they just let her lay there wasting away and do nothing just because they are waiting to get paid??? Is this legal? 

She is very low-income and I was just laid off and am currently unemployed. I am in town for a week. 

I have already contacted the Ombudsman, I filed a complaint with ACHA (florida), and called APS. The State conducted an ‚Äúinspection of the facility‚Äù which was bullshit. They found ‚Äúnothing wrong‚Äù. Meanwhile I‚Äôve seen roaches every time I have been to visit over the last 3 months and urine on the floor in the hallways. Every CNA is a foreigner and today I witnessed one of them yank an elderly man in his wheelchair in the hallway and slam him into a wall because he was in their way. 

Nobody seems to care. The facility is only concerned with documenting things to cover their asses. And my perfectly healthy mom is on some facility-based ‚Äúplan‚Äù that‚Äôs a combo of hospice and palliative care getting no treatment to help her get home. Since she has been there she has been deteriorating, contracted c. diff. and isn‚Äôt being kept clean. Her nails are super long and caked with scum or who knows what. 

Also, nobody contacted me to even tell me they were discussing this hospice crap with her when they had her do the paperwork. This is after I sent the facility an official refusal of nursing home placement 1-2 months ago on my mother‚Äôs behalf. 

Can a lawyer help us? I don‚Äôt want to necessarily sue them for money, I need someone to intervene to give my mother the care she needs rather than letting her lay there to rot. It is affecting her mental health very badly. There isn‚Äôt even a clock in her room. It‚Äôs a 4-wall prison cell basically. There‚Äôs one tv that her roommate won‚Äôt share the remote with my mom. She just lays there all day trying to sleep because there is nothing else she can do.

stories.title: Helping an elderly family friend
stories.story:
I've been helping an elderly friend going on three years now.  Myself, my mom and my dad lived in the same little neighborhood as this lady and her family.  My parents and her and her husband became good friends.  Her kids grew up and moved away, and her husband passed many years ago.  She had always been very self sufficient and independent.  After my dad passed, her and my mom stayed close and talked quite often.  

My mom passed away in 2020, and I kept in contact with family friend, knowing she missed my mom.  I began to notice how frail she was, and signs of dementia.  Her daughter, her only remaining child, worked full time.  I offered to help her take care of her mother when she needed help, knowing how hard it is to take on the care of an elderly parent, as I had taken care of mine on my own for many years.  I offered to help, and explained how we could split the responsibility between us, and that way it wouldn't be all on one person.  

It turned out to be completely on me, as she has shown almost no interest in having anything to do with her mom.  Over the last two and a half years I have taken her to all her Dr. appointments, listening to and helping her understand what doctors are telling her, managing her prescriptions and setting up her weekly pill reminders every week, getting groceries for her, been there to help when repair people need to come to her home, sat all night in emergency room with her at times, the list goes on.  I have a lot to manage in my own life as well.  Mind you, I don't get paid and I have never asked to be paid. I've done it because I truly care about her. 

She is now 92, and I've noticed she can no longer comprehend how to pay her bills at all, much less write checks and balance a check book.  I refuse to have anything to do with her finances, I see it as none of my business, and I definitely do not want to be accused of taking anything of hers.  I know her daughter is on her accounts, and she should be the one handling them, and actually, everything else to do with her mom.

I found out that her daughter no longer works, so I asked her to please start taking her mom to her appointments, it's time for her to step up and take over helping her mom, but she refuses to talk to me or help her mom in any way.  I don't know what to do.  It has gotten to the point that she really should not be living alone, actually, it has been to that point for a while.  Thanks for listening, and for any advice.  I'm at my wits end.

stories.title: No doctor at nursing home on weekends
stories.story:
Dad is bedridden but mentally sharp, speaks with difficulty due to a weak voice. He's being fed through a gastric tube, and is on antibiotics again due to a deep wound on his back (one got better, this one is worse.)

Yesterday (Friday) he called me and said he's having trouble getting his words out. He can speak and understand, but the action of saying the first few words of a sentence is difficult. Went to see him today, and he's completely confused and forgetful, no idea what's going on, being conversational at a bare-minimum level. He repeated the same questions, wasn't sure about my name, etc. but didn't seem distressed and said he was feeling fine physically.

Alerted the front desk and the nurse doing the rounds; nurse thinks it's his hearing (didn't make a difference when I spoke loudly to him though) and the front desk said it's likely the early stages of dementia (he was perfectly conversational yesterday.)

I checked the meds, Cefepime IV. Possible side effect includes confusion, which means the meds should be switched out immediately due to neurotoxicity that could lead to seizures. I called and tried to leave a message with the nursing supervisor- full mailbox. Tried to leave a text with my phone #. Then called the reception desk and asked if there was anybody who could handle this- I keep being told to call back Monday.

So I'm wearing myself out with worry. How is there nobody on a weekend at a LTCF? Can he manage until Monday since he needs to be on an antibiotic anyway?? The rapid onset of confusion can't be good for another day and a half.

Anyway my apologies if this isn't the place to story this.

EDIT: Visited this afternoon, somebody came by to check his bloodwork- seemed like they were sent specifically for him, which makes me feel better despite his ongoing confusion. Documented the issue in an email to the county and nursing home.

I'm trying not to panic, if I call an ambulance who the hell knows if the disruption will be worth it- he's not on Medicaid yet and I'm afraid that'll complicate things at the ER. Being able to vent here and read all the feedback is a tremendous help, I appreciate it!! ü•≤

stories.title: Advice for Elder care
stories.story:
Hello,

My mother and sister both had their own aides/respite but because of some conflict; my mom asked if I would move her to our home in another state. 

We did so last week.

I‚Äôm trying to hire part time help but my mom is my first experience; so I have no experience.

Her health is declining. My special needs sister CAN do things; she‚Äôs just used to my mom pampering her. Because of my mom‚Äôs health, she cannot pamper her as much.

My problems and questions are endless.

What is everyone doing for people who *can* do things; they just don‚Äôt want to? 
Their insurance hasn‚Äôt transferred yet, so we are having to pay out of pocket for an aide. Not only do I not know how care.com works but I don‚Äôt want to have to wait on both of them hand and foot when I‚Äôm around. I want someone that helps them be independent as possible. Not enable them to expect me to break myself. 

I still have my own kids and my own life. I‚Äôm trying to be a good mom and enable my small children to be independent. And here I have 2 grown adults that enjoy me cooking, serving, cleaning, etc . I am worn out. I‚Äôm not able to be as attentive to my children.

Don‚Äôt get me wrong - I get it - I would love to be pampered too. But I broke down the other day and begged my mom to just help me help herself. She‚Äôs in this mess because she let her homeless friend live with her. She‚Äôs always trying to help less fortunate but SHE IS the less fortunate for us. 

My husband is great but I don‚Äôt want my marriage to fall apart because of any of this. We have diverted thousands of dollars to help her. Anything to make her life easier. We are never in this home anyway, so it‚Äôs a good thing to bring them closer to us. He‚Äôs currently building them an easier accessible staircase. 

But it feels more like we‚Äôre expected to hire help for friendship. I don‚Äôt want to have to pay someone to hang out with them. That‚Äôs the major reason my husband and I stopped having most of the friends we had; because they only wanted money from us. 


Any/all advice is welcome. Don‚Äôt be rude. 

I guess I‚Äôm kind of venting too. They can do all of these things themselves‚Ä¶ cooking, cleaning, laundry, etc‚Ä¶ it‚Äôs more difficult for my mom. I don‚Äôt want her struggling but it‚Äôs just a lot.
I‚Äôm also worried about the hired help. Are they actually helpful? Who knows. What if they try something crazy to make my mom a vegetable that *needs* more care? 
I just don‚Äôt trust anyone. 

Thanks. 


EDIT: For example, we said it‚Äôs ok for her to keep her 3 cats. We‚Äôre a pet free family. I‚Äôm the one taking care of them. My sister does nothing. So if I don‚Äôt do it; then my mom is doing it. I have an extremely sensitive nose; so the smell is awful. One or multiple cats keep peeing in my sisters room/ her clothes. I don‚Äôt know why or which one. I want to get rid of the cats. But I want them to have their own home and not make these demands of them . We spent at least $100 just on urine cleaning supplies. We do not ask or demand my mom to pay.  If it were me; I wouldn‚Äôt even ask my kids any of this. But I would definitely not have the cats.

stories.title: JACC Jersey assistance for community caregivers
stories.story: I‚Äôve just applied for the JACC program. Does anyone have any experience with this program? I am trying to care for two elderly sickly parents and have lost my job due to this. JACC rep is saying that we can get $15 an hour towards a home health aide? You try to find a home health aide for that price in NJ. They also say a family member can be paid, but it cannot be the POA. I am the only Person in the family taking care of them and I am the POA. What to do?

stories.title: Support needed
stories.story:
‚ÄãHi everyone,
‚ÄãI'm hoping to get some advice or just hear from anyone who has had a similar experience. My family and I went through a very difficult time recently, and I‚Äôm looking for some support.
‚ÄãLast week, my elderly father passed away at a certain aged care facility, which was his home for over 10 years. Our experience with the facility's team was incredibly distressing and lacking in both compassion and dignity.
‚ÄãAfter being called to the facility, we arrived to a complete lack of communication. We were told to "go straight in," and when we got to his room, it was empty. A staff member casually gestured to a closed door, and when we opened it ourselves, we were confronted with his body, already covered by a sheet, without any prior warning. It was a complete shock.
‚ÄãOnce we returned to the nurses' station, we were told he had passed away 20 minutes before we arrived. Instead of offering condolences, staff immediately asked about funeral arrangements and told us we needed to clear out his room‚Äîall while we were standing in a busy corridor. My family was left to clear the room on our own, with no offer of practical help. Later that night, we received a cheerful, almost bubbly phone call to say his body had been collected. It was a completely insensitive end to a terrible day.
‚ÄãI've since written to senior leadership at the head office, but our formal complaint has gone completely unacknowledged. The only person who responded was the new Director of Nursing at the facility, who honestly admitted that there was a "lacking process around death management."
‚ÄãTo make things more difficult, we have not had any follow-up communication from the home about finalising his account or returning his personal belongings and jewellery.
‚ÄãHas anyone else experienced this kind of lack of care and dignity at a facility? I‚Äôm feeling a bit lost about what to do next.
‚ÄãAny advice or words of support would be greatly appreciated.

stories.title: Narc HCP sister starving my mother
stories.story: Hi, I have a mother who's in hospice in her home. She is quite elderly with demetia and doesn't have a lot of time. None of us (two sisters and myself) expected my mother to live this long. My narc sister has total control over her home care as she is the HCP.   I am the only daughter that lives near her and I visit her as much as I can ( 4 days a week to be exact).  My other two siblings live out of state. My mother has 24/7 home care thats provided by a home care agency. Hospice also visits regularly so there are a lot of people popping in and out during the day M-F. On weekends she's with the live in aide but no other health care people visit during that time; that terrifies me.  My access to all these health care professionals is limited because my sister doesn't want me interfering in my mother care. My sisters want my mom to pass as  they are concerned about getting a good price for her house before there's a turn in the economy. My sister dictates exactly what food my mother is given on a particular day and disregards the doctors recommendations for giving her nutritious food on her blended food diet. What I've observed on my visits, particularly in the last month or so, is that my mother is begging me to give her food. She complains of being hungry all the time. My sister has instructed the aides not to let me feed her and they watch me very carefully to make sure I don't. Needless to say, my mom is loosing weight and looks like a stack of bones. My visits have been very stressful. Yesterday on my visit my mother was bringing up clear fluid. At first I thought it might be from indigestion from her dinner as the aide told me she had it just an hour beforehand.  She didn't bring any food up at all and I thought that was kind of strange.  Later on I learned that this is often a sign of malnutrition and undernourishment.  To someone just reading this it might occur to you that I should complain to the agency who provides the aides. I've already done that. The woman in charge tries to avoid my complaints as much as she can. She is very intimidated by my sister and doesn't want to be involved in the conflict. Today I called Adult Protective Services and spoke to them about the situation. Apparently they are reluctant to act on my complaint because there are so many reinforcements in place. APS is very understaffed so they have to be selective on the complaints they follow up on. Realistically, I think my sister would be very successful  in duping them to think my mother's getting excellent care and proving that their practically starving her would be very difficult. The aides keep my mother's home very clean, she has no bed sores, etc., so if they were to show up suddenly at my mom's house I don't think they would learn much. I feel caught between a rock and a hard place, I love my mother and know her time is shortly up, but I don't want her to die from starvation, she deserves a dignified death. So I'm just putting this out there, in case anyone has any ideas of what I can do because I need to act quickly. I don't have time to go through the courts, and I don't even know if I could convince anyone my Mom's being underfed. Many thanks for reading (Too tired to edit so please excuse the typos).

stories.title: I‚Äôm the worst.
stories.story:
I feel horrible about this, but i don‚Äôt love my mom.  She had a crappy life & was very subservient to my narcissistic dad & others, and as a result, me & my brother were her EVERYTHING.  She hyper focused on us and we were always under her intense scrutiny.  She didn‚Äôt want or have any other friends, hobbies, interests, or anything.  I spent most of my life trying to escape her & my dad.  It was (and is) too much pressure to be someone‚Äôs sole reason for being.  

Now she‚Äôs 85 & has been cognitively declining since a stroke maybe 5y ago. My dad passed about 3 years ago and my brother, who was severely depressed & has chronic illness, suddenly passed away last month.  Her grief & increased dementia has intensified her fixation on me.  She hates having anyone else take care of her & only wants me around.  

I feel so angry at the world that her life was so unfair, and i have tried to be compassionate and helpful to her, but i just find myself getting impatient with her anxiety and overwhelmed by her intense focus.  It‚Äôs really hard, but i do my best to not let that show and to provide the best care i can.  But now, since she‚Äôs gotten even more intensely needy, it‚Äôs become even more horrible:  i don‚Äôt want to touch her or comfort her or hold her hand.  I really can‚Äôt stand the way her hands & skin feel.  I hate the smells associated with Eldercare & it‚Äôs become hard for me to be around her for longer than 4-6 hours at a time.  I have hired help, and that‚Äôs something, but like i said, she only wants ME and gets anxious when she doesn‚Äôt know where i am.  

I want to disappear forever.  I feel like there‚Äôs something wrong with me and like i just can‚Äôt feel love anymore‚Ä¶ or don‚Äôt want to?  Please explain to me why this doesn‚Äôt make me the absolute WORST person in the whole world.   I don‚Äôt even really  want to go on with my own life bc i feel like it‚Äôs all downhill from here.

stories.title: Small win!!!!!
stories.story:
Father in Law slipped and fell moving trash cans last week. 

I had tried to get in front of this months ago, talking to my in laws neighbor (who I golf with) about hiring a little homie on the street to handle the duties. The neighbor talked to MIL and she promptly went down the script when she saw me next..'we aren't decrepit, we can do things still, no no no'. 

Well at dinner last week, I said this is what we are doing. Period. 

MIL's response 'well I can help'. 

Me 'so two people with bad feet, knees, hips, and hearts are gonna move trash cans twice a week'

MIL realized and said 'you're right'. 

Next Monday we meet the lil neighborhood homie to work it out. 

Just one less thing for them to worry about, one more concern off my wife's shoulder, and a win all around.

stories.title: "Optional" Tips for Staff at Mom's Retirement Home!?!
stories.story: We just got a form letter from the company that manages our mom's retirement home. They're offering us a chance to contribute to the Team Member Appreciation Fund, which is basically the Christmas tip jar writ large. This is a tough one because we know most of the people caring for mom and they're pretty great. However, some of them aren't great at all. On top of that, mom's paid at least $25,000 over and above her monthly fee for extra care due to a variety of issues. So folks, what would you do? What do you do?

stories.title: Please help - Need advice
stories.story: My husband and I (28&27) just got married in July and have bought ourselves a home within the last year. We have found ourselves in a difficult situation that we were not expecting in our first year of being married. My husbands elderly and medically unwell father has had to move into our house. He had been living with a friend who no longer felt capable of taking care of him and she essentially dumped him on us months ago. He has nowhere to live, no one to take care of him, and basically no income. He has not been respectful of our new home and is becoming a financial burden for us as well. While this is biologically my husbands father, he unfortunately has not been very present throughout my husbands life. This whole experience has obviously been taking a toll on the mental well being of everyone in the house. What was supposed to be one of our most exciting years has been a very stressful and hard year. We never imagined that in our first year of marriage while being 27/28 that we would have to navigate this situation. Without beating around the bush, we need to get him out of our house. What resources are there for situations like this, what advice do people have? We don‚Äôt even know where to start, ANYTHING will help.

stories.title: How to find a group home for physically disabled senior in Pennsylvania
stories.story: This is for a F72 with a spine problem greatly limiting both standing and sitting.  Also has hardly any energy due to chronic depression and anxiety.  Philadelphia suburban area.

stories.title: How did you get your parents to accept a safety system?
stories.story:
My mom‚Äôs 80 and lives about three hours away. I worry all the time, especially after she had that fall last month. She‚Äôs super independent and gets mad whenever I bring up safety stuff. I‚Äôve been checking out things like Bay Alarm Medical, but honestly, the hardest part is just getting her to admit she might need help.
For those who‚Äôve dealt with this, what finally got your parents on board with an emergency system? Was it a specific incident, or did you handle it in a way that worked?

stories.title: The journey is over
stories.story:
Im Emmie, Im 26 years old and two years ago I quit my job to be primary caregiver to my 97 year old gma. 5 days ago she began rapidly declining, she couldnt open her eyes and couldnt speak. She could only cry in pain. So we began the in home hospice care. At 6:00 this morning I stepped in to give her liquid medications that was keeping her asleep and her pain at bay, I held her hand and told her it was ok to go, that I was strong and I will be okay. At 6:19 she took her last breath and died at age 99.

I dont even know what to do with myself. She was my world for 2 years. Due to unfortunate circumstances out of my control, I didnt get to know her that well as a child, I saw her maybe once a year. Going from that to spending every day with her, feeding, bathing, toileting, listening to her stories, making her laugh, going on drives in the winter and sitting on the porch in the summer.. she was like a mother I never had. The fact that im never going to see her again, im not okay. I dont know when Ill be ok. Im wondering if I did enough, if i took her for granted, if I gave her good enough care.. i know it was her time, but I just hope she felt loved and cared for.

stories.title: Telling mom that she is already home
stories.story:
After a brief hospital stay a couple of weeks ago, my mother (90, with dementia) came home and is now firmly convinced that she is not at home. Sometimes she is more agitated than others, but despite sleeping in her own bed, with her own husband (94) and cat (age unknown) next to her, and having all of her own furniture, photos, etc. around her, she keeps saying that she wants to go home.

I‚Äôve tried pointing out that she‚Äôs already at home, but she doesn‚Äôt agree in the moment, and then 10 minutes later, she has forgotten the conversation entirely. She just wants to go home.

i‚Äôm frustrated for her, and especially frustrated for my dad who lives with this all the time. I tried taking her out of the apartment building. They‚Äôve been living in for the past five years, and then bringing her back in, and hopes that seeing the outside of the building will help. It didn‚Äôt. We have adjusted some medication that helps with the agitation, but not enough to persuade her that she IS home.

Any suggestions?

stories.title: My dad cannot communicate after a stroke, but needs money if he wants to living with girlfriend in assisted living.  Can I find out about his finances somehow?
stories.story:
tldr:  Is there a way to use my dad's social security number to find out what assets he has, so that I can give them to his girlfriend to pay for his care?

My dad lives with his girlfriend in her home, which is about 3 hours from me.  Over the past few years he has had 5 strokes and can no longer communicate well.  The texts he sends are nonsensical and he has bad aphasia.  He can do a thumbs up and down though.  The girlfriend/caregiver wants to move into assisted living in another state.  She wants him to pay half, which is fair enough, but his social security won't cover it.  

She has given me until the end of September to sort it out (i.e., find the money, pay her myself, or put him in a nursing home).  I found him a nice nursing home near me that can take him immediately.  His insurance will cover everything. 

She says she wants to take him with her because he would get better care with her than in a nursing facility, but she wants money.  He has been giving her his social security monthly to pay for his expenses, but she wants more.  He is supposed to be receiving monthly payments from the sale of his property for the next 5 years, but no one knows where the money is being deposited.  It is not going into his checking account, which he gave her access to.  Is there a way to figure out where the money is going?  Or whether he might have other accounts that could be used to pay for his expenses.  I have his social security number.  He once sent me a text message from the hospital with it and stating he was giving he Power of Attorney.  I know that isn't legal, but ... it is what I have.

I wish he could tell me what he wants to do, but he just doesn't seem to be able to.  Despite our history, I do want what is best for him and I have no idea what that is.  I don't know if he'd like to stay and work on our relationship and see my kids more often, or whether he wants to go with her.  He once told me that their relationship was just companionship, not a passionate love-based one.  During one of his hospitalizations, she told me that she thought hooking-up with a younger man would give HER a caretaker and here she is doing the care-taking, so I just don't know how attached they are to each other.  

What would you do?

stories.title: Elder abuse question in California
stories.story: Hey everyone, I am trying to help my aunt in California. She is 82 years old and she had a tenent and his wife promise to care for her if she signed over half the deed to her house to them. They have since disappeared leaving her in a bad position.  She is on dialysis and is in need of full time care. The house is also in need of repairs. We have done as much as we can to help her but we cannot afford what she needs without selling the house. We have tried reaching out to the people she trusted to help her and they don't respond. We are in touch with a real estate attorney but that's more money we don't have. Elder abuse in CA is not helping nor is the police department in Sebastopol CA. Any advice would be greatly appreciated. Tia

stories.title: How to deal with certain behavior
stories.story:
My elderly father fell in his home and has spent the last few months in rehab because now it‚Äôs too dangerous for him to return to his home due to other medical issues that have happened to him in the time he has been there.
His wife-my step mom-is now not safe to live by herself due to her medical issues, and simply growing older.  We moved her in with us temporarily with the plan of moving them both into an assisted living facility when my dad is capable of doing so as well.
Now to the problem I‚Äôm having.  Every now and again she will come up with something-anything really-to get mad and cry about, and act like a victim of whatever she is upset about and then come back later asking if she has made me mad, and telling me she is just venting.  If we are visiting my dad, most of the behavior is focused on my dad, he just deals with it, he is an easygoing man.  But when we are at my home, she turns it toward me.  My brother was here visiting my dad and she did the same thing to him, except she directed it towards me and him, and she just cried and got boisterous about it to my dad, who was sitting there witnessing the entire thing.  My brother is a lot like me, so he and I excused ourselves from the room and left out for a bit hoping it would help her calm down.  I struggle with it because I suffer with anxiety and depression.  I‚Äôm on medication for it, but it doesn‚Äôt prevent me from experiencing it from time to time.  I‚Äôm a very sweet person, and I hate confrontation, and ‚Äúdrama‚Äù. This last episode of her behavior was when we brought some of her and my dad‚Äôs snacks here from their house I just sat them on the dining room table.  But I really just wanted to clean off the table, so I put those things in her room, so they wouldn‚Äôt get inadvertently eaten or drank.  Because I really felt if that happened, it would cause her to have another fit.  I was simply trying to avoid that.  
Unfortunately she still got upset and cried and said if I didn‚Äôt want her here, to take her back to her home.  I tried to reassure her that was not the case, but it just made her more angry.  In her defense though, I probably didn‚Äôt help matters with me trying to explain why I moved the snacks.  
There are so many more times and outbursts from her, I could write a book.  I try to think about all of my actions and words, trying to not cause her fits, but they just seemingly come, no matter how hard I try to prevent them from even happening.  So at this point it feels like I‚Äôm having to walk on egg shells in my own home.  
All of this to say, I would appreciate any words of wisdom or advice, so I can start to live in peace again.  It‚Äôs really taking an emotional toll on me.  Thank you!

stories.title: Dad is resistant to hospice--help planning?
stories.story:
This is half vent, half desperate cry for help! I'll put some tl;dr action items at the bottom for those who don't want to read all of this. 

Dad has kidney cancer that has spread to his brain. He's had seven brain tumors, had his brain radiated seven times, had full open brain surgery, and a few weeks ago the radiologist called it: no more radiation, and the oral treatment clearly isn't working. As you can imagine, that much radiation to the brain has had a toll on dad's cognition. He's been losing words and fine motor skills slowly over the course of his fight/treatment, but this last one was devastating. On bad days he has problems answering anything other than yes or no, and his mood is paper thin. The oncologist told us he has "months, and not many," which was clarified to 6 or less. 

One of the two main issues that brought me to reddit is this: dad will not accept what his doctors are saying, and will not discuss hospice care. Right now I live 2 hours away and mom is in the house caring for him. Mom is very fit, but he's over six feet, and we are at the edge of our capacity for what we're able to manage without losing our minds or running away from home. We NEED him to accept hospice in order to access whatever care will come with it. He's close to the point where he needs diapers full time, and mom and I are not up to that level of care for the net six months. We need to pivot to home health at minimum, or a nursing home. 

I think we should start looking into nursing homes now. If we got him signed up and start familiarizing him while he's still mostly aware of what is going on around him, the move will be less traumatic when he has no other choice. We could potentially bring him back home for sleepovers so that the transition feels less permanent/final to him. It also, based on my initial research, seems like the most cost-effective option for us. It looks like full-time in-home care is in the ballpark of $7000 a week, although I have no idea if that is before or after insurance, what insurance covers, etc. We're in a suburb of DC, which means we have at least one or two good options near us, but everything is WILDLY expensive. 

Dad wants to be kept at home until the end, which... I am not sure we can afford. If you all could put the cost of specific services you've used in the comments, it would be hugely helpful for me in Point 2: Mother. 

Mom is exhausted, grieving, traumatized, and past the end of her rope. She's not willing to piss dad off too much by mentioning nursing homes, and she keeps putting off discussions of in-home daily care (particularly a night nurse, that would be life changing at the moment) or nursing homes because "we don't need those yet." She agrees with all of my points--that his neurological condition is continuing to deteriorate, that we don't want to be totally off-guard when his level of need increases, that we need to know what we can afford... but she will not go into details on this with me because we don't have a jumping off point of "The cost of X thing is about $$, and you get A, B, and C service." Right now it's just her vs inevitable death, and looking up from that is clearly overwhelming her. 

I am on all of dad's forms and doctors as someone who can get into his records, pick up his meds, ask questions, etc. It's not that I am not wanted or involved in the process, it really seems like neither of them is able to have a logical discussion about these things because of the emotions it dredges up. 

I'm going down for the week at the end of September, and after that will likely be bouncing back and forth between my hometown and current residence. I'd like to make calls/visit places/ask questions when I can, but now \*I\* don't know where to start either. Do I call his insurance company and see what is covered and what needs a doctor's recommendation? Do I try to find one of these hospice companies that comes with a case worker and see what they recommend? 

It's been a slow slide since his first cancer surgery back in 2017. We're all exhausted, and this is so fucking sad, but I'm not convinced we can afford to respect dad's preferences here, and I'm just--- AHHHHHH. Why does America/capitalism have to extract every bit of peace, dignity, and money from even our deaths??

  
TL;DR--

* Please tell me what services you guys have used/will use *and how much they cost*
* Give suggestions on how to get dad to accept hospice care--he's trying to stick with palliative care every other week despite his oncologist giving him less than 6 months. He's always, even before cancer, been resistant to death talk
* General advice on getting myself and mom & dad through this new stage

stories.title: Visual Screen Reminders for Elderly Parents
stories.story:
I can't imagine this is a particularly unique request, but I haven't found the best words to find what I'm looking for. Hopefully someone here can give some direction - maybe with some more tech knowledge.

My grandparents (90+), live with me and my family. I have done a lot of work to make their basement apartment a "smart home". They use voice activated lights, cameras for safety, and doorbells for announcing our incoming arrival from upstairs. I am no means knowledgeable on the actual technical side of this. But everything I do for them needs to be extremely simple.

I am in need of some system that will let a family member type in a message to display on a screen in the grandparents apartment. (Ideally a large one mounted on a wall)  
It's intended purpose is to tell them to eat their meals, come upstairs, remind them of appointments, etc. We've tried using an intercom- or calling their home phone - but hearing loss makes that challenging. Having a constant visual reminder would be very helpful in keeping them on track while still living independently.

Would the best setup be a mounted iPad for us to display custom messages on? How would we efficiently send those texts over? My family is even less tech savvy than I am, but we use a Skylight calendar and google home system.

stories.title: It Takes 15 Minutes to Walk from the Kitchen to the Living Room
stories.story:
My mother told me today that it takes her fifteen minutes to walk from the kitchen to the living room. She starts at five minutes to nine to watch the news, and misses the first ten minutes. It's not a big house. 

Yet she refuses to make any changes in her living situation. She's 91 and has been told by her physical therapist to plan for assisted living in the near future. But no. Denial, refusal, excuses. 

I'm just so tired of it. So many years of refusing to get rid of things or downsize. Now with cognitive decline she's got a whole mess. I argued for two years that she needed help. Now she has a teenager come two days a week. 

It's infuriating that there is no social worker or objective party that can help. No adult protective services won't help until her life is in danger.

stories.title: I just need to say this out loud
stories.story:
A couple years ago, I went through a burnout while I was preparing my PhD. Since then, I dropped my professional career and stopped working to figure out what I really wanted to be.

At the same time, my mom got a rare disease that's slowly making her lose her autonomy. So I've stopped thinking about my burnout and automatically started to help her more at home with cooking and chores. Throughout the years, her health has become worse, to the point that we can't leave her at home by herself because she can fall down.

I have one older sibling that lives far from us, so I'm the only one who's taking care of my mom and the home. My dad is very busy with work, but he tries to help me sometimes.

Lately, I feel like I'm losing my sanity. I've isolated myself from everyone I used to know, and have zero interaction with people. So I don't have anyone to hang out with or just talk. Plus, I have to endure my mom's constant mood swings. I understand how difficult it must be for her to deal with her disease, but I don't know how much I can handle before collapsing.

Taking care of my parents is a duty I'm happily doing. It just hits very hard to see how my life turned out... being in my late twenties with nothing, no one. I don't even feel like I'm living. I'm just doing what I have to do for my parents and that's it. The worst part is that I don't even know what I'm supposed to do, or want to do or be.

stories.title: So this happened in a facility and I'm not sure what to do ...
stories.story:
I was visiting a loved one in a facility where I've come to know (from my regular visits) the other residents. While we were all in the dining room, a really sweet resident had been sitting all alone, and I saw an empty seat at another table and suggested they might join the group. This resident did that, and all seemed well until I heard a raised voice and behind me one of the young dining room aids was yelling at the resident, telling them that they moved tables and that that was wrong. It isn't wrong, it's totallty fine. The aid's yelling SO upset the resident that they were in tears. They spoke up for themselves a bit, but they were shaken, crushed. I spent time with the resident afterward, offering affirmation, empathy, etc., but what I REALLY should have done was scold the thoughtless aid. I think I'll ask the resident tomorrow when I visit if they'd like to do anything about this. I wasn't sure just how much to stick my neck into it since the resident isn't my relative, but now feel as if not speaking out for the resident was wrong on my part. I know the aid well enough to know that they have a boisterous-ish way of communicating, but there was nothing funny about their words -- they seemed downright mean and insensitive. What's the best way to handle this?

Update: I've been thinking about it, and I'm not sure if the aide technically yelled/raised their voice (beyond their normal volume), but I could hear them loud and clear, and the ATTITUDE is what seemed most insulting and hurtful to the resident.

She was scammed out of hundreds of thousands of dollars over the last 10 years. She‚Äôll fall for a scam immediately. We‚Äôve put so many controls in place and we have figured out her habitats. But she‚Äôs sneaky and it sometimes slips through the cracks.

Also this is in Canada, we‚Äôve been to the bank, they don‚Äôt have any other options to manage her. It‚Äôs like she can‚Äôt have her own money any more.

This has happened before. Or some how stop her having access to money at all, like going into a home and I have no idea what to do.

stories.title: Update on my dad (what the hell‚Ä¶ thread)
stories.story:
First of all I want to thank everyone who gave me advice and kind words on my original story. Thank you very much it‚Äôs so appreciated. This is honestly harder on me than when I had cancer because I hate to see my dad so defeated. This all came on so fast, like 4 months tops, it‚Äôs been crazy. Before that he was living at home able to take care of all these things on his own. I did help with some things, like driving, etc, but nothing like he needs now. 

So. My dad had been pretty adamant he wanted to go home on Thursday when he was going to get kicked out. I was given the option of sending him home with private pay care, which was not feasible. It was recommended 24 hour care. I‚Äôm disabled myself, and besides his house and his income he has no money. Or they said he‚Äôd be sent to ‚Äúlong term care‚Äù, I immediately apply for MA, and sell his house. Then when MA is approved he goes to assisted living. Idk if the LTC is paid back then or what. 

Anyway, as of earlier today he insisted he wanted to go home. I told him fine, but if he needs to go to the hospital again because he can‚Äôt get out of bed or he fell he‚Äôd be back and have to go in. I told him that toileting was an important part. But he thought he could do it so I called the SW and told him he‚Äôs going home and to set up the covered home care (like 4 hours a week with OT, PT and an aide to bathe him). She wasn‚Äôt happy but what to do? 


Well while I was there, he went in his diaper. And he was not able to get to the toilet in time and for whatever reason, whether it‚Äôs the brace for the recently broken vertebrae or what, but he‚Äôs not able to change the diaper and his pants/shorts and clean himself up. 

So I told him that was a reason right there to not go home. Because he can‚Äôt sit around in a dirty diaper for hours until I can come. I explained that it‚Äôs bacteria it‚Äôs often poop and pee, and it will just multiply and the longer he sits he can get UTIs, sores, etc. The aide came in to clean him and said she usually works nights and that he didn‚Äôt know she had to change him 2-3,times a night. Between the two of us he reluctantly decided he would go to LTC. So I called the SW and left an updated message that he will do that so set that up. 

So she‚Äôs going to call me Monday, I‚Äôm going to go in and start what I need to do after I get a repair taken care of at his home that‚Äôs required. I feel terrible that I can‚Äôt provide the care he needs. I‚Äôd have cancer again if he could take care of himself and go home. But I already live with my mom to care for her even though it‚Äôs a lot less. 

But that‚Äôs the way it goes. I know he doesn‚Äôt want to live like that but he also doesn‚Äôt want to sit at home in his mess and getting poop everywhere that I or someone have to clean up. Hope the LTC won‚Äôt be the nightmare you hear about sometimes and he can still have some kind of life. I won‚Äôt have to worry about being admitted to the hospital because I can‚Äôt care for him then. 

My youngest brother just got evicted and moved back in with my dad who raised him. He‚Äôs going to have to figure something else out. He works and does his own thing and even made my dad call me when he couldn‚Äôt get out of bed when he was THERE, he‚Äôd spent the night. Useless. I‚Äôm honestly afraid for my life to tell him, he‚Äôs bipolar and has made me fear for my and my dads life before, so wish me luck. 

Thank you again for everything. Not all Reddit is bad, I really appreciate all the support and help.

stories.title: Struggling with poor communication from my grandmother's provider, is this common?
stories.story:
Hi everyone,

I wanted to share a little about my own experience. My grandmother was receiving domiciliary care, and while the carers themselves were kind, the **communication between me and the care provider was horrendous**. I often felt left in the dark about her visits, changes to her routine, and whether she was being properly supported. They would occasionally cancel visits altogether and inform me after the fact.

It got so bad that I eventually felt forced to switch providers altogether ‚Äî not because I wanted to, but because I simply couldn‚Äôt trust the flow of information. It was stressful, frustrating, and it made an already difficult situation even harder for my family.

Since then, I‚Äôve been wondering how many other families are going through the same thing. So, I‚Äôve put together a short survey (just a few minutes long) to learn more about these challenges. My hope is to use the results to **explore whether we can create something that gives families clearer, easier access to updates about their loved ones‚Äô care** ‚Äî all in one place.

If you‚Äôve faced similar struggles, I‚Äôd be so grateful if you could share your experience through this quick survey: [https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSfHH69qONG8bVDqzYf8hplGblGcgPC173Ef5MZikLSSaBF-tw/viewform?usp=dialog](https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSfHH69qONG8bVDqzYf8hplGblGcgPC173Ef5MZikLSSaBF-tw/viewform?usp=dialog)

Thank you for helping me with this ‚Äî together, maybe we can push for something better for families like ours.

stories.title: Anyone relocate with a spouse to care for elderly/ill parent(s)?
stories.story:
My dad was diagnosed with cancer several years ago, and as it progressed he had an accident which has left him in a wheelchair. My mom is his sole caregiver, but is not in the best physical shape herself and has health conditions too. I moved to my husband‚Äôs home state years back when we were still dating. I worked remotely, and I genuinely was willing to move wherever at 24 for new experiences and for our relationship. 

However, the past two years, I‚Äôve been driving up and back (approx 5 hours) to help my parents out. It‚Äôs been tough to say the least while holding down one to two jobs myself. Their situation is precarious financially, so it‚Äôs not like I can hire caretakers in-home. I also had to temporarily stay with them three years ago as my mother had a mental health episode that left her hospitalized several times. Unfortunately family in the area isn‚Äôt able to support them much and my brother has a baby and lives out of state too so he is not able to assist. As the eldest daughter most responsibilities fell to me anyway for years. My parents named me POA before all this happened. 

After talking to my husband, he agreed to try moving to IL where I grew up. He will be able to transfer for work. I pray he can get the same shift. I also do have social connections in the area some of which he knows. We will not be too far from Chicago, so for people without kids in their early 30s that at least sounds appealing. He said he likes my hometown area and does like Chicago, but I really never saw him leaving his home state and at that his parent. We‚Äôre still young so maybe the change will be good, as long as we can get out of cohabitation quickly. We plan to live with my parents briefly in order to find a new home that fits our budget and needs. I want the best for my husband too, and I feel he is the one sacrificing the most here. He seems a bit despondent even though he hides it well. I just don‚Äôt know what to do. I can‚Äôt abandon my parents, but I also don‚Äôt want to ruin my husband‚Äôs life and or marriage. It‚Äôs like a no win situation. 

I guess what I am asking is if any of you have experience with this? What can I do to help support my husband in this change? Am I making a mistake?

I know TLDR sorry‚Ä¶

stories.title: Mom wants a dog
stories.story:
My mother (76) is in rough physical shape. She‚Äôs paralyzed from the waist down and has limited mobility in her upper body. She‚Äôs in assisted living and receiving hospice care for stage 4 cancer. 

One of the biggest battles she‚Äôs fighting is loneliness. I live across the country but speak with her daily. My brother visits her often. We encourage her friends and other family to check in with her often and visit when they‚Äôre able. She has access to activities through her assisted living facility. But she‚Äôs certain that the cure for her loneliness would be adopting a dog.

Last year, when she was still living at home, her 16-year-old dachshund passed away. She was able to keep the dog because her roommate would feed and walk him. Otherwise he sat on the bed with her. 

She believes that if she could move to a pet-friendly facility and hire someone to take it out for walks twice a day, she could get a dog. I can‚Äôt convince her how bad of an idea it would be for her to take on the care of any pet, let alone a pet that needs that much work. 

 I‚Äôve encouraged her to have a therapy dog visit, but she wants a dog that ‚Äúknows her‚Äù. I‚Äôve affirmed her feelings, that she‚Äôs in a really difficult situation and that dogs are great companions, but that it‚Äôs not something that can work. It‚Äôs become a fixation now, something she blames for any bad mood. ‚ÄúI want my dog.‚Äù

Has anyone else dealt with a similar fixation? I‚Äôm having the same conversation over and over and it‚Äôs just leaving us both frustrated.

I have taken care of everything and taken him on vacation, appointments, cleaned cooked, paid for his phone etc. He has never worried about anything.  But I lost my job 2 months ago and now I find myself financially strapped.  I hope to get a job soon but we booked a trip a year ago for October and my dad really wanted to go so I never cancelled.  I feel like it‚Äôs my responsibility to take him on all the trips he wants to go on before he dies. Don‚Äôt get me wrong he had been gairly functioning up till a year ago but at 88 he has slowed down significantly and he is an alcoholic.  It‚Äôs gotten very bad lately and I don‚Äôt get a break.  Even though I have 4 sisters left , they don‚Äôt offer. Last time I had to beg my mother be sister to take him for 2 weeks.  It has become very mentally and emotionally difficult for me.  But to get to the question he has lived free for 5 years with me , now that I‚Äôm financially strapped due to unemployment, AITAH for asking for money.  Just an fyi, he has 5 pensions and has a lot of money just never felt right asking him for any and he never offered.

But I justify it saying that I‚Äôve paid for him for 5 years.  Now wait till my sister finds out I‚Äôm sure she is going to have something to say.  She normally takes care of his finances while I do everything else. stories.title: The Good Death by Suzanne O'Brien
stories.story:
**The Good Death** by Suzanne B. O'Brien
This isn't a pitch. It is a review of a book my wife and I found very helpful and something I think the people in this subreddit would also find helpful. 

I read this for 2 reasons: My local death collective had a read-a-long and I'm helping my wife's mother (90+, dementia (mix of Lewy Body and vascular), diabetes). I'm glad for the read-a-long because it made me accountable even with nutty schedules. And I'm glad I read it. 

The book is in two parts - part one is facilitating a good death, part two is the good death planner. Now, I think everyone should read this book - whether they're a caregiver or not. Why? Because death is part of the process and no one gets out of here alive.

The first part is something that everyone that's a caregiver should read. Whether it's been 10 years or you're just finding out about what you're getting into. Why? Bluntly, most caregiving roles end in the death of the person you're caring for. This book is very clear and concrete in what a caregiver will be dealing with. It's particularly clear in laying out the symptoms of the most common terminal diseases (that would be chapter 4). Also, avoiding caregiver burnout (chapter 5).

In part two, O'Brien begins taking the reader through planning for a good death. And this is in all types - physical, mental, emotional, financial and spiritual. These are exercises that I think everyone ought to go through. Why? Because chance favors the prepared mind. Having a plan for how you're going to die and all the things around it (like, who do you want to bathe you?) will make things a lot easier for you and your loved ones. And if you're a caregiver, it isn't too late to discuss this with your loved one. You can at least try.

Now, after reading it I think **The Good Death** is golden for the first part. It's clear and concrete and up front about what's happening. The second part earns silver. It does get into the planning for death, but it feels more like work book than a guide. Still, it is an excellent book and one that everyone should read. Five stars ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ.

stories.title: Georgia: Power of Attorney
Family of resident putting too much pressure on solely me
stories.story:
I work in a care home as the activities lead/manager. I genuinely really enjoyed my job. I work hard and I get a lot of pleasure out of care for people's loved ones. The job itself is stressful and I do a lot more behind the scenes that I dont think people are always aware of. I used to be on a job share until they left but I'm now the sole person in the role. Im currently working 6 day weeks and planning for 7 days. I really try to do a mixture of activities, we do 2 bus trips a week, I book entertainment, organise visits from local schools etc  I do absolutely all the activities and as much as I enjoy myself it is exhausting at times. Now I totally understand that if you're paying the amount of money that is charged in the home im working in for your family you want daily activities but I cannot constantly be entertaining 40 plus people everyday and doing admin and filing my reports. Sometimes for instance we will do a morning of colouring and sudoku because its just a chilled out activity and gives me time to get stuff done. 

One of the residents families has mentioned to me a couple of times that they dont think the activities are up to scratch. For the record I had been on annual leave during this time so it was out of my control. If im being perfectly honest they just tend to get on at me for every little thing, if they can complain they will. We had a singer in last week and I have to take pictures because its part of my JD to publish to our online pages for families to see... they complained to my manager who told them I was literally doing my job. They complained because I hadn't asked the nurses to stop doing their job and come listen to the singer for an hour. I also have second job and one of the family members saw me there and reported it to my manager who once again told them that I have another job. 

Its just hard and honestly it's a lot on my shoulders, I know its my job but I really think there's way too much pressure on me sometimes to constantly be entertaining and performing and doing absolutely everything. 
Think I just needed to offload! But honestly any advice would be helpful! Not sure if I should start to document any complaints

stories.title: Recroding devices for capturing elder abuse
stories.story:
Hi all,

We have an elder family member that lives with a younger family member. We know there have been some verbally abusive instances from the younger member to their elder. 

We don't know if these are isolated or infrequent instances or if they are more pervasive.  

We want to find a way to surreptitiously record audio in an attempt to alleviant or confirm our fears. In our state this is allowed as it is the elder's house and it's legal for the recording party (the elder for this example in their own home) to do so.

Here is where it gets a bit interesting - The younger family member is extremely paranoid and would likely be extremely suspicious of anything noticeable plugged in, etc.

I'm ideally looking for something that can record to the internet that I can still wire in somehow that would be covert - That way battery life isn't an issue as well retrieving memory cards.  However, I'm open to using something battery powered and with memory cards if it is the easiest solution and most covert. 

Anyone have to go through this? It is eating away at us that our own family member might be abusing our own. The elder has always been extremely meek/passive and has said they are afraid of this family member but is not willing to share how often this potential abuse has been happening.

stories.title: Worked intensely to buy a home for elderly mom. She doesnt want to live there and asked me if she'd be eligible to buy her own home.
stories.story:
Im numb.

Ive busted by tail to purchase a home for my elderly mom as its what we've discussed for the past decade or more. Weve always been super close and this has been my commitment to her. Never in my wildest dreams did I ever think I'd be able to make this happen in this economy and based on my humble beginnings. 

My mom had a stroke in 2023. Recovered but we're definitely noticing personality changes, at a minimum. Much more argumentative and frequently spinning up manipulative banter about how she doesnt need me and that I should leave her alone and allow her to move to a shelter or low income housing. As much as possible, I ignored. 

All the while, my mom continued to join me on open house viewings, and I literally passed up half a dozen homes because they weren't right for her (accessibility, location etc)

This past winter, I finally found a home that would work because its close to my sibling and nieces home and closed a few months ago. My mom suddenly went distant - she would come look at the house as a stranger. When I explained how we'd start gradually moving her in, she was quiet. She'll stay a few days then go back to her place. In frustration, Ive asked why shes behaving this way given that Ive emptied out my saving to make sure she has permanent shelter of her own. She shuts the conversation down implying that she never asked me to do this!! I decided that Inhad to ignore whatever was going on for my sanity and to avoid a heart attack. So I just let things be for months - she comes over and stays for a few days, then leaves l, as a visitor. She has a cozy room and Ive spent money on modifications to make things more accomodating. The only thing I cant change are 1. Stairs, 2. No shower on first floor and 3. Gas stove (she prefers electric). 

Just this week, she asked me a question "would she be eligible to purchase a home of her own". I almost lost it but just walked away and pretended to not hear it because I dont want to break down. The lack of gratitude or care! How did it ever get to this point where one is ignoring a HOUSE that was bought for them! In moments where shes complaining she still says things such as "none of her kids care about her" or "she has no one to depend on". WTF!!! I'm thinking about selling the darn home and leaving the rest to God. Not sure what else to do and Im tired. Truly unbelievable.

(He had rented it for a handful of years and landlord wanted to sell.) Both my dad and his gf are of able body and mind. Neither of them have real jobs. This has been causing me crippling anxiety because they need a stable home or like an apartment! I have sent them links to apartments and mobile home parks to which they act insulted but i'm like you are grown adults bouncing between relatives and hotels? All their belongings are in storage. They are in deep denial. We grew up in nice suburbs and lived a comfortable life and I am so shocked my dad is completely broke. My siblings don't seem to want to help and they are also in denail. I know they both get ss but don't think they have any other income. My dad had a lifelong career and I just can't believe this. Everyone can't believe even after all this the gf hasn't gotten a job like at a grocery store or cleaning. Has anyone else experienced this?? This business was started by my grandfather in 1995. I‚Äôve worked in it since day one and fully ran it after his passing in 2016. We even paid a tax bill to prevent the property from being lost earlier this year ‚Äî and now the state wants to sell it out from under us.

We are very picky about exposing her to medical procedures, as she has dementia and anesthesia can make that worse. 

So we went ahead with eye 1. They used just versed for the procedure (I met with the anesthesiologist abs told him her issue) she was MOST unhappy BUT. After 2 days of drops she can SEE. She's recently admitted that sometimes, if me and my sister are both away working, she gets very lonely on bank holiday weekends when everyone in her area seems to be away, so there isn't even the normal friendly noise of children, families, workmen etc which provide her with a lot of solace. She's said that she would consider going into respite care for short stays during those empty bank holiday weekends. My initial enquiries have not gone well - many care homes do a minimum of a two week or even a month respite stay, and she's adamant that she doesnt want to "waste her money" on longer stays. 

I thought maybe she could go on a short break somewhere instead, somewhere where her needs would be met physically but also her companionship needs, but she's said she doesn't want to do a course or learn anything as she's "full up." 

I've learned the hard way that trying to persuade her to do anything she doesn't want to do is completely pointless and I want to respect her wishes and help her find what she needs, but it seems that this is a service that is not easy to find. Her needs are 1. safety and security 2. good food suitable for a diabetic vegetarian 3. some minimal physical assistance, but mainly complete independence 4. A community of people to have fun with. 5. Not too far from where she lives (Penge). Has anyone been through something similar or can advise me where to look? Cheers

stories.title: Siblings don't believe MIL is suffering from cognitive decline
stories.story:
I'm wondering if anyone has any advice for getting my husband's siblings to understand that their 90-year-old mom is probably experiencing symptoms of cognitive decline? Long story short, I had very good reasons to audit her finances earlier this year.  What I found was shocking:

She made 63 different political donations last year totaling over $2,200. She also made a high amount the previous year, and the kicker is that on one occasion, she intended to make a $25 donation but mistakenly made a $2,500 donation instead.  CNN wrote an article not too long ago about how political parties take advantage of elderly donors, and the examples described in it sound disturbingly similar to what I discovered in her bank statements.

Then there were the $6,000 in donations to 60 different charities, some of which are ranked among the worst in the country.  I put her on the DMA Opt Out List, but that doesn't cover entities she has done business with, so I have personally contacted 145 different non-profit and political organizations to request that she be removed from their mailing lists.  I think this issue snowballed over time, because what I have learned is that when a person gives to one charity, that charity turns around and sells their mailing list so now that person will be getting solicitations from more charities, and then they will give more money to more charities and end up on even more mailing lists.  I am well aware that when an elderly person starts donating to charities that they have never supported before, it could be an early warning sign of dementia.

She has three different risk factors for dementia.  My husband has been trying to get her to see her doctor for a cognitive assessment, but has not been successful thus far.

My mother-in-law now understands that her political and charitable giving got out of control, and she has been sending back unopened envelopes, but the fact remains that her judgement is often lacking.  For example:

She spent $2,000 dollars last year to have some crab grass ripped up and replaced with new seed.  The problem is, it was the end of the summer and the frost would have killed off the crab grass within a matter of weeks.  The salesperson should have put her down for a crabgrass treatment in the spring, but probably saw an easy mark.

Around the same time, she spent $5,000 to have hundreds of pounds of perfectly fine stone mulch hauled away and replaced with wood mulch.  When I asked her what the $5,000 landscaping bill was for, she couldn't remember.  When I called the company and had them send an itemized list of charges, she said she must not have bothered to look at the price before signing the contract.

When we discovered the excessive lawn and landscaping charges, we talked to her about how they were not really necessary, but she apparently forgot this.  On Mother's Day this year, I thought it would be wise to ask her about her lawn care plans for the season, and she said she was going to have her lawn care company come out and rip up more grass because there were a few bare spots in the lawn.  She said price tag on this little project was "over $1,000."  We convinced her not to do it, and my husband came over and put down some grass seed for well under $100.

She also has problems writing checks.  She ends up throwing away 15% of the checks she writes because she "makes mistakes" when writing them.  We are glad she catches most of them, but how much longer can we count on her to continue catching her own mistakes?  We did get her bills set up on autopay, so that should at least minimize this risk.  Again, I am well aware that difficulty writing checks is an early warning sign of cognitive decline.

I should also note that she recently told me that my late father-in-law always handled their money and she knows nothing about finance.  That would probably explain why her discount financial advisor's decisions have resulted in her paying a total of $56,000 in largely avoidable capital gains taxes over just two different tax years.  My husband and I have started attending calls with her financial advisor with her.  My husband knows very little about finances and has to lean heavily on me during these calls.

When my husband brought these issues to the attention of his brother, he said he was her power of attorney but that he "struggled to manage his own finances."  He offered no help.  We brought up the possibility of cognitive decline with him.  We showed examples of his mom's issues and we cited reliable sources, but we don't think he believed us.  When my husband discussed this with his sister who lives six hours away, she said that their mom "has always been altruistic" and so her excessive charitable donations are "fine."

My husband recently convinced his mom to give him power of attorney, but since he knows very little about finances, his responsibilities are falling heavily on me.  He is trying to learn and I am even giving him hands-on training exercises, but I have significant experience doing corporate training and I know that his financial knowledge won't come overnight and will slowly grow over time.

His brother and sister are not helping.  And why should they?  Their mom is still driving and living in her house, so that means everything is fine, I guess.  I should also note that I have multiple relatives who have lived into their 90s and beyond, so I am well-versed on issues related to aging.  That has not been the case in my husband's family, and his mom has lived the longest of anyone.  Therefore, my husband does not recognize other, subtle signs of aging until I point them out.  I suspect his brother and sister are in the same boat, and any feelings of denial they might be having are just making it worse.
