stories.title: What Customer Stories Taught Me About Family Dynamics and Mobility Challenges
stories.story:
I work in the mobility assistance industry, and over the past few years, I've had the privilege of speaking with hundreds of customers about their experiences with mobility challenges. One pattern keeps emerging that I think this community would find valuable: the universal struggle of when and how to tell family about mobility issues.

I wanted to share some insights from these conversations, especially since so many people seem to go through similar emotional journeys, regardless of their specific condition.

# The "Secret Keeping" Phase

This happens way more often than I expected. I'd say about 60-70% of our customers mention initially hiding their struggles, even from close family.

One customer, Howard, who has IBM, told me: "I was diagnosed at the very beginning of 2018. It was a shock to me. I was very upset and depressed that I had IBM, and I didn't tell anybody about it, not even my family, just my wife."

Another customer with multiple sclerosis shared how his wife had to physically help him stand with a "one, two, three" routine, but they kept this private struggle within their immediate household for months.

# Why People Wait to Tell Family

From the stories I've heard, the reasons are usually:

Fear of becoming a "burden" - This comes up constantly. People worry family will feel obligated to help or change their lives.

Loss of identity - Many describe feeling like they're no longer the "strong one" or "independent one" in the family.

Uncertainty about solutions - A lot of people wait because they don't know what options exist, so they feel like they're just sharing problems without solutions.

Protecting family from worry - Especially common with parents not wanting to worry adult children.

# The Turning Point Stories

What's interesting is hearing about what finally motivates people to open up:

Safety scares - Often it's a near-fall or actual fall that makes secrecy impossible.

Missing out on family events - One customer told me about skipping his granddaughter's graduation because he was worried about the seating situation.

Spouse exhaustion - Partners often become the "bridge" between the person with mobility challenges and the rest of the family.

Finding solutions - Howard's story continues: "Then, lo and behold, I heard about SitnStand. I looked at it. I couldn't believe it. I bought it. I still couldn't believe how well it worked. It just gives me the confidence to go anywhere I want at any time."

# What I've Learned About "The Conversation"

From successful family conversations I've heard about:

Timing matters - Most people say it worked better when they had some kind of solution or plan to discuss, not just the problem.

Start with one person - Usually a spouse or adult child who can help navigate telling others.

Focus on maintaining independence - Frame it around "here's how I'm staying active" rather than "here's what I can't do."

Be specific about help needed - Instead of general "I might need help," people respond better to "I might need help with X situation."

# The Surprising Positive Outcomes

What really struck me from these stories is how often family involvement actually improved things:

* Reduced isolation - No more making excuses for avoiding gatherings
* Shared problem-solving - Families often research solutions together
* Increased social activities - With the right tools, many customers report doing MORE with family than before
* Deeper relationships - Several people mentioned feeling closer to family after being honest

One customer's spouse told us: "It's really transformed my life, not just his. We've just been praying that God would show us a way... and all of a sudden, this solution came across the internet for him, and he found it."

# For Those Still Waiting

If you're reading this and still haven't had "the conversation" with your family, here's what I'd suggest based on these customer experiences:

1. Research your options first - Having even one potential solution makes the conversation feel more hopeful
2. Start with your biggest supporter - Usually there's one family member who you know will be understanding
3. Focus on activities you want to keep doing - Rather than limitations, talk about goals
4. Be open to family input - Sometimes they've been worried too and are relieved to finally discuss it

# Questions for This Community

I'm curious about your experiences:

* Did you go through a "secret keeping" phase? How long?
* What finally motivated you to tell family?
* How did your family react compared to what you expected?
* Any advice for others still struggling with this decision?

I know every situation is different, but I've been amazed by how many common themes emerge across different conditions and family dynamics. Would love to hear your thoughts or experiences.

Note: I work for a company that makes mobility assistance devices, so I hear these stories in that context. I'm sharing because I think the emotional/family aspects are universal, regardless of specific solutions people choose.

stories.title: Can I reach out for support about a friend who needs more care than I can give?
stories.story:
Hi, first time commenting, I'm just looking for someone to talk to because I'm freaking worried and don't know what to do. I have a friend for whom I'm one of a small group of people caring for her and we're all worrying. 

Let me call her "Bee". She has family in a distant country and talks to them on the phone but hasn't seen them in person in many years. I think the family members she's closest to don't speak English so it'd be difficult for me to discuss with them if I wanted to. So people who're with her day to day are all friends.

So, Bee is extremely independent, extremely determined. She has very bad knees and a host of other health problems that have prevented her getting knee replacement. Also she has financial and insurance problems that make it hard for her to get a wheelchair or an accessible apartment. For the last few years she was continuing to walk around even though it caused her agony -- she wouldn't move out of her apartment to assisted living, refused the prospect of leaving her cats and losing her independence. She got to the point where she couldn't leave her chair very much. I and other people go there every day to get her food and do some cleaning. 

So, a month ago her knees finally said No More and now she cannot even stand up... Not even to use the potty so she's just changing pads under her with great difficulty and you can imagine how well that doesn't work. It's awful, and she's getting so sick from immobility and poor sanitation. None of us friends is a nurse, we don't know how to lift her up and help. But she Will Not Hear of living elsewhere! She's just trying to get her insurance to provide her with a home nurse and so far they won't. She refuses to even stay in the hospital for a day, even if she's sick and in horrible pain. 

How do you talk to someone like that??? We've all said, look, this is impossible, can't you just stay at a rehab center until better care arrangements are sorted out? And gotten a flat NO.

stories.title: He fed on their guilt and love for decades. I told them it was time for change.
stories.story:
Hi all I spent countless hours on this letter and thought I would share it in the hope it might help someone please give me feedback on it (names changed for privacy):-

Hi Kenadee / Sylvania

I hope this message finds you both well and at peace.

Of all the messages I‚Äôve shared, this one feels the most important. I‚Äôve put a great deal of time and thought into writing it, and I‚Äôd be very grateful if you could read it fully, with care and an open mind.

I‚Äôve truly poured my heart and soul into it. Not for drama, but because I genuinely can‚Äôt stand to see good people mistreated, manipulated, or emotionally drained.

I‚Äôm writing because I want to help limit Jono‚Äôs ability to cause harm ‚Äî not just to others, but to himself as well.

Some of what follows may overlap with things we‚Äôve already discussed, but I thought it would be helpful to have everything gathered clearly in one place ‚Äî all the cards on the table, so to speak.

There‚Äôs absolutely no pressure to reply or take action. This is simply here for your reflection and consideration ‚Äî whenever you feel ready.

**The Core Problem**

With someone like Jono, virtually any emotional response becomes¬†**narcissistic supply**:

* Praise? Supply.
* Criticism? Supply.
* Outrage or disgust? Still supply.
* Calm advice? Supply again.
* A regular chat? Yes ‚Äî still supply.
* Reacting to a letter ‚Äî positively or negatively? More supply.

He thrives on eliciting emotional reactions ‚Äî approval, disapproval, concern, anger. They all feed his sense of control and importance.

**How He Harms You ‚Äî and How to Protect Yourselves**

You might feel he ‚Äúcan‚Äôt really hurt you‚Äù anymore. But emotional manipulation¬†**is**¬†a form of harm ‚Äî especially when it causes distress, confusion, robs you of peace and precious sleep.

Think back to the letter he sent to his mum. Did it upset you? Most likely.  
Think of the never-ending lies, scams, and manipulations ‚Äî too many to list in one email. You‚Äôve seen firsthand just how calculated and damaging his actions can be.

It may be painful to hear, but I believe Jono¬†**relished**¬†the distress those events caused. Not just for leverage ‚Äî but for the emotional reaction itself. That‚Äôs¬†**narcissistic supply**. For him, that‚Äôs a win.

That‚Äôs why I urge you to adopt the¬†**Grey Rock Method**.

If long-term no contact isn‚Äôt feasible, this is the next best thing: no emotional responses, no deep conversations, no advice ‚Äî just¬†**polite, minimal interaction**. This is different from your previous ‚Äútime-outs.‚Äù It means no email advice, no coaching, no gentle guidance.

Try it for a defined period ‚Äî say,¬†**60 or 90 days**.

You don‚Äôt need a long explanation for Jono. Simply say you need some time to yourselves. He may demand a justification or try to debate it ‚Äî but you don‚Äôt owe him anything.¬†**Your preferences and needs are reason enough.**

At the end of that time, ask yourselves honestly:

* Do I feel calmer?
* Less drained?
* Did the confusion and guilt start to fade?

**You may find that Grey Rock isn‚Äôt just a boundary ‚Äî it‚Äôs a relief.**

Imagine carrying a heavy bag of rocks on your back for decades ‚Äî and finally giving yourself permission to put it down.  
Be¬†**one grey rock**, instead of carrying a¬†**bag full of them**.

I know Grey Rock or No Contact can seem extreme ‚Äî but based on everything we‚Äôve seen, I genuinely believe they‚Äôre the only approaches that protect your peace and stop the cycle. Even ‚Äúfirm boundaries‚Äù still risk feeding the manipulation. He‚Äôs¬†**too skilled**¬†at twisting softer limits.

**Ask Yourself Honestly**

After a typical interaction with Jono, do you feel:

* Uplifted and calm? Or:
* Drained, irritated, confused, guilty?

If it‚Äôs the latter ‚Äî that‚Äôs harm. Subtle at first, but devastating over time.

And if emotional manipulation stops working, I wouldn‚Äôt be surprised if he escalates to anger or contempt (‚ÄúYou‚Äôre horrible for treating me this way!‚Äù). That‚Äôs when people often see a narcissist‚Äôs true self ‚Äî as I did.

**The Nasty message Incident**

I believe the Nasty message upset you so deeply because it exposed something real ‚Äî not just contempt for me, but contempt for everyone,¬†**including you both**.

He sent me similar kinds of affectionate messages to the ones that you receive. But that Nasty message shows what he really thinks behind all the manipulative affection.

Jono‚Äôs actions ‚Äî his rejection of your values, his boundary violations, his lies ‚Äî make it clear: he has¬†**no genuine love or regard**¬†for your emotional wellbeing. Your peace and happiness mean¬†**absolutely nothing**¬†to him.

Someone who truly loves and respects you wouldn‚Äôt behave like this for years or decades.

**Narcissists Cannot Love or Respect Others**

This isn‚Äôt personal ‚Äî it‚Äôs¬†**pathological**. It‚Äôs a well-established psychological truth:

A narcissist cannot love or respect anyone but themselves.

Trying to help or fix them only drains the helper. And every bit of emotional energy you give becomes¬†**fuel**¬†‚Äî for more dysfunction and harm.

It‚Äôs like trying to put out a fire by¬†**pouring petrol on it**.

**What I‚Äôm Absolutely Certain Of**

You both deserve a¬†**peaceful, emotionally fulfilling**¬†retirement.

You‚Äôve lived lives grounded in honesty and integrity. That should be¬†**rewarded**, not disrupted by guilt or chaos from someone who preys on others.

You owe Jono nothing. You‚Äôve already done¬†**far more**¬†than he deserves. He‚Äôs not a helpless child ‚Äî he‚Äôs a fully capable adult.

You are not obligated to parent, guide, or emotionally support him anymore. That‚Äôs not cruelty ‚Äî it‚Äôs¬†**self-preservation**.

**The Guilt Trap**

I know you don‚Äôt want to ‚Äúabandon‚Äù Jono ‚Äî because you love him. That‚Äôs natural.

But I believe this guilt has been¬†**deliberately planted**¬†in your minds by Jono through phrases like:

* ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre all I have.‚Äù
* ‚ÄúI‚Äôd be nothing without you.‚Äù
* ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre my only hope.‚Äù

These are¬†**manipulations**¬†‚Äî designed to weaponize your empathy.

He presents as a helpless child to trigger your nurturing instinct. If another persona worked better, he‚Äôd use that instead. It‚Äôs all a calculated presentation.

**Rubbing Your Face in the Chaos**

Why does he tell you about his ‚Äúscams and misdeeds‚Äù knowing it‚Äôll upset you?

Why does he ask for your advice ‚Äî then completely ignore it?

Because he enjoys the distress and drama it causes. He has no respect for your peace, time, or emotional safety.¬†**Your needs simply don‚Äôt matter to him.**

You may have adapted to the chaos ‚Äî it might feel familiar after decades. But familiarity doesn‚Äôt mean it‚Äôs healthy.

You can choose something better.

**Peace is not a luxury. It‚Äôs your right.**

**If Jono Were an Alcoholic...**

If Jono were an alcoholic, would you give him a drink because he begged or sent an ‚ÄúI love you‚Äù photo?

No ‚Äî because you know that¬†**one drink**¬†leads back to chaos.

Now think of emotional responses as¬†**alcoholic drinks**¬†‚Äî and Jono as addicted to narcissistic supply.

Why keep giving him that drink, knowing it leads to pain for everyone?

**On Love and Enabling**

You can love someone and¬†**still protect yourself**.  
You can love someone and¬†**still say no**.  
You can love someone ‚Äî and go no contact or grey rock ‚Äî to prevent harm.

That‚Äôs not cruelty.  
That‚Äôs¬†**strength and preservation.**  
That‚Äôs¬†**love with boundaries**.

**You Don‚Äôt Have to Do This Alone**

If this feels overwhelming, please consider speaking to a therapist or psychologist. Many have¬†**extensive experience**¬†dealing with narcissistic family dynamics.

There are online options ‚Äî fully private and on your schedule ‚Äî or local professionals in your area. If you‚Äôd like, I‚Äôd be happy to help you find one.

You could even share this message with them as a starting point.

**Things Need to Change**

Sometimes people come into your life for a reason.

Maybe Jono came into mine so I could meet you ‚Äî to learn from your kindness, your values, and your generosity.

And maybe I came into your life to help you¬†**finally escape the cycle**¬†of emotional abuse.

I‚Äôve only dealt with Jono‚Äôs abuse for a few years ‚Äî and even that was more than enough. I can‚Äôt imagine what you‚Äôve endured over the decades.

What I know is this:

I will¬†**never again**¬†give Jono the narcissistic supply I used to.  
That ends now. Forever.

Whatever you decide, I‚Äôll continue to wish you peace and happiness ‚Äî always.

**With warmth and hope,**

**Your friend over the pond,**

**Lew**

stories.title: My dad with dementia has completely lost it
stories.story:
My mom had a stroke and never woke up a week and a half ago. We had to take her off life support last Wednesday, and after palliative for a week, she finally passed two days ago. My dad already had to be taken to the hospital last weekend because he kept taking his clothes on and off and threatening to cut the tube of his Foley catheter. This morning, he pulled out his Foley catheter. I can't handle this. It's just my 19 year old nephew and myself living with him, and we just can't do it. 

I also have bipolar disorder, and I've gone from mania into manic psychosis. A voice is back that hasn't been in my head since my last episode 7 years ago. It's ME who needs to be in a fucking hospital, in a psyc ward. 

If only he had passed first! I'm so fucking angry! I don't want to take care of him. I don't want to lose the house either. If he goes into a nursing home, I'll be homeless. 

I'm so fucking angry at him!!! He's ruining my fucking life!! I just want my mom back, and him gone!!!!! I don't care about the reality of his illness. 

In fact, I just wish that I had passed away!!!!!

stories.title: Just having my feelings

I just had to send her screenshots of how to find the phone function and where the keypad is. I had to explain to her how to turn the volume up on her ringer. She‚Äôs like a child now. But we can‚Äôt live together. She‚Äôs reverse mortgaged her house, so she doesn‚Äôt own it anymore and we‚Äôre stuck in a 2 bedroom house with 2 kids, 2 dogs, and 2 cats. We literally have no room for her or her 3 dogs. But she doesn‚Äôt need to live alone, and we can‚Äôt afford to put her in a home, but even if we could she threatens to off herself if we even talk about it (which is silly bc we literally can‚Äôt afford it). But the fact that she doesn‚Äôt even understand her own phone now is just so‚Ä¶.. there‚Äôs just so many feelings that I can‚Äôt even put it into words. I never anticipated that I would have to be my own mother‚Äôs caregiver. Or that she would devolve into the person she‚Äôs become, who is so absolutely opposite of the person she‚Äôs was when she was raising me. I don‚Äôt know this woman. I haven‚Äôt known her for a long, long time. And it‚Äôs just so strange to say that, and sad to say that. It‚Äôs like I already lost my mom, and now I take care of this angry, scared, confused shell that looks like my mom. Does that make sense? I don‚Äôt need anything from this story, I just wanted to put it out there, needed to get it off my chest. stories.title: Ensuring my father's "final approach" doesn't hurt us
stories.story:
Throwaway account since I want more pseudonymity. I am cross-storying from other subreddits to get additional exposure and support. 

  
I was born and raised in California, and I am now almost 37 years old, the youngest of three sons. My father is 83, turning 84 this year. He is still relatively spry and independent, but age is slowly catching up to him. He does not need a caretaker, yet my brothers and I have been helping him navigate life on "final approach" (his words) since his wife and our mother passed away in 2021. It has not been easy.

My mother died in 2021 after complications of a lifetime of smoking. He was glad to see her through her end of life. Unfortunately, she was a severe hoarder. The house was at a "level 5" after her passing, when I helped my dad find a group to help him clear out the house. I was transitioning out of active duty military service on the East Coast and was working to return to school at the time. I linked him up with Steri-Clean to help with the hoard, which significantly improved the interior of the house.

Unfortunately, we are at an impasse. Three years after this, and despite several major property renovations, my father still needs help. I ended up back living with him and sought to help as much as I could while navigating my current work life. We have old cars to get rid of, sheds to organize and clear, a yard full of rubbish and hazardous materials. The interior still requires a significant amount of clearing and organization, including the donation of and selling of items. He also has been derelict in estate planning. He says it's 75% complete, but this has been ongoing since 2022. He repeatedly told me to nag him to get it done, but has also been dismissive about the consequences of what would happen if he were to die without planning completed. 

The major kicker for me has been his dedication and obsession with volunteering. He dedicates at least 15 hours a week to veterans' programs, including event planning and administration. He spends most of his time on the computer, where he has much trouble navigating. He also feels obligated when a local event is at risk of failure and tries to step in to save the day. He lets those priorities take precedence over his being active in walking, as well as spending time at his vacation cabin. I helped with some of those efforts for several years. I quit my involvement so I could straighten my priorities and for other reasons. ¬†I want to see him continue doing what he enjoys, but the imbalance throws everything off.

I would sincerely appreciate suggestions on how we can make the "final approach" as easy as possible for him, as well as for us. If he were to die tomorrow, everything would be in probate, and the property would be in an absolute shambles. I would like to recruit one of his close friends on the estate planning side as an accountability buddy, as she has been trying to do the same. I am also hoping to recruit more help with property work so that he can worry less about those things. But it is a continual struggle. Thank you for giving me time to express all of this.

stories.title: Just need to talk about this.
stories.story: My dad is 82. He lives on his own two states away from me. He had knee surgery on Tuesday. I got here two weeks before that, and got his labs and pre-op appointment taken care of. I came prepared to be here for as long as he needed me, up to 90 days. In that two weeks, he fell three times. He has had several episodes of being very disoriented, one time not knowing how to open the garage door in a house he has lived in since 2008. Since his surgery, he has been very altered and has been hallucinating. They haven't been able to do much physical therapy because he's been so out of it. They stopped opioids to see if that was the problem, but he's still talking to people that aren't there.So instead of coming home, he's being transferred to a rehab facility later today. On top of that, in talking to the physical therapist about my dad's gait, he told me that my dad is showing signs of Parkinson's as well. So in a very short time, we're looking at the very real possibility that he is going to have to move into an assisted living facility. I have to talk to his doctor about tests and evaluations. Once we have that information, I'll have some decisions to make, including possibly moving him to the state I live in, which will make him very unhappy.

stories.title: Looking For Financial Assistance Programs
stories.story:
My grandma is 100 years old and had a stroke last year. She‚Äôs been back home since January and lives on the same property as us in her own home which is convenient for times like this because she can‚Äôt really be left alone. I‚Äôm wondering if there are any more financial programs than the ones she‚Äôs already receiving for her at home care. She currently receives VA survivors benefits which is $1,500 a month and just started receiving 40 hours of assistance from a state funded (Massachusetts) Frail Elder Waiver. I just found out about PACE programs so I told my mom to look into the 2 that service our county. We are extremely grateful to receive this help, but I‚Äôm trying to find more for my mom. She pays $1,550 every week for my grandmas morning and night home care, which in order to do so she‚Äôs draining her retirement. She doesn‚Äôt want to take a home equity loan out on my grandmas house, but I think this might be the only other option. I know my mom feels like she‚Äôs drowning and sooner than later there‚Äôs going to be no retirement money left. I just really want to find another option for her before that happens. 

At this point I personally think the home equity is the best option, since the payment would be a lot less than the $6,200 she‚Äôs paying now. Instead of the VA money doing little for that, it could pay for most of the monthly payment on the home equity loan. Any thought and suggestions appreciated!

stories.title: vent/advice request: I need help with my grandmother with dementia
stories.story:
i (19) have a grandmother (96) who is mentally declining. she has been diagnosed with alzheimer‚Äôs/mild dementia, and she lives alone. my father (70) and his sister (70s?) are both unwilling to take care of her. My aunt (dad‚Äôs sister) has her own health complications and cannot live alone either, and is taken care of by her husband. she lives 30 minutes from my grandmother. My dad has no excuse other than not wanting to deal with it, especially because he lives 2 hours away. His wife, my evil stepmother, treats my grandmother poorly anyway, and always makes her feel unwelcome. 


Me and my sibling (23) are the only ones who live close to our grandmother (5 min drive) and regularly check on her. the thing is, we are both college students. while during the summer i am able to sacrifice more time to see my grandmother, in the school year i never have time. my sibling is studying to teach and come next semester, will be doing student teaching and thus will be busy during the daytime hours when she most needs supervising. In other words, we haven‚Äôt even gotten to live and finish our degrees yet and are already being pushed into the position of being live-in nurses.

My dad‚Äôs solution is to ‚Äújust put her in a facility‚Äù because he allegedly doesn‚Äôt have the funds to care for another person in the house (and there‚Äôs literally no physical room for her to stay in) but my argument is that if you have the money to just throw her away like that‚Ä¶ you should just take care of her. 

i‚Äôm a little bit more lenient on my aunts reasoning, especially because her and my grandmother are a handful for my uncle who is mainly concerned with my aunt. still, she has the mental capacity to help with the decision making and should be more involved. both my grandmothers children deny just how bad she‚Äôs gotten‚Äî this is because they don‚Äôt see her nearly as often as we do‚Äî and thus are less inclined to care/understand the severity of the situation. the worst part of this though is that my grandmother is the most stubborn person. she refuses help, and gets in sour moods when someone does something for her. her biggest fear is losing her independence, and i really hate that for her.

i don‚Äôt want her to have to suffer in her final years, i just want her to be happy safe and healthy, surrounded by people she loves. i don‚Äôt want her rotting away in a nursing home. i am horrified to think of my grandmother accidentally leaving the stove on, sleeping with the door open, falling, etc. but worst of all im terrified that any time i go to visit her i will find a corpse, which will leave me traumatized. 

what can i do? what can i say to my aunt and father to make them listen? can this situation even be helped? because there is very very little that i myself can do about it. i don‚Äôt have money to sacrifice for her because im a student. i love my mimi and just want her to have a peaceful life.

stories.title: bed sore help!!
stories.story:
hello reddit! to be completely honest, i‚Äôm freaking out and spiraling down a hole of anxiety. any and all help, advice, or words of support are greatly appreciated. 

my dad is bedridden and lays in a reclining couch chair and has stage 3 bed sore in between his butt cheeks (evaluated by a wound nurse) and we are currently waiting on prescription/order from the doctor. 

we try to adjust my dad to lean left and right every hour or so, but because he‚Äôs in so much pain all the time, it makes it super difficult. additionally, the nature of his couch makes it so he‚Äôs constantly putting pressure on his butt. 


every morning and night, i clean the wound with a saline solution, and then i apply a mixture of maruko honey ointment and zinc oxide cream. then, i cover the wound with either a gauze/bandage or a hydrocolloid patch. i‚Äôve also started him on vitamin C and zinc supplements every morning.

i‚Äôm so anxious, i don‚Äôt know if im doing the right thing. it doesn‚Äôt seem like the wound is getting any better. 

im not sure if i should try a different ointment? i‚Äôve been looking on amazon and i see brands like terrasil or triderma. i also just bought some wedges for him to try and elevate the sides of his body. 

its just me (f21) caregiving for my dad and im so overwhelmed. i‚Äôm doing the best i can but it doesn‚Äôt feel like it‚Äôs enough.

stories.title: Navigating the Decision to Stop Driving for Seniors
stories.story:
For many older adults, driving represents independence, freedom, and routine. But over time, age-related changes can make driving increasingly unsafe.

Recognizing when it's time to have a conversation about stepping away from the wheel can be difficult, but it is an important step in keeping everyone safe. When handled with empathy and thoughtful planning, it can also help preserve a loved one's dignity and sense of independence.

CareForTom, a Vermont-based nonprofit that supports caregivers and older adults, has created a helpful guide to walk families through this sensitive topic. The article covers:

\- Common warning signs that may suggest it is no longer safe to drive

\- How to start the conversation with care and respect

\- Alternatives to driving that support continued independence and connection

The goal isn't to take something away, but to prioritize safety while supporting quality of life.

You can read the full guide here:

[https://www.carefortom.org/resources/when-its-time-to-stop-driving](https://www.carefortom.org/resources/when-its-time-to-stop-driving)

This may be a useful resource for anyone supporting an aging parent or loved one. Discussion and shared experiences are welcome.

stories.title: Both parents at same time
Question About Home Health Aide
stories.story:
TL;DR: when someone dies, how much compensation should their professional home health aide receive from the estate?

Hi, all. My grandmother is nearing the end of her time with us after battling late-stage heart failure for a little over three years. Since April of 2022 she's been unable to live alone but adamant that she remain in her home. To that end, some of our family have taken shifts staying with her and helping her with an increasing number of tasks as her condition and cognition have deteriorated. We were fortunate and privileged to enlist the services of the absolute best home health aide who has made the last three years, while still challenging, at least possible. My question is, when a person passes away, what is appropriate severance compensation for their professional caregiver. I don't want to make it awkward but also can't imagine just waving goodbye is an appropriate response. Is there an agreed-upon standard number of weeks' pay they should receive? It's not something I have experience with, but hopefully some of you are more familiar with industry standards than I am.

stories.title: Bad doctors? Just came back from an appointment with "physical medicine".
stories.story:
Also about many doctor's in general though. Not all of them.. just seemingly 99% of them now days.. She has 1 really good doctor. My mom is 78 years old.



My question is about the physical medicine doctor. I talked to her primary care doctor, about me being concerned about her back pain. So he gave us a referral to Physical Medicine, and we were able to take x-ray's of the spine too.



I was counting on trying to figure out what is safe for my mom to do, maybe some more tests about bone health concerns since she's always fracturing her feet, and also some treatment options to increase bone health, or muscle health. With her ankle x-ray 10 days ago, a radiologist noticed a small bone fragment came loose from ankle. "Well-corticated bone fragment is seen adjacent to the medial malleolus"



Instead he was adamant on only discussing treatment options of "acupuncture, or steroid pills" to treat the back pain, and refused to discuss anything related to general bone health, or any other problems besides her back since her back was the only thing her primary care physician listed in the referral notes.



My mom can hardly walk at all, she's in bed all the time, and can only manage to use a commode right next to her bed. Many elderly that I know are able to walk much more than my mom..and are more active, so I was really hoping on this appointment to figure things out further. Like is it muscle weakness, of maybe look into hip problems, weight problems, position problems, etc?





My mom was complaining during the whole time about feeling uncomfortable, so he was more than happy to cut the appointment short to send us home so "she can be more comfortable".





My mom isn't a very cooperative patient due to her mental state, and I don't have a "power of attorney" over her, so many doctors shut conversations down and end appointments early even when my mom tells them to discuss things with me.



The only good doctor that I know of my mom has had forever is for pulmonary and he is happy to take time with my mom and discuss all of her problems even if it's not his exact specialty, and he's very good at making my mom feel comfortable with the appointment instead of looking to find any excuse to end the appointment early.





The other issue I have with doctors I consider bad is they are quick to hand out treatments and drugs with hardly any discussion. Like I wanna know "is this treatment safe for my mom?" or "Is this treatment necessary for my mom?" Is there any side affects that I should be concerned about? Is there something we can do to make this treatment safer? How does my mom compare to other people her age?



It really feels like most doctors don't care anymore. My mom had a cataract surgery scheduled, and the day it happened, the anesthesiologist actually over ruled the doctor and said "I don't think she's healthy enough to have the surgery" and canceled it. The doctor looked a bit dumbfounded and said "ok".



I still hardly have a clue what's going on, I wish I could get her doctors to care more. I want to find out the exact problems, and treatment options, and the complications that could happen if we do those treatments.



What can I do? I'm hoping I can get her primary care physician to care more somehow..Switching seems very hard to do, and there seems little chance that if we do switch we'll end up with someone better. 



We use Kaiser, southern california.

Little sis is currently unaware that this move is happening, because she has told my mother she will never speak to her again if she puts him into memory care. I obviously know it‚Äôs happening, but haven‚Äôt said anything to my sister, because my mother does not yet want her to know, and I want to keep some sort of peace while the transition is made.  The less I know or am involved, the better.  

I really can‚Äôt help at all with his move, because my mother does not yet want her to know, and if it comes out that I ‚Äòhelped‚Äô with her not knowing‚Ä¶ all hell will break out and there will be an additional family rift.  

The guilt of leaving a 92 year old wheelchair bound woman and her caretaker to deal with this alone, is bad. I wish my mother would tell her, so she could at least get support and help from me and my husband.

My mother is actually afraid of my sister‚Äôs temper.  She‚Äôs not physically violent, just very verbally abusive to her.
The last thing our poor mom needs is my sister carrying out her threat to abandon her and never talk to her again. My sister wears the pants in her family and her husband simply follows her lead.

stories.title: Finding a Place For Mom
stories.story:
**My story, caring for mom with dementia**

¬†

¬†Most people don‚Äôt think about this situation until it happens and then they‚Äôre racing around in a panic looking for information on what to do. That‚Äôs exactly what happened to me. I should‚Äôve known that eventually mom would get old and require around the clock care but for some reason I never prepared for it. Little did I know how hard it would be to get the right information. So, hopefully this article will help prepare others for when this unfortunate situation happens.

¬†When my mother was about 70, her husband (my stepdad) passed away. I noticed a change in her, like forgetting a lot and some anger issues, but nothing major. She ended up losing her home to foreclosure so I moved her in with me. By the way, I‚Äôm a single man, 49 years old and live by myself. She also has COPD, mild heart disease and high blood pressure. Everything went good for the first few years but she progressively started getting worse mentally. She was independent for the most part, so I was able to work and not worry about her. She got to where she refused to leave the house at all and also when her health started to decline, she absolutely refused to see any doctor. She started having severe anxiety and breathing problems and very high blood pressure. She had numerous trips to the hospital for blood pressure issues and breathing issues. A few times I found her on the floor unconscious.

¬†One time, she was rushed to the hospital and we didn‚Äôt think she would make it, she was in bad shape. She eventually started to recover at the hospital but was bed ridden. I talked to the doctors about dementia. I was told that a hospital cannot diagnose dementia. I was told that she would have to go to a psychiatrist. But being that she was bedridden at the time, that was impossible, nor would she ever agree to that. The hospital called one day saying she was ready to be discharged. I panicked! How would I care for someone, by myself, that is bedridden and needs 24 hour care? I had no idea who to call or what to do. They set her up with home hospice which called me and assured me everything would be ok and they will take care of it. They sent her home with a hospital bed and all the equipment we would need. Home hospice, for the first week, came by everyday for about 45 mins per day. After the first week, only 3 times a week. I soon found out insurance wont pay for any more than that and it was up to the family to provide 24 hour care. In my situation, ‚ÄúFamily‚Äù was just me. I was working with a social worker about placement into long term care but was told it could take several months. Luckily I have a sister that lives abroad that flew here to help for a couple weeks until she had to go back to work. Mom started to recover quite quickly and was soon up walking and then was able to take care of herself. They discharged her from hospice care. She did good for about a year but was slowly declining mentally and still refused to see a doctor and follow up visits.

¬†Mom is now 76. One day, I come home for lunch from work and went to check on her and found her unconscious on the floor beside her bed, barely breathing. I called 911 and they transported her to a different hospital this time, which turned out to be a much better hospital than the last. The doctors said she was probably unconscious for at least 8 hours or more. So it must have happened sometime that night as I didn‚Äôt check on her early in the morning because she‚Äôs normally asleep when I leave for work. Turns out both shoulders are fractured, a fracture in her back and neck. Doctors say her bones are very brittle. She recovers while in the hospital for about 10 days. She cant walk but can stand with help, barely. They send her to a rehabilitation facility. Medicare will pay for 21 days, after that there is a copay of $210 a day. While in rehab, her dementia gets worse and worse. I start talking to a social worker to get the process going for long term care.

¬†Mom qualifies for Medicaid for nursing homes, which is different from regular Medicaid. You can have a lot higher income to qualify for Medicaid for nursing homes. She has no assets and only receives SSI. Which isn‚Äôt nearly enough to pay for long term care which, in my area, starts around $8000 a month. So we would have to find a place that accepts Medicaid, which a lot of places are self pay only. They submitted referrals to a few nursing homes and some rejected immediately. Then more referrals are sent out and more rejections. I soon realize that all the facilities request her medical notes and records and I‚Äôm pretty sure it‚Äôs because of her dementia episodes that she‚Äôs rejected, even though she‚Äôs never been Officially diagnosed with dementia. Eventually the social worker tells me that it normally takes 90 days to find someone to accept her. This is where I really start searching for help, knowing that soon they will send her home and I will no longer be able to work.

¬†I start scouring the internet for any help I could find. There are several websites that say they will help you find placement at no cost to you. I called a few, but once you say she will have to use Medicaid, they say they cant help. Those websites are just looking for referral fees for self pay patients. I called numerous government funded programs, center for aging etc, that assist elderly people in these situations. Every single one I called would say, ‚ÄúI recommend you call so and so‚Äù. I call so and so and they say the same exact thing. Not one organization gave me any useful information on what I could do to speed up the process. The 21 days pass and she‚Äôs ready for discharge from rehab, still cant walk and can barely stand with assistance. Most of the time there, she refused physical therapy. After all this time, I never found help or answers to my questions after about 100 phone calls.

¬†They once again send her home and I prepare to quit work to provide 24 hour care. This time they set her up with home health which comes out 2 days a week just to check her vitals. They do provide in home physical therapy also but mom refused any type of physical therapy. I had to assist her to the restroom and help with her diapers so she could use the toilet. After a few days home, she starts waking me in the middle of the night yelling for help. I would go in her room and ask what she needs and she would say she doesn‚Äôt know. She started staying up all night thinking it was daytime, it‚Äôs called sundowners dementia. After about a week or so she started standing and wandering around the house in the middle of the night and a few times she fell and would scream for help. Every night she woke me up yelling for something. I didn‚Äôt sleep for a couple of weeks, a few hours here and there. I started losing my mind and it was scary.

¬†This is where I finally found help! One day, I had her in her wheelchair in the living room watching tv. I walk outside for maybe 2 mins, I come back in and shes screaming for help. I find her on the floor in pain. I get her onto the couch and asked what happened and she didn‚Äôt know. I call home health and told them what happened and they said they will send a nurse out. A few mins later, her case manager from home health called me to see what happened. I explained the situation and told her all about what has been going on as far as wandering at night and the numerous falls. I told her I haven‚Äôt slept in a couple of weeks and I‚Äôm afraid mom will wander outside or god forbid I find her dead one morning. This sweet lady told me she understands what I‚Äôm going through and said ‚Äú I shouldn‚Äôt be telling you this but since she has had a fall, call 911 and send her to the hospital and once she‚Äôs there just refuse to let them send her home, because its an unsafe discharge‚Äù. She said that they will have to find a long term care facility to accept her and they will expedite the process. This blew my mind!! After all this time, Nobody has ever told me this. Now, you have to realize that, by her telling me this, her company is gonna lose this contract with mom. This lady is the one person that actually helped and understood what I was going through. Maybe she went through the same thing with a parent.

¬†So I call 911, they send her back to the same hospital and find out she refractured one shoulder. She stays there for about 11 days and she doesn‚Äôt qualify for another round at a rehab facility because insurance wont cover it. They contact me about discharge planning. I told them she could not come back home because its an unsafe discharge. I told them she has had numerous falls and wanders at night. They said they will start the process of finding placement for long term care. Within a few days, they found a place that accepted her. It sure is amazing how quick this happened when a hospital needs to get rid of a nonpaying patient, being that they couldn‚Äôt bill medicare anymore. Anyway, she is now settled into long term care and turns out that the place she‚Äôs in is a very good facility. They take very good care of her 24 hours a day. I pop in every other day and its been great.

¬†I hope this article helps others through this process. In these situations, it can be just as bad on the caretaker as it does on the parent being cared for. Lack of sleep, depression, not being able to leave the house, not being able to pay the bills, just to name a few. You‚Äôll feel guilty as hell about placing mom somewhere and you‚Äôll feel relief. It‚Äôs completely normal. But you have to do whats best and safest for your parent and you.

¬† Sincerely,¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†

¬†Patrick Parker

¬†

P.S. I highly recommend getting a Durable Power of Attorney and an Advanced Directive ahead of time. Before your parents are in dementia stages or when you start to notice problems. I was lucky to get them signed a couple years ago and it made everything so much easier when all of this happened. Please prepare ahead of time.

stories.title: Mother wants to reverse colostomy, surgeon advises against
stories.story:
To give a little back-story, my mom has been having GI issues since November, but was in denial, and downplayed the seriousness of it. She‚Äôs very anti-doctor and anti-pharma, and didn‚Äôt want to go in to get it diagnosed.

She has fallen several times in the past year. The worst was this past April. I was on a road trip with my girlfriend, and tried calling and texting her several times with no reply. I had the foresight to give her neighbor a house key. I asked him to check on her, and she was collapsed on the floor. There was also a trail of fecal incontinence on the floor.

EMTs estimated she‚Äôd been on the floor for at least 10 hours. She underwent a battery of tests in the hospital, and they determined she had an inflamed sigmoid colon. The inflamed section was removed, and they gave her a colostomy. At the time, they said it could be reversed, and she could regain normal bowel function. 

At her last check up with the surgeon, he recommended against it, and said he thought she should have the colostomy for the rest of her life. A few days ago, it sprung a leak. She‚Äôs currently in skilled nursing. She called me in a bad mood, and said she wanted to do the reversal surgery.

I‚Äôve been reading up on the reversal surgery, and it would require an additional hospital stay and recovery. Risks are an infection, and sporadic bowel function during recovery and possibly months following.

Just wondering if anyone has had an experience themselves or with a loved one that had the colostomy reversal surgery done, and what your experiences were?

Nearly all her meals come from the microwave. She has a toaster that holds a single slice of bread. She also has a toaster oven; however due to her eye sight she can no longer read the buttons to make selections so she doesn‚Äôt use it. 

She doesn‚Äôt shop for herself so she mostly gets the same food on repeat. I try finding new things just to give her some variety but it‚Äôs difficult. Sometimes she has me make food that doesn‚Äôt have microwave instructions, puts it in her microwave after I cook it then microwaves it. 

What I‚Äôm looking for:
	‚Ä¢Frozen meals that taste good and aren‚Äôt too high in sodium
	‚Ä¢Things I can prep or batch-cook that reheat well
	‚Ä¢Shelf-stable or fridge items that pair well with a microwave meal (like small sides, protein boosts, etc.)


Any go-to brands, hacks, or meal routines would be really appreciated. Bonus points for things that don‚Äôt require a lot of cleanup or can be eaten right from the container.

stories.title: Brother-in-law Skimming $$
stories.story:
My brother in law is the eldest of three and 2 years ago given control of in-laws finances. First thing he did was "kidnap" them (mother's words) to an assisted living - literally told them they were visiting for a tour but in reality had already arranged for them to stay.

He had also made all arrangements with a realtor to sell off all of their possessions and then the house which netted ~$3M. The siblings were only alerted of all of this after the deals were done. It was a quick turn around that was clearly planned behind every one's backs.

My father in law passed a month later - he simply gave up after the shock of the move. My mother in law was confused and depressed - she wanted to stay in her home with aides (which she could afford).

Well yesterday we got message from brother in law that he was "blessed" to buy a house for himself...at $300,000 in a condo community. This man is disabled and living on $30,000 annual SSI benefits. He hasn't had a job or other income in 20 years. He insists though that he is paying for the house with his own money. 

My husband and his sister are livid, sister in law especially is heartbroken. She loved her dad and he insisted that brother in law look out for her financially. She has had traumatic experiences in the last several years and getting back on her feet. Brother in law sent her $10,000 after the house sold with a note that she wouldn't be getting anymore money. 

Clearly he "blessed" himself with the new home. We are all concerned because brother in law also has struggled with a gambling addiction. If he is Skimming to buy a house he can't afford, we are all concerned about the possibility of money for mother's care suddenly being gone b/c he relapsed. 

My husband isn't sure there is anything to be done. Is there recourse if the person in charge of $ for an elders care is misusing funds? I should add my mother in law also has dementia.

stories.title: At wits end rant (UK)
stories.story:
I'm not sure if this is mainly a US group, but if there is anyone out there that could advise it would be much appreciated. 

I took over care, in a small capacity, for my father (84) when my mother passed away two years ago. He has professional carers and I deal with groceries, finances, appointments etc. and the stress 

He lives in an 'independent living' facility, so has an alert system if he falls, all the aids - rails, walkers etc - but he just god dam keeps falling. He's had multiple hospital admission and diagnosis that it's either his insulin dosage - type 2 - blood pressure, that's causing the falls, all resolved according to the hospital. 

On his last discharge from hospital, after 8 weeks, he fell again within 4 hours of being home. I was with him until half an hour until he fell, and he was standing and walking ok, for him, while I was there. As soon as he was left alone, he lost balance and was on the floor. He says he just lost his balance on standing, no quick actions or anything he shouldn't be able to do. 

He has a roller walker and a riser chair. And we've had all the council support assessments which come back saying he's mentally and physically able to support himself, and has all the equipment he should need. 

I'm just at my wits end as to how to keep him independent safely. His falls have become more frequent as time has gone on. Before his last hospital admission it was onece every two days and I'm really worried he'll hurt himself on the next fall. Any suggestions much appreciated

stories.title: Rant!  I am starting to resent my parents.
stories.story:
My mother is 92 and mostly not able to get around without a wheelchair or a walker, and is becoming more paranoid and unreasonable.  My father is 91 with Alzheimers and advanced dementia, and he is pretty much completely deaf.  
My 92 year old mother has been the primary ‚Äúcaregiver‚Äù for my father and is in control of all of the decisions for the both of them.  I have power of attorney for my father, both durable and medical, however my mother refuses to give up control.  

They live in a facility with stepped care, and are currently in the independent cottages on the property of the facility.  My father needs to be in memory care, but my mother refuses to put him there.  She recently took a fall, and has been mostly bedridden for the last week.  They have a part-time caregiver who has been working 7 days a week since this happened, but she can only work a few hours a day because she has a 12 year old daughter who needs her.  Since my parents normally go to the dining room of the facility where they live, they have been unable to get their meals without someone bringing them to them, serving them, and cleaning up afterward.  My father needs to be led everywhere they go, and is unable to do anything for himself.  He cannot go to the dining room alone because he doesn‚Äôt know where it is (after five years of going there twice a day, every day) and he gets lost coming back.  

My father cannot be left alone for even a second, so anything that concerns my mother, including doctor‚Äôs appointments, etc, has to include my dad, since he still lives with her and cannot be left alone.  Taking them anywhere is a two person job, because my father gets agitated and someone needs to wrangle him whenever they are out.

Their caregiver, my sister, their neighbors and friends and I have all been taking turns bringing them meals and cleaning up.  And someone has to get my mother up and to the bathroom about every three hours, so we are all driving back and forth to take care of this. 

My main issue is that my mother refuses to go into assisted living or to put my father in memory care.  She is frustrated with him so she is constantly yelling at him, as though he can understand her, and acting like this on purpose.
She had an opportunity to move into the main facility in a preferred unit, but refused it because it wasn‚Äôt on the floor she wanted.  Now there is nothing available, yet they cannot continue to live independently, (they aren‚Äôt now) and my mother has been told that my father needs 12 - 24 hour supervision, every day.  I have looked in to other facilities in the area that may have availability, but she refuses to go anywhere else.  She demands any unit they live have two bedrooms because they have had separate bedrooms for years.  To get someone in-home to watch him is ungodly expensive, and although my parents aren‚Äôt destitute, they don‚Äôt have millions, but most likely won‚Äôt qualify for assistance.  Although my father‚Äôs mind is gone, he is physically very strong and could go on like this for years. 

My mother of course thinks people are stealing from her, and is constantly telling everyone how smart she is, which only shines a light on the fact her facilities are waning.  Her refusal to change their living situation is putting a huge strain on everyone around her.  My sister works full time, but has fortunately been in between jobs the last couple of weeks, only working part time training her replacement, but will be starting her new job on Monday, which is about a 25 mile drive.  She has a husband who wants her around when she isn‚Äôt working.  I only live in the area during the summer to help out, and actually live two states away, and have a husband who is 78 years old and very dependent on me.  

Her increasingly unreasonable behavior is becoming alarming, and my sister and I are seriously considering guardianship.  Everything you present to her is met with an immediate ‚ÄúNO‚Äù which she yells before you even finish speaking.

(Sorry this is so long and if you are still with me, I truly appreciate you.)  How have any of you out there dealt with a situation like this?

stories.title: Trying to get state support for my elderly father in Georgia‚Äîfeeling stuck between family, finances, and care needs
stories.story:
I‚Äôm (37) based in California and my father (87) lives in Georgia with his wife (this is a second marriage for both of them). He‚Äôs legally blind due to untreated glaucoma‚Äîhe lost his sight mostly because no one was there to help administer his eye drops or take him to doctor‚Äôs appointments. He‚Äôs HIV positive, and diabetic. 

His wife also has dementia and her adult son lives in the home. Up until two years ago, she was his primary caretaker. She‚Äôs come to a point where she does not remember much of anything. The son helps his mother with her meds, but has made it clear he will not assist my father. I flew out to Georgia recently and tried to hire in-home help, but the son refused to contribute to the cost of care‚Äîdespite living in the home and watching my dad deteriorate.

I‚Äôve burned through my FMLA, and was let go. I can‚Äôt afford to relocate to Georgia without compromising my career and home life in L.A. I‚Äôm now looking into whether I can call Adult Protective Services or get the state to step in and assign a social worker, initiate Medicaid, or even take legal guardianship if my dad can‚Äôt advocate for himself. At this point, he‚Äôs refusing to leave Georgia. 

Has anyone else done something similar‚Äîessentially ‚Äúsurrendering‚Äù a vulnerable parent to state care from out of state? What was your experience like? Did APS actually follow up? Did your loved one end up in a good facility? Did you feel guilty afterward, or relieved?

I feel torn and exhausted, but I‚Äôm also trying to be realistic. I‚Äôm doing everything I can from across the country, but I‚Äôm hitting a wall. Any guidance, experiences, or even emotional support would be appreciated.

stories.title: At home care ‚Ä¶
stories.story:

I will have someone come in 3 days a week and help with bathing, tidying up, cooking and medication management. 

Can you tell me what is expected of me?Do I tip?  Do I really trust this person to run errands and shop for me?

stories.title: Where do I even begin?
stories.story:
My mother lives alone and I live about a mile away. She is 80 and seems to be ‚Äúslowing down‚Äù more and more. Although she has always been on the quieter side and introverted, she has had less and less interest in socializing, taking walks (her only form of exercise) and now, doesn‚Äôt cook much anymore even though she used to love cooking. She almost never calls me to check in or chat, so I do all the checking in. When we talk, she almost never asks me about my life or my interests, it‚Äôs only me asking her questions or prompting her to make conversation. She has been more forgetful, and has been getting confused more, but nothing like dementia-related confusion that I read about. I‚Äôve asked her if she feels depressed and she says no, and I take her in for regular check ups and all necessary health care. I‚Äôve thought about the possibility of some hearing loss, so I will take her to an audiologist. Also, English is not her primary language so I think this adds to the confusion because I only speak English. I‚Äôve started taking back to the church she used to go to before the pandemic, which is in her language, so she has been happy to go.
I know she would probably do much better/be happier if we lived together but neither of us want to live in each others‚Äô houses. I have a great husband who is very supportive, and we are about to become empty nesters. It really seems like she needs someone to live with though, so I‚Äôm really torn because I can‚Äôt take care of 2 houses properly, and she is not really taking care of hers.  I hate thinking that she‚Äôs all alone, watching tv by herself 90% of the day. I try to go on walks with her when I can but I have a job and house/family to take care of and other things I like to do.
On top of all of this, she doesn‚Äôt have a will, but she does have TOD on all of her accounts.  I‚Äôm thinking: 
1. Get her to do a will and power of attorney, etc since I can see her mental clarity starting to slip. How do I do this? Do I hire an estate planner/attorney? It isn‚Äôt a very complicated estate.
2. Who can I talk to for advice on what else to do? (Besides Reddit, lol!) I feel like I need advice for her and therapy for myself for all the worrying I do! I have 1 sibling who lives far away and he would not be helpful.
3. Of course if money was not an issue, things would be a lot easier but although we are comfortable and she has enough to live on, it‚Äôs not like we have a lot of excess funds to do things like hire cleaning/cooking help and yard help. Or maybe that‚Äôs what we need??

Thanks in advance for anyone who actually read this far! I would appreciate any advice.

stories.title: Sitting in Emergency Waiting Room

I am currently in my hometown visiting my mom who lives in an assisted living facility.  I‚Äôd say lately she takes a fall about once or twice a month. My sister called me and told me the ‚Äúhome‚Äù called and said mom had fallen and was complaining of a sore back. Usually my mom wants nothing to do with hospitals but she was ok with an ambulance bring called. Now I‚Äôm in the emergency department and mom‚Äôs laying in a parked ambulance outside because emergency is ‚Äúfull.‚Äù At least she has paramedics with her. I hope they‚Äôre making her as comfortable as possible. 
It‚Äôs hard watching the people who raised us become vulnerable. I want to protect her at all times. Just needed to get this off my chest. Feeling kinda useless as I sit here..üôÅ
Update: mom‚Äôs back at the assisted living facility. Will start meds for rib pain, hypotension and a skin rash that‚Äôs been lingering(lower region). She‚Äôs sleeping. I just spoke to the manager and started bawling in her office. I think I might be mentally and physically spent. Thanks for all the support. I know there‚Äôs a huge community that totally gets it.

stories.title: Document Inaccessibility in Facilities
stories.story:
Hi all,

Im a healthcare founder and have been working in healthcare for 4 years, specifically in assisted living facilities, nursing homes, independent communities, etc. and I saw there was a problem with documents (DNRs, COLSTs, POLSTs, MOLSTs, Advance Directives, etc) where not available in the event of an emergency. The last couple weeks i've been talking with EMS agencies and they have said they can have trouble finding/getting ahold of these documents in a timely manner in an emergency which in turn means that patient doesn't get the care they want and their wishes are either not known or simply not honored. 

I'm curious if others working in facilities like these have seen this issue and what current systems are in place for locating these documents when the time comes. Im looking to create a universal solution for this issue that can be applied to any facility so any insight on that would also be helpful. Thanks!

stories.title: mom wanting doped up

my 80 year old mother insists that i buy her nyquil almost every time i go shopping, she says she cant sleep at night and its the only thing that helps. she sits up until 2 or 3 am on her tablet watching videos or watching old game shows on tv.  i told her the lights from the tv and tablet are causing her rhythms to be out of wack and she needs to turn all that off about an hour or two before laying down, but she cant. then she wants nyquil to dope up on and sleep the afternoon away.  her granddaughter has been staying nights with her and yet she still contacts me for everything. she says her gd is sick and unable to do alot but she isnt, she has really whipped my moms home into shape. getting rid of alot of hoard and she cooks and cleans, keeps things in order. i refuse to buy her nyquil and i think my neice does too. she tries to pit us against each other in order to get one of us to go behind the others back and buy her sleeping aid. what to do?

stories.title: My parents have no doctor!?
stories.story: My parents, 85 and 87, had a PCP who retired last year. They told me another doctor at the clinic took his cases, and my mom didn't like him. I live 1500 miles away so I can't check their paperwork myself. I just found out yesterday: That clinic actually closed and it was the insurance company that assigned them to another doctor at another clinic. Not only have they never been to see him, he's not even taking new patients. My mom has flat-out refused to even look for a new doctor in spite of her legs ulcerating all over the place, neuropathic arthropathy, out of control diabetes, and possible renal failure. She refuses to even accept help finding one. My dad isn't making an effort either even though he had skin cancer last year. They're both like, "This is fine."

stories.title: Mother falling
stories.story:
My mother has low hemoglobin and it leads her to be light headed and dizzy and falling frequently. Several times in the last year she's had to take an ambulance after being unable to get up. One time she was injured from the fall. She has a regular visit with her doctor to help with the low hemoglobin, including transfusions and some other treatments. My sister and I live in different states from her so it's difficult to come and help. 

What can we do to keep this from continuing to happen? We've looking into assisted living in her area and it is too expensive.

stories.title: Are there some facilities where you can pay up front and a patient can remain when they move to Medicaid? If so what are they called?
stories.story:
My aunt is currently in a nursing home. In the past six months she  has gone from living on her own (though know we know with dementia) to being on palliative care to now just with deep wounds on her feet.
She has no immediate family so we are trying to get her set with future placements for care.
She has a house which can be sold and a monthly pension.

Are there facilities where an upfront payment can be made so the person can remain even after private funds are deleted and she is on Medicaid?
If how can they be located in Maryland?

stories.title: Can a privately paid nurse go to a private pay assisted living facility?
stories.story:
We are trying to get a family member transferred from nursing facility to an assisted living center. She was in rehab following an emergency hospital stay.  After Medicare for rehab stay ended, the plan was to transfer her to an assisted living facility.  Everything seemed all set up but when a nurse from the assisted living facility came to see her, it was determined she would not be accepted at the facility because of the wounds that are still on her feet.  The new facility would not have a nurse available for this type of wound care.

Is it ever possible to have a private in home nurse service go to a private paid assisted living facility for deep wound care (stage 3).  At the current facility the only would care she is receiving is daily bandage changing.

What are the best options for help us navigate this whole process?  Recommendation for companies like "A Place for Mom" services.

Note - in Maryland

Edit - updated info about the wound care

stories.title: Persuading a Family Member to go into Assisted Living
stories.story:
My 91 yo uncle has had 4 falls this year and its only June 6. Each time he has ended up in the hospital where they just want to turn and burn him right back home so he can fall again. He did go to rehab on two separate occasions where he was also turned and burned back to his home.

Clearly he can't go back home again after this current stint in acute rehab is done. He has 3 different serious health conditions and severely degenerating joints. He HAS to go into Assisted Living. His mind is sharp, he's hardheaded, and every time I've approached him with the topic for the last 5 years, he has shut me down. If he refuses this time and the rehab turns and burns him out the door I know he will fall again. He's been lucky to not get injured the last 4 times. What can I do? How do I get him to swallow his pride and at least give it a try?

stories.title: Georgia APS and Guardianship System is a Confidential Trap ‚Äî and They Almost Got Me
stories.story:
I just went through hell dealing with Georgia‚Äôs Adult Protective Services (APS), and I need people to understand how rigged and abusive the system actually is. It‚Äôs not built to protect‚Äîit‚Äôs built to control, profit, and cover up. If you're taking care of an aging parent and think you‚Äôre safe because you‚Äôre doing the right thing‚Äîyou‚Äôre not.

Here‚Äôs what happened to me:

I moved my mother‚Äôs money out of Wells Fargo into a smaller local bank (Southern First) to simplify her finances and achieve a higher interest rate for her money. Next thing I know, someone from Wells Fargo files a confidential SAR (Suspicious Activity Report) and a local detective (Sandy Springs PD) gets involved. He writes two vague police reports months apart‚ÄîApril and August‚Äîaccusing me of stealing from my own mom. He never talks to me or my mom - just talks to my sister to have her \*back Wells Fargo elderly fraud claim against me\*.  No charges, no notice, no investigation I was informed of‚Äîjust shadow records.

Then the detective tells my sister to hire an elder law attorney, who starts moving behind the scenes to build a guardianship case. They refer the whole thing to DHS/APS, which is 100% confidential under Georgia law. Bascially DHS /APS can coach my sister to  push a guardian action confidentially behind the scenes, all with taxpayer money cash.  They know she won't actually get it because we fight like hell and she's schizophrenic.  It's just an action to get their own guardian ein there.  Even my mom isn‚Äôt allowed to see any records about what was said about her, or who made the claim. And I sure as hell can‚Äôt get access.

Then the cherry on top: they coach a doctor to claim my mom ‚Äúneeds a shot or she‚Äôll go blind.‚Äù My mom calls me to cancel the appointment, and when I help her do that‚Äîthey claim I‚Äôm obstructing medical care. Suddenly I realize the game: they‚Äôre trying to frame me as an abuser, cut me out, and force her into court-appointed guardianship or a nursing home.  Because APS is a colluding bunch of fraudsters who have their dirty actors everywhere, hoping to split up the pie known as your elderly mother's assets.  Once I caught on, I went into overdrive: rescheduled the appointment, hired independent caregivers, got new doctors, got completely transparent with the finances and even shared everything with my sister‚Äôs attorney. I had my mom get a competency test with a psychiatrist and write a letter telling APS to fuck off.  But it was amazing how much power they had.  They could operate completely in secret and were completely shielded by open records requests, and framing a situation where my mom woul foot the bill for guardian ad litems, attorneys, evaluations, her own attorney fees‚Äîall of it. All because the APS system lets them build a case behind your back with zero transparency and zero accountability.

# Why this is total bullshit:

* APS records in Georgia are sealed from everyone‚Äîincluding the person being ‚Äúprotected.‚Äù
* No way to challenge or even know what‚Äôs being said until it‚Äôs already in court.
* Law enforcement, doctors, and attorneys work as a coordinated clique, and you‚Äôre the villain the moment they choose that narrative.
* You can be criminalized for *literally helping your own parent* if it contradicts the ‚Äúconcerned‚Äù narrative they‚Äôre building.
* And all of this profits the system: attorneys get paid, doctors get referrals, GALs (guardian ad litems) get gigs, and your parent pays for all of it.

This is state-sanctioned exploitation dressed up as elder protection. If I hadn‚Äôt figured out the game and moved fast, they might‚Äôve taken my mom and tried to toss me in jail‚Äîall over a canceled eye appointment she asked me to stop.  Anyone who experiences this needs to know that they can tell their elderly parent to write a letter to APS to fuck all the way off -- if they can just find a doctor to vouch for their competency.  I wish I knew this so as to prevent massive stress when they were planning to file this emergency action right at the wrong time in my life -- when I was prepping for my daughter's wedding!

#

stories.title: Money going missing from great grandmother
stories.story:
My 95 year old great grandmother has always lived at home. She is set in her ways about staying at home and living fully autonomously. In her older days, her POA‚Äôs (my aunt and grandma) have looked after her finances. The odd time my great grandmother will give me $20 for doing odd chores, gas, cooking, etc. and same to my father (who‚Äôs on the road most of the time for work), which is normal - so we both also monitor balances. 

Essentially we know we can trust all immediate family who are around. Within the past year or two she has had home care staff come in for extra help. While I was away at university, it had occurred where my grandma had noticed money missing, (I can‚Äôt recall exactly but $50-$100). With this occasion, there had been no action taken and just suspicion, not sure when the money could‚Äôve been stolen. This led to the POA‚Äôs hiding the money in a cabinet. This would hold the majority of her cash on hand, about $300 leaving about $50 in her purse with small bills. 

Fast forward to today, she had asked me to check her purse to count and give me $20. When I checked, her purse was empty. I later went down to my grandmas to chat for a bit. After leaving, she texted me asking If I had taken any money from great grandma today. I let her know I hadn‚Äôt and what I noticed. She had then told me there was $100 total in her purse that went missing. $50 for getting grass cut, and $50 for Culligan water, groceries, items etc. This has left both my grandma and I to believe the home care staff are to blame. She has a care provider come in breakfast, lunch, and bed time. 

At this point we are unsure of how to catch this person or take legal action against them. I would greatly appreciate any suggestions or advice based on how to best approach the issue. Thanks.

My mother's 83, wears dentures, and is entering the late stages of dementia.  Eating is becoming an issue. I guess I need to shift her diet to soft, simple things.  Easy to understand, easy to chew.  Things that look like a single lump of mostly the same thing.  Like soup, coffee cake, yogurt, ice cream... Any suggestions?

stories.title: Caring for both of my in-laws at the same time nearly broke us
stories.story:
In January 2024, both of my in-laws were hospitalized in the same week ‚Äî and ended up needing care for over a month. Different medical issues, but similar chaos.

My partner, her siblings, and I were scrambling to manage everything ‚Äî meds, appointments, updates, and coordinating with caregivers to give family members breaks from round-the-clock support. It was overwhelming. Too many group chats. No single source of truth. And a lot of stress.

That experience led me to create something that I wish we‚Äôd had at the time. It‚Äôs called **Thorp** ‚Äî an app built specifically for families and caregivers to stay organized when caring for a loved one.

With Thorp, you can:

Share updates with family & caregivers
