stories.title: FINANCIAL TIPS FOR YOUR ELDERLY LOVED ONES
stories.story:
Hi all.

I worked as a financial counselor most of my life, have a masters degree in financial planning & counseling and was an Accredited Financial Counselor Planner Educator (AFCPE) and worked as a contractor for the Dept of Defense teaching personal finance. My favorite meeting was with an adult child of a senior citizen. I wanted to share some of the info I shared:

I put together some tips for your elderly loved ones. I hope some of these help. It's long. I wrote this assuming it's for a parent so you may see parent when this applies to anyone you are caring for and have the responsibility for financial matters. This is not investment advice or legal advice.

1. A record book

¬†Staying organized is key. I suggest getting an old fashioned sturdy notebook of all things financial.

Their¬†social security number, birthdate, all insurance numbers and contacts, any medical information, doctors, meds, life insurances, banks, credit cards. All of it.¬†

A page for ID, address, birthdates, social security, apple ID etc, passwords. a page of doctors and numbers, medicines and amounts and where purchased, medical history, allergies, vaccines, shingles? Flu? Tetanus?,¬†

Another page for credit cards, numbers, online sign ins, bank account, online passwords, life insurance, , amounts, beneficiaries, numbers,

ASK YOUR PARENTS IF THEY BY CHANCE HAVE ANY VERY OLD LIFE INSURANCE POLICIES THAT WERE SOLD IN THE 1940S. THEY ARE TYPICALLY FOR $1000, A FUNERAL POLICY. Be careful about that last insurance policy. The one I found had changed company hands three times and the first contact told me the policy was not paid up and was invalid. Not true. I had to email, snail mail, call, and make copies of everything, including make an online account in my mother's name in order to see that yes, in fact, the account was paid up and valid. ADVOCATE!

Another page for the VA. Service dates, enlist and honorable discharge. VA number, Life policies. A lot of veterans have a $5K life insurance pollcy from serving.

Any credit cards, store cards, etc. All numbers, sign on and passwords and any secret questions

When you sign up for accounts for them to freeze credit, you may need to log questions and answers. Best friend from childhood, nick names, things you'll need to recall later. Make note of all of these identifying questions!

¬†Then make photo copies and keep it in a google keep app on your phone.¬†You will be referencing this frequently. Google keep is an easy app for your phone. It's like a digital bulletin board. I took photos of each page of this book and accessed it frequently if I was not at home.

2. Legal Papers in place

Someone might want to speak to an attorney to inquire about a general durable power of attorney, whomever will represent them in medical and legal matters.

I am not giving you legal advice. i am suggesting you speak to a legal representative who can explain what this is and if you need it.  The IRS and financial instituations use a similar type of form, but one that is their own, and they may require an in person visit and signatures. ¬†Make sure all doctors and hospitals you visit have all permission noted for family members who might need to speak to a medical professional on behalf.

The Social Security Administration wants each person to have an online acct with a representative chosen.¬†You can set this up in the presence and with the help of your parent but they have to be there and able to be involved in the choosing of the representative payee. That person can speak on their behalf should they become unable to manage their own finances. I had trouble signing my father up for this and even with a represtative on the phone, it would not go through. She stated up to 20% were not able to set up an online acct so be aware.

How might you convince your parent to do this in the event they are private and not wanting you in their business? My parents allowed me to 'start' helping with bills so I always called right in the middle of my father's favorite afternoon show. "Daddy, I need you to give permission to Miss so and so, in order for her to speak to me on your behalf."  it wasn't long before he was asking me "Honey, isn't there something we can do where I don't have to take all those calls in the middle of my show?"

Yes, there sure is!

3. Credit bureau freezes

Your¬†parents¬†need¬†to have¬†their¬†3 credit bureau reports FROZEN so that no one can open a credit line in their names, and trust me, people are trying to do that as we speak.

Transunion, Equifax, Experian. It's free. FREE. Always free.

Keep the PIN¬†or password¬†in a safe place if her credit needs to ever be thawed. Google how to freeze credit bureau accounts. Do not sign up for monitoring service, each bureau must do a freeze or thaw for free.

¬†4. Credit card online presence

If¬†they¬†don't¬†have an online presence for¬†their¬†accounts: credit card, xfinity,¬†bank¬†etc. do that now. Explain to¬†them¬†their financial accounts ARE already¬†are¬†on the computer, and that¬†they¬†just can't see it. This is common with seniors who aren't computer savvy and might distrust online accounts. ¬†Set up online accts for all financial accounts, bank, credit cards, investments, the VA, everything.¬†

Sit with¬†them¬†and write down the sign-on information. Whomever is the financial manager needs to keep a look at¬†the¬†xfinity or other phone numbers in the history to watch for scam calls so the numbers can be blocked if they have a land line. On the cell, check history of calls, check for out of state calls, especially area code 876. That is from Jamaica, a common hub for scams.¬†

Speak with the loved ones about common scams, the Grandson in jail, you've won a mercedes, etc. Ask your loved one to call you right away. My own father fell for the grandson in jail call, even though he had been well versed and educated on the scam. He called me and I convinced him it was fake, but he insisted on speaking to his grandson to make sure.

5. Scams

Also, on any credit cards, you want to check for 'continuity charges'.¬†The word may be different for different cards.These are repeated charges that might be magazine renewals at $79 or college classes or any other types of false charges that were inadvertently signed up for without¬†them¬†knowing. I found $275 per MONTH on my parents visa card that shouldn't have been there: porn, college classes, magazines and self care courses. All of these were scams charged most likely through a phone call that started with "Can you hear me??" and my father said, "YES!". The recorded word 'yes' was all they needed.

Someone needs to also check on those charity donations. Every. Single. Time. my parents called in a $35 donation, they were magically signed up for monthly repeated donations. One call can undo this.¬†

I set up alerts every time their credit card was used. Instant alerts for anything over $1. I also set up through their banking, a morning email showing balances.¬†Be very aware of balances and credit card charges. Download monthly invoices.

Go and meet with the bank manager and ask them to alert you to any attempted large amounts withdrawn. Ask them to block these and alert the power of attorney. Do not allow them to put you or a sibling's name on the account. Your parents should have a POD, payable on death, on all financial accounts.

¬†6. Bank account

Adding a child's name to the account will override the POA and upon the last death, all monies belong to that one child, not the intended POD beneficiaries. We requested my name removed by the bank manager, she falsely claimed she did this, and upon their deaths, my sister and I were told a large sum belonged to me, and me alone. It took an out-of-state auditor to spend eight hours reviewing the history of their account and POD to reverse this and it was done under great duress by the manager who asked me to never tell anyone.¬†

¬†One step at a time. First thing, get that notebook. Edited to add: talk to¬†them¬†NOW while¬†they¬†have¬†their¬†wits about¬†them¬†and find out everything you can.

¬†Do¬†they¬†have a safety deposit box? Get a key, and go through it with¬†them. Add your name to the box. Or just empty it out and close it.¬†

Also, set alerts for her bank accounts. I get an email every single morning showing my parents account balance. I also get an immediate text if their credit card is used and is not present. (over the TV/telephone) This is how I cancel sooo many items they order then they never remember what they ordered. They ordered that brain series of books THREE times!) It's all about placing safety nets in place in the form of credit freezes, email and text alerts, etc.¬†

You can put a LOCK in place on financial accounts through various means. Make a relationship with the bank manager!

7. Last thing, if there is a credit card in a parent's name, when that parent passes, do not call the credit card company until you know the last bill has arrived and has been paid. Once you call and report the death, here in my state, the account online (that you should have set up) will be instantly shut down and the account will be turned over to a debt collector.

You may have medical bills that were paid recently that show back up and unless you printed off the monthly bills, you won't have that proof, due to the online access that is now removed. So cover yourself, don't use the card for anything, as that is illegal, and wait till you know you don't need access to the history.

Upon death, purchase a multi folder file folder. Sections such as, medical, VA, insurance, funeral, etc will have all the important papers you will be referencing. And make sure when you do get that death certificate, you scan the front and back and keep a file as most places only want an electronic copy.

You will be filing two taxes most likely depending on time of death. My parents died early in the year, so we had to file that April for the previous year, then the following year for those six weeks they lived. Keep everything as the IRS did come back and I needed my references to prove the mistake was on their end, not mine.¬†

I know this is a lot, and it's just the beginning, unfortunately. Rules and laws change and different states will be different, but hopefully this is a good start.

I hope this helps someone. Have a blessed day in your caregiving.

\--¬†

stories.title: Caregiver.
stories.story:
I was the point person, or as I said, "The CEO of my parents' lives' for six years.

During that time, I managed all of their investments, paid every bill, monitored their phone calls and blocked spams calls, got text alerts for every credit card spend and canceled countless charity monthly donations. 

I scrubbed poop off the toilet and floor weekly. Bought their clothes, washed their clothes, cleaned poop off shoes, trimmed nails, cleaned poop from nails. So much poop!

Took them to doctors, emergency rooms, eye doctors, dentists, surgeries, sooo many ER visits from falls. 3am emergencies, ambulances, head hits, UTIs...

Slept on their couch, helped my father with catheters, bloody cuts, bruises, diabetic injections...

Managed every single aspect of their lives, their bodies, their environment. It all filtered through me.

Calls all day, from them, doctors. I counted 50 calls one day concerning them. A normal day had nine calls from Daddy, "I can't find your mother' or "We have a serious problem' And off I'd go, driving an hour to their place.

My entire life was consumed with them. Every day and every night. Medicines, managing pills, calls at 7pm that no pills were in the automatic dispenser I had filled that day. 

And yet...my 'friend' just told me I had not been a caregiver because they didn't live with me.

Show love and care to your friends and family who are 'the one' who is the giver of care. It's beyond exhausting. It's soul deflating. I used to call my friend and say "I need you to tell me this isn't going to go on forever'.

Show them some love. They need it desperately. I cared for my parents for almost six years and they died on the same day. It was....a Season of Honor.

stories.title: My Parents' Credit Card Chaos After They Passed
stories.story:
My elderly parents died on the same day. 

I had cared for all of their finances, doing investing, paying bills, tracking every dime. I had online accounts I had set up with my parents so we could oversee invoices and bills.

When they passed, I called the credit card company to let them know and hung up. 

I knew it was illegal to use the card after death.

Literally less than one minute passed and I could not access the online account. And...the account was turned over to a debt collector!

The problem was that the very last bill had not arrived and we needed to pay it and be done with it. Also, sometimes medical bills came in and we needed to verify they had been paid. But we had not been printing out monthly bills. Just all online.

So I had no way to verify past charges that had been paid. And it took almost four months for them to send the final bill. The phone calls were incessant, they wanted me to pay that final bill, without me seeing the final bill.

Now, I tell my clients to download all monthly invoices, get an email verification the balance gets paid, and make sure, MAKE SURE the final bill has arrived and been paid, and then call to announce the death.

stories.title: PA is the only state where nursing homes can sue the adult children of patients for outstanding bills, but this can be changed
stories.story:
Pennsylvania is alone in allowing nursing homes, which are often corporately owned, to sue the children and spouses of patients over outstanding bills. Nursing home care costs a few hundred dollars each day, which means this can lead to significant hardships, even for children who are estranged, were abused by that parent as a child or played no role in their parent's decision to enter that facility in the first place.

This has effected me personally and I have also seen it in the work I do in elder care. But, unfortunately, I think many people are unaware of how our system works until it effects them. Nursing homes do work with families to help patients apply for Medicaid to cover the cost of care when someone enters their facility, but this can be a stressful and confusing process and families can struggle with locating all of the financial documents from the past few years that are required for the application, especially if there is no Power of Attorney in place.

While the families are scrambling to locate documents and file the paperwork, then also during the period of time when the Medicaid application is being processed, bills are piling up. If it turns out the application is later rejected and the patient will be denied Medicaid coverage for any reason, family members can get hit with a large bill. Courts can even garnish wages to cover the cost of ongoing future care.

As we face potential cuts to the Medicaid program, I am even more concerned about how this could effect PA families in the future.

Currently, House Bill 65, which aims to reform our filial responsibility laws and make them more similar to those in other states, is with the house health committee while they hear from stakeholders. I don't know who these stakeholders are, but think we need to make sure they hear from voices beyond those in the nursing home industry lobby who want to keep these laws in place.

Please consider speaking out about House Bill 65, which you can read about here:

[https://www.palegis.us/legislation/bills/2025/hb65](https://www.palegis.us/legislation/bills/2025/hb65)

Email correspondence can be sent to the Chairman of the Health Committee, Rep Dan Frankel at¬†[repfrankel@pahouse.net](mailto:repfrankel@pahouse.net).

Governor Shapiro can be texted at 717-788-8990

stories.title: Do delirium return?
stories.story:
Hello. My mom was admitted to the hospital last week due to a mini-stroke. This is her 2nd stroke.

While at the hospital, she was acting weird, like randomly singing in the middle of the night, saying that she could see our dead relatives, and more. After doing a bit of research, i found out that she was experiencing hospital delirium and its quite common and will go away once you leave the hospital.

Fast forward. She was discharged on Saturday. The day after returning to our house, her delirium was gone. She's acting fine, answering my questions properly and such.

However, after 5 days. Her delirium suddenly returned. She is again seeing our dead relatives. Calling the names of people who are not living with us, as if they're in the house. Doing random things and when questioned why she's doing it, her answer is extremely confusing. And a lot more things.

I am very worried. It's just me and my mom in our house. We have a doctor's appointment later for her update checkup. I will share everything to the doctor. However, im just curious if its normal for delirium to suddenly return?

stories.title: Caregivers need care too
stories.story:
Who is a the primary caregiver for their aging parent? What are you doing to find time for yourself?

I see it often, that caregivers (generally the eldest daughter) takes on the responsibility to care for their aging parent, dive in to make sure they stay safe and healthy, only to realize they no longer have their time, freedom, or autonomy.

It‚Äôs an act of love, but it can come at a steep cost to your own well-being if you‚Äôre not taking time for yourself, finding support, and processing your emotions‚Ä¶

If this is you, I just want to gently remind you: you matter too. It‚Äôs okay to step back and check in with yourself. You‚Äôre allowed to take a walk, call a friend, eat something nourishing, or simply breathe for five quiet minutes. 

Caregiving doesn‚Äôt mean abandoning your own needs‚Ä¶ it means finding ways to sustain yourself while being there for someone else.

You deserve support, whether it‚Äôs from a sibling, a friend, a professional, or an online community like this one. You are not alone. üíõ

What are the little (or big) things you do to care for yourself while caring for someone else?‚Äù

stories.title: Caring for elderly parents who refuse help is honestly breaking me
stories.story:
I moved back into my childhood home a little over a year ago to help out with my mom (early dementia) and dad (mobility is trash, can barely walk). I work full-time and have some flexibility, but not enough to be their full-time caregiver. Tried bringing up hiring someone part-time or even looking into adult day care, but my dad‚Äôs acting like we‚Äôre trying to bankrupt him. He‚Äôs got money he‚Äôs just real old-school about not spending a damn cent unless it‚Äôs an emergency. Problem is the *emergency* is already here, he just won‚Äôt see it.

He‚Äôs had a couple falls already, missed the toilet more than once (not trying to be gross, just real), and my mom's starting to forget to take her meds or gets paranoid when someone unfamiliar is around. She almost called 911 on a caregiver because she ‚Äúdidn‚Äôt recognize her‚Äù‚Äîeven though we literally introduced them the day before.

I‚Äôm exhausted. Not just physically but mentally. My partner and I barely get time together anymore, I‚Äôm constantly worried while I‚Äôm at work, and it feels like I‚Äôm slowly turning into a ghost of myself.

Tried talking with them calmly, got nowhere. Even brought a doctor in to explain how serious it is my dad nodded like he understood, then said "we‚Äôll figure it out ourselves." Spoiler alert: they haven‚Äôt figured anything out.

If it was just about making peace with their decisions, maybe I could let go but the reality is if they don‚Äôt accept help they‚Äôre going to get hurt and then it‚Äôs *really* going to be on me

stories.title: Caring for elderly parents has completely changed my life‚Ä¶ anyone else feel like they‚Äôre drowning sometimes?
stories.story:
I never thought I‚Äôd be in this spot, but here I am‚Äîearly 40s, no kids of my own, and basically full-time caretaker for my mom. She‚Äôs 83, sharp as a tack mentally most days, but physically she's declining fast. I moved back into her house about a year ago after she had a nasty fall, thinking it‚Äôd be temporary. Lol. It‚Äôs been anything but.

I work full-time from home, and in between Zoom calls, I‚Äôm cooking her meals, managing her meds, cleaning up accidents (yeah‚Ä¶ the incontinence stuff is real), and dealing with her stubborn streak a mile long. She refuses help from anyone but me‚Äîeven when I bring in a professional caregiver just for a few hours, she acts like I‚Äôm trying to dump her in a home or something. It‚Äôs exhausting, man.

She won‚Äôt consider assisted living, won‚Äôt move in with any other family (not that they‚Äôve offered anyway), and somehow it‚Äôs become ‚Äúmy responsibility‚Äù because I‚Äôm the single one. I‚Äôve had to put my social life and dating on pause. My savings are taking a hit. My mental health is not great. Some days I just wanna drive off into the sunset and not look back‚Äîbut then the guilt hits me like a truck.

I‚Äôve looked into getting paid for caregiving, but she has ‚Äútoo much money‚Äù for government help and not enough to afford private services. Awesome. I‚Äôm stuck in that perfect little in-between where you‚Äôre too broke to pay for help and too ‚Äúwell off‚Äù to get help.

So I guess I‚Äôm just here wondering if anyone else is going through the same thing. How do you manage caring for elderly parents without completely losing yourself in the process? Anyone figure out how to set boundaries without being made to feel like the worst human alive? Would love to hear how y‚Äôall are coping‚Äîor not.

Thanks for reading. This stuff is hard and lonely and weirdly invisible.

stories.title: I'll never have kids, but I will have money. How can I ensure that I'll be cared for in my old age and will never have to go to a nursing home / assisted living?
stories.story:
So I will never kids and - honestly - I'll probably never have nieces and nephews either. I cannot count on younger generations of my family to take care of me in my old age. And - even if I could - I would never want to put them through that like my grandparents did to my own parents.

Luckily I'm set to be worth several million by the time I reach old age, so money will be there to see to my care. Not an infinite amount, to be sure - but enough to be able to hire help to take care of me in my 80s and early 90s (I anticipate my life expetency to be 85-95, based on family history). 

However, I have questions/concerns.
1. First of all, what kinds of services should I be hiring out? I mean evenutally there will be 24/7 nursing care, but... before I get to that point, what would I be in need of? I'll definitely need housekeeping, cooking, and someone to take me to/from appointments but IDK what else.
2. How can I find someone to advocate for me? With doctors especially, but also in my dealing with care staff. Are there professional medical advocates you can hire? 
3. What steps can I take to ensure that I am not physically or financially abused?

I'm kinda stressed thinking about all this, because not only do I need to make sure there is a plan to get me the help I need... but I also need to make sure there's someone to initiate the plan, especially if I lose my mental accuity. I am so scared by the prospect of being thrown into a home.

stories.title: How does one go about getting POA when an elderly loved one is refusing to give up complete control?
stories.story:
Okay, I feel like that sounds crazy and borderline abusive, but we have reached a stage with my nana where something has got to give. She is a genuine danger to herself. She CANNOT be trusted to take care of herself and cannot live alone. She‚Äôs completely given up. I‚Äôm trying to get her to agree to assisted living, it‚Äôs what everyone agrees is best (nurses and doctors at the rehab facility, the social worker at the hospital and at the rehab facility, the physical therapists at both the hospital and rehab facility, etc.), but she wants to go back to her apartment and remain independent. She refuses to allow anyone to be POA because she ‚Äúread One Flew Over the Cuckoo‚Äôs Nest too young‚Äù üôÑ. 

For a little bit of context on why it is she cannot live by herself, she had a stroke at some point in the last couple of years. We don‚Äôt know when because she refused to go to the doctor until maybe 6 months ago? After not going for 20 years? She only went after she had a series of falls that we had to call 911 to get her up off the floor for. She can still walk, retained cognitive function, etc., but she favors her left leg a little bit. It‚Äôs something that would have been solved with physical therapy, if she did her exercises and followed PT‚Äôs instructions. She is, by her own admission, continent during the day. It‚Äôs only when she‚Äôs sleeping that she‚Äôs incontinent. Well. She‚Äôs decided that she doesn‚Äôt like getting up to go to the bathroom anymore (again, she is perfectly capable of walking and doing so, she just *won‚Äôt*) so she wears depends 24/7 (she doesn‚Äôt even bother wearing pants anymore) and does not change them between uses, NOR does she shower! Like at all! She refuses to! So that, in combination with the fact that she refuses to manage her diabetes, has led to constant UTI‚Äôs, which has led to her most recent diagnosis: encephalitis that‚Äôs causing rapid cognitive decline. I guess in some ways she is managing her diabetes. By not eating. Like less than 500 calories a day. She‚Äôs lost close to 80 pounds in the last 6 months. We set up a caregiver for her, but they can‚Äôt provide care if she doesn‚Äôt answer her fucking door and none of us have time to micromanage her and do everything for her, which is what she wants. This most recent hospitalization happened because she somehow managed to unplug her phone charger and her power lift chair and she was just stuck in it with no access to food, water, or the bathroom for 4 days. When caregivers couldn‚Äôt get in and we couldn‚Äôt get ahold of her, we went over there and found her. The nurse at the rehab facility said ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know how something like this happens‚Äù and we were a little defensive initially, but explained, and she said ‚Äúno, no, I mean, I don‚Äôt know how you get to the point where you don‚Äôt even *try* to get up‚Äù. She had canes and her walker right there, but she *didn‚Äôt even try to use them to get up*. She is denying she has depression and refuses to take any antidepressant medications, so idk. 

I‚Äôm her granddaughter and my mother and aunt are still alive, but I‚Äôve been the only one taking care of her for the last 2 years, and the decline has been *fast* and *steep*. My mom is back in the picture after 16 years of no contact (it‚Äôs complicated and my nana is a difficult woman who put her through hell, so I‚Äôm not mad about it) and my aunt is back in the picture in a limited way after 3 years of exceedingly limited contact, but they both feel I should be POA. I work for a home care agency (I do the office side of things) and work closely with DHHS and coordinating care, etc., so they feel I‚Äôm more qualified. We even offered to split things so my aunt would take care of managing finances, I would take care of managing medical, and my mom would be like the 3rd signature/ tie breaker, and still no dice. I‚Äôm not really sure how to begin to proceed here, but I‚Äôm pretty sure I‚Äôm going to have to take her to court, which is going to destroy our relationship. I‚Äôll do what I have to do to make sure she‚Äôs safe and cared for, though, I don‚Äôt care if I have to be the bad guy. I‚Äôm just incredibly tired and incredibly overwhelmed. I just turned 30, I just got married a month ago, I‚Äôm back in school working on a STEM degree, I have step kids, I have work, I‚Äôm in therapy and trying to prioritize my mental health, etc. I feel like this is such a huge time of change and transition for me and doing all of this stuff with her is just adding a lot of stress. If anyone has any advice on how I should proceed, I would greatly, greatly appreciate it! 

*ETA: she is currently in a rehab facility and they are refusing to allow her to return home because she‚Äôs not safe. The 4 days in a chair thing happened a couple days before Mother‚Äôs Day so this stay is apart of that whole mess. She‚Äôs taken both my aunt and I off her list so the social worker at the rehab facility can‚Äôt talk to us about what‚Äôs going on anymore. Everything we‚Äôre hearing we‚Äôre hearing through my mom. Also, my nana is only 71, lol.

stories.title: Eye Glasses for Seniors

stories.title: PSA: Plan for your own elder care, or someone else will have to do it for you.
stories.story:
...and probably not the way you'd want. This is going to sound harsh, but this is a very harsh reality.

I can't tell you how many older folks, and even my own Millennial cohorts, are "spending everything they have and living for today, because who knows what tomorrow brings!" Well, I'll tell you what tomorrow brings, and it's not pretty.

If you don't plan for a place to live when you are no longer able to live independently, you are planning to have a very shitty time as you "live out" your golden years in a "facility" chosen for you by a hospital or relative that is basically a storage unit for the sick, infirm, and elderly until you eventually die, which you will almost certainly welcome at that point.

Alternately, your adult child(ren) will be forced to take you into a house (IF YOU ARE LUCKY!) in which they probably have no room for you, and no time to care for you, as every adult in this country has to work to afford the roof over their heads. You will make a stressful situation unbearable. You might destroy a marriage or two in your wake as your needs consume all of the resources that no one has. The days of a stay-at-home partner handling the kids, bills, meals, and mom-care DO NOT EXIST ANYMORE. You will rip someone from their livelihood or force them to spend their own meager funds on someone to watch you so you don't burn their house down while they're at work.

If you don't have a kid willing or able to take you in, there are hardly any beds available in "good" nursing homes, which typically only present as "good" on tour day, so you can be ASSURED the shitty ones are like living in hell, provided you envision hell as sitting in your own feces while underpaid, overworked aides ignore you at best. Someone else, probably your oldest daughter, will be forced to deal with ALL of your medical issues, whether you want them to or not, and on a schedule over which you have zero control. Do your kids live out of town? Do they have time to take off or funds to fly your way for every medical situation that arises?  If your caretaking kid has a work trip or gets sick, you are on your own. You will be stripped of your autonomy and dignity and your loved ones will have to watch with guilt and sadness as almost no one has the funds necessary to furnish you with a better living situation. These cost upwards of twice the average salary in this country. And if you're betting on the nursing home situation to improve, I have a bridge to sell you: It's only going to get *worse* as the boomers suck up every available bed and resource.

If you have been financially reckless, and end up in this very situation with no money or home equity to rely on to pay for your care, you will get the care that you pay for, which is (you guessed it!) shitty. It will take months to a year for Medicaid to review and approve you for services. IF Medicaid is even an option for you; if it's gutted to the extent Trump and his cronies are trying to do, you might actually just end up in the streets. It's anyone's guess what could happen here, and we're so precariously close to the point of no return NOW, that you might as well just assume that if you're poor, you're completely fucked and your final months/years will be one hellacious experience after another.

There's always the chance that filial responsibility laws that already exist in states like Pennsylvania will become the norm, so your financial fuckery will become the problem of any of your kids that are in remotely stable financial situations. Guess what an extra 100-500K in debt will do for them? Maybe they can hire a decent lawyer to absolve them of that, but do you know what one of THOSE costs?

And don't even get me started on how your lack of any type of planning will begin the destruction of sibling relationships. It is inevitable that one of your kids will get stuck with the majority of your care and slowly begin to resent, and then absolutely fucking hate, the sibling(s) that are off living their lives while we literally clean up the mess that you gleefully refused to plan for.

TLDR: PLEASE, FOR THE LOVE OF EVERYTHING, PLAN FOR YOUR FINAL YEARS AS THOUGH YOUR LIFE AND THE LIVES OF YOUR KIDS DEPEND ON IT.

stories.title: potential retaliation after reporting neglect at assisted living facility - need advice
stories.story:
I‚Äôm 24 and currently dealing with an issue at my grandmother‚Äôs assisted living facility. She moved in about 8 months ago, and since then I‚Äôve personally witnessed their paging system fail at least four times. I‚Äôve made small complaints before, such as her having to wait over 20 minutes after paging for help, but nothing has been taken seriously.

This time, I scheduled a meeting with the care coordinator (for privacy, I‚Äôll refer to her as ‚ÄúWoman‚Äù). I‚Äôd previously been communicating with her about my concerns. The meeting was pushed back 45 minutes, and by the time it started, I‚Äôll admit I wasn‚Äôt in the best headspace. I was upset that my concerns hadn‚Äôt been addressed and that my time wasn‚Äôt being respected. I‚Äôm also only 5‚Äô2 and was visibly shaking from anxiety during most of the meeting.

At the start, I told Woman that I understood this is a corporate business and they have policies to follow, but I was coming to her as a concerned grandchild. I told her that the paging system had been down the day before. My grandmother waited over 30 minutes for help using the bathroom, and later that morning, she waited 15 minutes for assistance getting downstairs for a doctor‚Äôs appointment. Because no one answered her page, she was late, which threw off my entire day and left me very dysregulated.

Woman told me she wasn‚Äôt there that day and would follow up with me after checking the charts. I also asked her for clarification on what I needed to do when bringing in my grandmother‚Äôs medications, and she said they just needed a fax and that they‚Äôd handle the rest. At this point, it was clear to me that she wasn‚Äôt taking anything I said seriously ‚Äî especially when she made a cold comment about how it wouldn‚Äôt be that hard to follow my grandmother‚Äôs end-of-life directive.

I asked how she planned to address the issues I brought up, and she said they have a bid for a new paging system, but she didn‚Äôt know when it would be installed. Again, she said she‚Äôd need to check the charts and follow up.

Two hours after our meeting, I received a text from Woman that included information from my grandmother‚Äôs chart ‚Äî but only from 7:00 to 8:15 a.m., and not in chronological order. (During our meeting, she had actually told me she shouldn‚Äôt even be discussing this with me because I‚Äôm not my grandmother‚Äôs POA.) The incidents I brought up happened at 6:00 a.m. and 9:00 a.m., which were not covered in her follow-up.

In the text, she claimed the paging system was only down for one minute at 9:30 a.m. However, I was physically at the facility at 9:15 a.m. and encountered three staff members who all told me the pagers were down ‚Äî that‚Äôs how I knew there was an issue.

I had an interaction with a nurse in my grandmother‚Äôs room, where my grandma told her, ‚ÄúI‚Äôve been paging for 15 minutes and now we‚Äôre going to be late.‚Äù The nurse replied, ‚ÄúOh, our pagers are out. Sorry.‚Äù I don‚Äôt remember exactly what I said, but it was along the lines of, ‚ÄúThis is ridiculous ‚Äî is there anyone besides Woman that I can talk to about this?‚Äù The nurse walked out as I was saying it.

I then saw her at the elevator and asked again, ‚ÄúSorry, I missed your answer.‚Äù She told me Woman was the only person I could talk to about this. I remember saying something else like, ‚ÄúI understand you‚Äôre just doing your job ‚Äî I‚Äôm just really frustrated.‚Äù

On the way out, I kept getting stopped on every floor trying to get my grandmother to the car. That‚Äôs when I had encounters with Caregiver 1 and Caregiver 2. Caregiver 1 got on the elevator on the third floor and asked how I was, in a bubbly tone. I replied, ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre late for our appointment because she was paging for 15 minutes with no answer.‚Äù Caregiver 1 started to apologize and I snapped a bit, saying, ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want to hear excuses, I get it.‚Äù

We stopped on the second floor for her to get off, and Caregiver 2 was holding the elevator door while finishing a conversation. I said, ‚ÄúGuys, we‚Äôre late for an appointment ‚Äî either get on or take the next one.‚Äù Caregiver 2 got on and asked if I was okay. I started crying out of frustration and said, ‚ÄúI know it‚Äôs not your fault, I‚Äôm just very frustrated right now.‚Äù

Now, according to what Woman told me, HR is getting involved because of those ‚Äúencounters‚Äù with staff, and they want to have a meeting with me ‚Äî either by phone or in person ‚Äî with no further context.

I can‚Äôt help but feel like this is retaliation for making a report. I admit I didn‚Äôt have the best tone in those moments ‚Äî I‚Äôm passionate about protecting the people I love ‚Äî but it just doesn‚Äôt feel like it needs to escalate to this level.

It feels like they‚Äôre trying to scare me away from speaking up or advocating for the residents. And this isn‚Äôt just about my grandmother. It‚Äôs not safe for any resident in that facility to have to wait 20+ minutes after paging. Someone could be on the floor or choking, and no one would know in time.

I‚Äôm just looking for other people‚Äôs opinions on this situation and advice on how I should handle it moving forward.

stories.title: Caring for My Addicted Mom in Assisted Living ‚Äî How Do I Stop the Spiral Without Losing Everything?
stories.story:
Hi all ‚Äî I‚Äôm in a really hard spot and would love insight from others who‚Äôve been through something like this.

My mom has been addicted to pain medications for decades (pill-seeking, manipulation, doctor shopping, etc.), and now in her mid-70s, she‚Äôs in an assisted living facility with med management. I‚Äôm her main support, though my sister technically has POA. We‚Äôre in California.

Here‚Äôs the problem:

* She‚Äôs receiving extra meds from family members (we found empty Klonopin bottles from my aunt, and texts show she asked my uncle for more).  
* Since January, she‚Äôs been in a downward spiral: recurring hospitalizations, falls, disorientation, UTIs, INR issues, vomiting, hallucinations‚Äîon repeat.  
* Every time she stabilizes, she‚Äôs sent back to assisted living, then crashes again.  
* She‚Äôs in the hospital right now, and I‚Äôm trying to figure out if there‚Äôs a way to break this cycle.  
* Meanwhile, I‚Äôm paying out of pocket for her care. This month alone we‚Äôre facing $1,500 in extra charges due to added supervision. I‚Äôm terrified that this will turn into $8‚Äì10K/month if her needs increase, and my wife and I simply cannot afford that.  

My goals are:

* Harm reduction and stability in an appropriate setting (assisted living, memory care, or SNF).  
* Stop the diversion of medications from family.  
* Protect our family‚Äôs finances while still providing safe care for my mom.  
* Create some emotional breathing room so I‚Äôm not scheduling every doctor appointment, driving to hospitals weekly, and slowly burning out.  

Have any of you:

* Had to deal with elder addiction in assisted living?  
* Found a way to enforce boundaries with enabling family members?  
* Successfully transitioned someone from AL to SNF or a better-suited facility when they didn‚Äôt meet the obvious criteria yet?  
* Navigated cost escalation without losing your mind or life savings?  

I‚Äôm especially looking for any templates, strategies, or even scripts you‚Äôve used with facilities, POA dynamics, or discharge planners. I‚Äôve already started talking to the hospital about whether she can go to rehab (SNF) instead of back to assisted living, but I don‚Äôt know how to make that stick.

Thanks for reading. Any insights, even small ones, would mean a lot!

Advice on dad‚Äôs exercise routine
stories.story:
So my dad likes to exercise which is great. The issue is he‚Äôs 80 and kind of refuses to acknowledge that his body can‚Äôt handle a lot of the rigors of exercise he still puts it through.

He‚Äôs been advised by his physical medicine doctor to not run anymore as part of his cardio. His knee is apparently in bad shape. His form, to put it bluntly, is atrocious. His speed to roughly a brisk walk for an able bodied person and due to the fact he doesn‚Äôt lift his feet high enough on his runs, he‚Äôs tripped 3 times in the past year which scares the hell out of me.

He walks with a bad hunch in his back and you can see just the general discomfort he has when he has to go from sitting to standing. 

He‚Äôs attempted to do the elliptical at the gym, but because he finds it really difficult he retreats back into running. 

His insurance covers the cost of a personal trainer, but after one session he stopped because he felt the trainer was treating like him like he‚Äôs over the hill, which he claims he‚Äôs not. My feeling is the trainer had him doing some basic exercises like body weight lunges and he struggled with them. He cannot do one basic body weight squat, but claims his lower body is very strong.

My partner is a yoga instructor and has worked with him on some basic stretches and balance exercises, but because he even struggles with them he stops doing them.

I feel like the bigger issue is my dad is having a very tough time acknowledging his body cannot do what it used to which I can only imagine is very difficult. It‚Äôs difficult for me because I do like that he wants to stay physically active, but he doesn‚Äôt seemingly want any advice on what to do to work with the limitations his body is telling him.

Any advice?

stories.title: What to do with the cat?
stories.story:
I moved my in laws from VA to CA in 2016, when my FIL had dementia.  He was very attached to his cat, so we moved her with him and she lived in memory care with him til he died later that year.  

The cat was never socialized, and further traumatized by a cross country move and the VERY dominant memory care cat. She basically lived in the closet and rarely came out. 

Cat moved downstairs to my mother in laws room in assisted living, where she has lived for 8 years.  She has relaxed somewhat though she still spends most of her time under the bed or behind the couch. I've taken her to the vet once or twice and it takes a village to get the cat in the carrier, and the vet can only do one procedure a visit (e.g, EITHER blood draw or vaccination) because, again, this cat has not been socialized and cannot be handled.

stories.title: transportation option for wheelchair bound folks
stories.story:
as my mother recently decided she doesn't/can't walk any more, i was faced with a dilemma in getting her to an appointment.  i can't lift her in/out of a chair into my awful car .

sorry if this sounds like an ad, but i promise you im getting 0 kickbacks from this. 

uber wav and lyft wheelchair exist and i had no idea.  both services i used today and they are equipped with wheelchair ramped vehicles.  (your location may vary).  for Lyft, to enable showing this service you have to go into settings and enable it.

i had 2 rides.  16 miles each way/30 mins.  and both roughly were the same cost at $50.

lyft advantage is that you can schedule a pickup  whereas with Uber i couldn't. 

i scheduled the lyft on our way to the appointment and crossed my fingers that one of the 2 services would be able to pick us up without waiting too long.  surprisingly, an Uber picked us up in 15 mins.

obviously, there may be cheaper options in your area if they are available such as dial a ride, public transit, or even city services, but none were in my area. 

i called other transport services and they could only schedule one day in advance (no same day) and wanted anywhere from $150 - $225 one way. 

edit:  in both instances, up to 2 passengers can ride along at no extra cost

edit edit:  lyft will not take you to a hospital/doctor even if it's not an emergency.  uber will with non-emergencies.  this according to both of our drivers.

stories.title: How do you help elders with remote tech support while not being frustrated
stories.story:
I've often gone to this sub to remind myself of how things could be worse, and I should be grateful for what I have. Just writing this into the void because I am struggling. My mom still lives independently but probably won't be able to for much longer. She has a chronic illness and is a widow, and I live a few hundred miles away. I feel some amount of guilt for this, but it is likely she can move up here to be with me when it is necessary. I try to support her how I can remotely, because she does need help. She has some sort of mild cognitive decline and visual processing empairment that doctors haven't been able to figure out- it leaves her struggling to read many kinds of text (books, bills in the mail, login options in apps, etc). It's probably just at the extreme upper end of the range of what could be considered normal aging, but it is likely partially related to her disease. 

I was just trying to help her login to Google stuff on her new phone and it was so difficult to walk her through the options over the phone with her visual and minor cognitive empairment. There are about 15 steps it feels like (avoid passkey prompts, enter her login, enter second factor, go to her email, get the code, etc), and she kept pressing the wrong things leading us to have to start over. I started to get frustrated and she knows me better than anyone, so she could hear it in my voice and that made her less able to follow my directions. I think I feel frustration with this tech support stuff, because I start to remember how smart and capable she was when I was younger, and how I looked up to her as the most "street smart" person in my life, who fixed a lot of my problems even in early adulthood. That person is partially gone, and I feel a kind of grief about it. 

I have gotten therapy in the past a couple times about this, but still struggle with this feeling of frustration and wishing my mom was the way I remember. I am kind of the first of my peers dealing with this issue (my parents were older when they had me), so I don't have in person friends to talk to about this who really understand. A lot of online stuff is about people in a lot worse situation than me. I try to remember that she is still here and I should be grateful for that. Outwardly, those complex feelings register as frustration, but I want to find a way to manage those feelings because I want to enjoy these last few years with my mom. I was wondering how you all deal with this stage of helping elders with stuff like tech support and staying patient. I could use any advice you have. It's weird because I am a longtime tutor and am often extremely patient, but when my student is my mom, it is a more complicated situation!

stories.title: Easier Ways to Navigate the Senior Living Machine
stories.story:
I am leaving a job in senior living sales (call center) and have learned a few things that are helpful for getting around the senior living sales pitch and getting to the pricing and information more efficiently. I thought I would share what I have learned here to be helpful:

A Place for Mom= A Place for Spam. Once you share your contact information with them they essentially sell it to communities who will call you every other day or more.¬†[Caring.com](http://caring.com/)¬†and others are similar.

Create a new email called¬†[Xfamilynameseniorlivingsearch@gmail.com](mailto:Xfamilynameseniorlivingsearch@gmail.com)¬†just for this to avoid sales and marketing emails. Never share your mailing address. There is a thing called cold lead campaigns, and you can receive sales and marketing materials and even calls for years after sharing your information. Usually, when filling out a form for pricing, you can put 5558675309 and the computer will send you the downloadable pricing email and pass that disconnected number on as if it's a real number.

You can call a community directly after dialing \*67 to hide your number.

You can directly ask are you on-site or in a call center and just ask to be connected to someone on site. Have a script like, " I understand each situation is unique and your job is to gather information but I once I have accurate pricing and availability I am willing to discuss further and consider a tour, thanks for your time."

They will always give you the starting pricing and try to get you to tour. Ask about the room size, levels of care structure and exact pricing for each one and write it down on each call so you can quickly narrow down where to tour and where is a waste of your time. Often times starting pricing includes nothing but a tiny studio and no care.

They really put their best foot forward on tours, making sure the foyer is clean, food being served that day is wonderful, etc. Try to schedule tours at the last minute, and try to talk to a caregiver or current resident if you can. Ask detailed questions like, "Is the food prepared on-site?" "Where is it sourced from?

stories.title: Freezer friendly recipes for comforting meals
stories.story:
Grok (AI) gave me some great recipes. My MIL loves a chicken noodle casserole so I requested similar recipes. Thought I‚Äôd share with this community.


Freezer-Friendly Recipes for Comforting Meals

These recipes are designed for an elderly person who enjoys chicken noodle casserole. They are easy to chew, nutrient-rich, and freeze well in single portions. Each serves 6 but can be divided into smaller servings.

---

## 1. Creamy Turkey and Vegetable Casserole
A cozy, creamy dish with turkey, noodles, and vegetables.

- **Ingredients**:
  - 2 cups cooked turkey (or chicken), shredded
  - 2 cups egg noodles, cooked al dente
  - 1 cup frozen mixed vegetables (carrots, peas, corn)
  - 1 can (10.5 oz) cream of mushroom soup
  - 1 cup sour cream
  - 1 cup shredded cheddar cheese
  - ¬Ω cup milk
  - 1 tsp garlic powder
  - 1 tsp onion powder
  - Salt and pepper to taste
  - 1 cup crushed buttery crackers (e.g., Ritz) for topping

- **Instructions**:
  - Preheat oven to 350¬∞F (175¬∞C).
  - Mix all ingredients (except crackers) in a large bowl.
  - Transfer to a greased 9x13-inch baking dish or individual containers.
  - Top with crushed crackers.
  - Bake 25-30 min until bubbly (if serving now).
  - Cool completely before freezing.

- **Freezing**:
  - Portion into single-serving freezer-safe containers or wrap dish tightly with plastic wrap and foil.
  - Freeze up to 3 months.

- **Reheating**:
  - Thaw in fridge overnight.
  - Bake at 350¬∞F for 20-25 min or microwave 3-5 min on medium, stirring halfway.

---

## 2. Beef and Potato Bake
A hearty casserole with ground beef and soft mashed potatoes.

- **Ingredients**:
  - 1 lb ground beef
  - 1 small onion, finely chopped
  - 1 cup frozen peas and carrots
  - 1 can (10.5 oz) cream of celery soup
  - ¬Ω cup beef broth
  - 1 tsp Worcestershire sauce
  - 3 cups prepared mashed potatoes
  - 1 cup shredded mozzarella cheese
  - Salt and pepper to taste

- **Instructions**:
  - Preheat oven to 375¬∞F (190¬∞C).
  - Cook beef and onion in a skillet until browned; drain fat.
  - Add vegetables, soup, broth, Worcestershire, salt, and pepper; simmer 5 min.
  - Spread beef mixture in a greased 9x13-inch dish or individual containers.
  - Top with mashed potatoes and cheese.
  - Bake 20-25 min until cheese melts (if serving now).
  - Cool completely before freezing.

- **Freezing**:
  - Use freezer-safe containers or wrap tightly.
  - Freeze up to 3 months.

- **Reheating**:
  - Thaw in fridge overnight.
  - Bake at 375¬∞F for 20-25 min or microwave 3-5 min.

---

## 3. Cheesy Broccoli and Rice Casserole
A creamy vegetarian option with rice and broccoli.

- **Ingredients**:
  - 2 cups cooked white rice
  - 2 cups steamed broccoli florets, chopped small
  - 1 can (10.5 oz) cream of chicken soup
  - 1 cup sour cream
  - 1 ¬Ω cups shredded cheddar cheese
  - ¬Ω cup milk
  - 1 tsp garlic powder
  - ¬Ω tsp paprika
  - Salt and pepper to taste
  - ¬Ω cup breadcrumbs + 1 tbsp melted butter (optional topping)

- **Instructions**:
  - Preheat oven to 350¬∞F (175¬∞C).
  - Mix rice, broccoli, soup, sour cream, 1 cup cheese, milk, garlic powder, paprika, salt, and pepper.
  - Transfer to a greased 9x13-inch dish or individual containers.
  - Top with remaining cheese and breadcrumbs (if using).
  - Bake 25-30 min until bubbly (if serving now).
  - Cool completely before freezing.

- **Freezing**:
  - Portion into freezer-safe containers or wrap tightly.
  - Freeze up to 3 months.

- **Reheating**:
  - Thaw in fridge overnight.
  - Bake at 350¬∞F for 20-25 min or microwave 3-5 min.

---

## 4. Chicken and Stuffing Bake
A savory dish with chicken and soft stuffing.

- **Ingredients**:
  - 2 cups cooked chicken, shredded
  - 1 can (10.5 oz) cream of chicken soup
  - ¬Ω cup sour cream
  - ¬Ω cup chicken broth
  - 1 box (6 oz) stuffing mix (e.g., Stove Top)
  - 1 ¬Ω cups water
  - 1 cup frozen green beans or mixed vegetables
  - 1 tsp dried thyme
  - Salt and pepper to taste

- **Instructions**:
  - Preheat oven to 375¬∞F (190¬∞C).
  - Mix soup, sour cream, broth, thyme, salt, and pepper in a bowl.
  - Combine stuffing mix with water; let sit 5 min.
  - Layer chicken, vegetables, soup mixture, and stuffing in a greased 9x13-inch dish or individual containers.
  - Bake 30-35 min until golden (if serving now).
  - Cool completely before freezing.

- **Freezing**:
  - Use freezer-safe containers or wrap tightly.
  - Freeze up to 3 months.

- **Reheating**:
  - Thaw in fridge overnight.
  - Bake at 375¬∞F for 25-30 min or microwave 4-6 min.

---

## Tips for Use
- **Portions**: Freeze in single-serving containers (8 oz or 16 oz) for easy meals.
- **Labeling**: Mark containers with dish name, freeze date, and reheating instructions.
- **Safety**: Reheat to 165¬∞F (74¬∞C) to ensure food safety.
- **Texture**: Soft ingredients (noodles, rice, potatoes) are easy to chew and digest.

stories.title: Mom in Assisted Living
stories.story:
I storyed a few weeks ago about moving mom to AL. I wanted to share a few details for others who choose this route. I had no idea about lots of things. Sorry this is long!

Paperwork - I filled out an entire inch of papers for admittance. This is a pay as you go place, and one page was them wanting to know all of mom‚Äôs assets. They don‚Äôt need to know what mom has, so I listed her social security payment, and the info for a long term care insurance she has. 

Insurance - another large pack of papers to fill out. The facility has to supply their license number and some other info. Mom isn‚Äôt covered by the insurance until the 21st day. We also don‚Äôt know yet how much they will pay. The policy says ‚Äúup to‚Äù $150/day. We shall see. 

Being misled - we did two tours of the facility, including the small apartment mom would have. He stressed that it‚Äôs ‚Äúall inclusive‚Äù (outside of personal things like incontinence supplies or OTC meds). We saw a very nice shower chair in her bathroom that he said was included. There was a riser on the toilet too, which he said was included. As I started taking her belongings over, I noticed both were gone. And was told those aren‚Äôt supplied. So we quickly bought them, thanks Amazon. They also told us basic cable is included. There was even a page from the cable company showing the basic tier channels, in the welcome packet. When I asked him how we get mom hooked up, he told me they don‚Äôt supply cable, just WiFi. No problem this time, as mom prefers streaming Hulu, Prime, etc. The big omission was the $3000 ‚Äúcommunity fee‚Äù.  That was never mentioned over several visits, and the day I made a deposit to hold her room, he wanted me to pay it.  I squawked because that‚Äôs a lot of money to not have mentioned it before!  He told me they are ‚Äúhaving a special promotion right now‚Äù and he would waive that fee. 

Meds - they said they have to take over all of mom‚Äôs medical care - doctors and meds, which are dispensed by the facility. Mom organizes her own meds, and has a doctor she likes. So I pushed back and they agreed she can do her own pills until she can‚Äôt do it herself. Mom also needed a physical and a TB test to be admitted. 

Meals - the manager told me the meals are all included. I told him several times that mom can‚Äôt walk to the dining room and she would need her dinner delivered to her. She will have her own breakfast and probably lunch. He said that‚Äôs not an issue, several residents need food taken to them. Once she moved in, we found out delivered meals are $10/ each. I challenged it at the office, and they agreed that if they didn‚Äôt tell us ahead of time, they won‚Äôt charge. But only for a couple of weeks until mom gets settled and the aids can convince her to let them assist her to the dining room. 

The room itself - they had lots of safety rules like no toaster or fake fireplace, to avoid burning the place down. No rugs or extension cords to avoid tripping. She has a small fridge and sink with cabinets. But she‚Äôs 4‚Äô10‚Äù and can‚Äôt reach any of them. The rod in her closet is also about 6 feet above the floor and she can‚Äôt get to her clothes. Still, it‚Äôs a pretty nice room and all she does is watch TV, so she doesn‚Äôt need much. 

Final advice - I‚Äôm just a farm wife and not too smart about business things. My husband told me that the facility salesman would negotiate. Some of what they tell you is just to makes the sale (like a car salesman). Be sure to read every bylaw and remember certain things are negotiable. Don‚Äôt be pushed into anything.

stories.title: Capital One reported me to APS after returning wrongfully withheld Social Security funds (following prior CFPB complaint)
stories.story:
I am the legal representative payee for my elderly mother. Capital One accepted two months of her Social Security benefits but then froze the funds, claiming they do not support representative payee accounts‚Äîeven though they had already accepted direct deposits from the government.

I provided Capital One with the official government letter confirming my legal role as representative payee. Despite this, they refused to recognize my authority or release the funds. I then contacted the Social Security Administration (SSA), who reviewed the situation and formally requested that Capital One immediately return the funds.

Even after that, the situation was not resolved‚Äîso I filed a complaint with the CFPB. Only after that complaint did Capital One return the money.

However, a few days later, Adult Protective Services (APS) showed up stating they had received a report. This leads me to believe Capital One filed a retaliatory or deflective APS report, despite knowing I had followed all procedures, provided legal documentation, and that the SSA had asked them to return the funds.

Their behavior caused unnecessary emotional distress, reputational harm, and unwarranted involvement from social services‚Äîall after I had done everything according to law.

stories.title: Does a non removable tracking bracelet make sense for a parent with advanced dementia?
stories.story:
My father has mid-to-late stage dementia and recently wandered off during a walk around the block. It took us almost 45 minutes to find him, even though he was only a few streets over. He had no idea how he got there.

We‚Äôve been looking into options and one thing that came up was a non removable tracking bracelet for dementia patients. It sounds a little intense at first, but I can see how it might be necessary at this stage. We‚Äôre not trying to take away his independence completely, just ensure he doesn‚Äôt end up in danger.

Has anyone used one of these tracking systems? Were there ethical concerns or pushback from your family? I‚Äôd love to hear how others have handled situations like this.

UPDATE: We ended up using Bay Alarm since their bracelet option was both secure and practical without being overly restrictive. It‚Äôs been a good compromise between freedom and safety.

stories.title: Venting-I never want to live like this.
stories.story:
My Dad is in late stage Parkinson‚Äôs. We just got him into an age in place ALF. Now he‚Äôs skilled nursing, bed bound, can‚Äôt understand most of what he says. He wears a diaper and hardly eats. Hospice‚Ä¶
Such a strong man once and a decent man. I love my Dad but never want to reach this point personally. So humiliating and undignified. My brother is here and feels the same way.  I am taking time off from work to spend with him and my Mom who has memory issues now. I dread coming into the ALF. Staff are nice and take care of him, but we sat up with him and severe tremors last night. I hate this disease and what it‚Äôs done. No one should have to go through this.

stories.title: Medicare Hospice - Is MediGap Unnecessary Now?
stories.story:
My 89yo mother who lives in assisted living just started up using Medicare's hospice coverage through a local provider. Coincidentally, the same day we started talking about it, I got a letter from BCBS saying they're raising the rates on her MediGap supplement insurance. All this got me wondering if she even needs the supplement any more.

In looking at her claims history, the sum of the policy's paid portion of her medical bills for the past 3 years is less than what 10 months of the new premium would be.

TBH, I'm starting feel like she's been throwing money away for a while, and that she'll only be throwing more away on MediGap under hospice.

She's got heart disease and dementia, so there's no chance of her "getting well" and being forced out of hospice.

Is ditching the MediGap a good thing to do at this point? I'm hoping someone has some insights on this to help me make an intelligent decision.

Thanks!

stories.title: Need Help with Elder Parents
stories.story:
I don‚Äôt know where else to story this. I think I‚Äôve been in denial for quite some time. My parents (77 and 78) are in need of major help. My mother hasn‚Äôt left the house since the start of COVID in March 2020. She refuses to see a doctor or leave the house. The longer it goes on, the harder it is to try to get her to out. Her mental health is suffering obviously. She is lucid, though. Her feet are huge from lack of use making it hard for her to walk. She also has a growth on her face that looks like it could be melanoma. I have said many times that me or my husband would take her yo the doctor but she flat out refuses to go. 

Additionally, their apartment is a mess. It‚Äôs ‚Äúneat‚Äù but absolutely filthy. I am also concerned for food safety as my mom will leave things like chicken and cheese on the counter for hours before she or my dad eat it. I also suggest hiring an aide and it‚Äôs met with great resistance. 

My dad is another stubborn mess but at least he goes to the doctor, takes the dog out and is on medication for his medical issues. 

I have a brother but he‚Äôs no contact. There‚Äôs no other family. Has anyone had any luck doing anything in a similar situation? It‚Äôs very sad to see two people who have given up and worse they‚Äôre your family. My mom especially feels like this is self-induced, could have been dealt with and now things are much worse due to fear and neglect.

stories.title: Any action for elderly neighbor?
stories.story:
Hey all, wondering if you could offer me any advice regarding an elderly neighbor. Today my wife and I had an encounter with a neighbor a few houses down from us who we've seen, but never met (who is in her 80s). She came to our door upset because she said a man had come into her house, taken her phone, and was rummaging around her garage.

We went up the street with her and called the police. They searched the house, didn't find anyone (or any evidence anyone had broken in), and found her phone on her dresser (not in the living room where she said she was charging it when it went missing/was taken). We aren't really sure what to make of it, but I told her I would check on her tomorrow as well.

Her living conditions seemed good, house wasn't really cluttered, she had food in the fridge and pantry, her dog had food and seemed healthy. She was totally coherent, if a little upset. From what she told us her husband has passed, and doesn't seem to have any family living nearby. For what it's worth, she said she knocked on our door because her closer neighbor calls her crazy, =(. To be honest, we're not sure if someone was around, if she's just lonely, or has a health condition.

Is there anything we should do, or someone we should call? I don't want for her to have to leave her house if she doesn't want to, but I also don't want her living in constant fear if in fact there is mental illness/declining health as the cause of what she's experiencing.

stories.title: California. Millers Trust Not Honored Questions...
stories.story: Hi All... So mom is a senior and she has a Millers Trust, in the state she lives... as she made too much money with her benefits to qualify for medicaid, which would help cover PCA to show up during the day. She had medicare which didnt offer such things.  If she ended up moving to California, which does not honor a Millers Trust, are there other similar programs, for seniors who are over the income limit, that offer a bit more freedom than a Miller Trust, but stil allows one to qualify? Learning. thanks.

stories.title: Is there any help out there for Seniors?
stories.story: I've worked since I was 18, put myself through undergrad and grad school while adopting my child, started an agency and worked it pretty successfully until it went belly up due to COVID. As the matriarch of my three person family, I've always helped everyone out, paid for dinners, phone bills, car insurance, home repairs, etc. Since being hospitalized at age 70  in 2024 with COVID pneumonia, I have worked some , but quickly went through my "savings". My stamina is just not there enough to work full time. I live in a very modest house which needs repairs (I stepped through the crumbling deck and try not to use the old a/c despite living in the Southern heat), no car now, and lead a frugal life. My teacher daughter works 3 jobs and this week has sewage backing up onto her lawn in her older home and an old a/c that drips water constantly into the house. My 75 year old sister still works 5 days a week just to get by. I'm not sure we're going to make it!  And the idea of our SS being cut is horrifying. Our homes need emergency repairs. We have no backup plan. Are their low interest loans from any source anywhere for lifelong hardworking single women who are out of funds and out of ideas?  We are on the verge of insolvency. Thank you for listening.

stories.title: Recording emotional elder abuse without permission
stories.story: My 90 year old mom (confined to her home and taking oxygen 24 hrs/day), is verbally abused daily with screaming expletive language from her own child.  On occasion, my sibling's rage (F 50+) has extended to shattering  the glass of my parent's door and one time breaking the door's hinges, all in the presence of her parents.  I'm in a state which won't allow conversations to be recorded without bilateral consent, but I feel like I need to gather evidence.  Mom just tells me to stay quiet, don't refute anything she says, and avoid doing anything to inspire my sister's rage... but enough is enough and the harassment has now escalated to criminal charges of assault on someone else.  This is all related to a progressing and undiagnosed mental illness.  Any thoughts/ideas?

stories.title: 30-Year Gastroenterologist, sharing my Thoughts on Healthcare Autonomy
stories.story:
Hi Everyone,

I've spent the past 30 years as a gastroenterologist in Cleveland. I've also spent 16 of those years writing about my work, and I just created a Substack in the hopes of generating dialogue about issues in the medical world. stories.title: Parkinson‚Äôs and Dementia care
stories.story:
I have a good friend (m, late 60s) suffering from the above. He doesn‚Äôt know he‚Äôs ill, and so tries to get out of bed, but falls. Then needs help getting back into bed, along with everything else. 

This cycle repeats all day long until he‚Äôs too tired to try. And that‚Äôs just the start. 

He was in a hospital recently, and was handed off to a rehab facility. 

My wife and his wife and his family are trying to watch him 24x7 but there are holes in the schedule. 

He is a navy veteran, retired FDNY, and former coast guard and navy reserves. 

How exactly is care and insurance supposed to work? We are lost and feeling overwhelmed. 

What happens when he gets released from rehab? His wife still works and I think because of that her insurance is covering most things.

stories.title: Mystery Night Time Tenants
stories.story:
Is this considered a crime? How do we report it without proof? Or is considered elder financial abuse or fraud?

My 73yo father owns a large plaza with both restaurant and office space units. About 80% of the units are rented out. But there‚Äôs still many empty units. It is in the state of California. 
My father has an on-site assistant manager that works with him to manage the plaza property, communicate with tenants, collect rent, etc. etc. Her name is Edith (55F).

My father had a stroke back in Feb 2024 and has been physically incapacitated and became wheelchair bound. My family had to frantically gather together to take care of all his medical needs. And since our minds were all focused on my dad‚Äôs health, we left the plaza to be managed by Edith and my dad‚Äôs brother YC, who came from overseas to help during this time. 
After about 6mo of my dad recuperating and getting physical therapy, we started to get reports about the plaza from our security team and some tenants. Strange things like noises being reported from supposedly empty units in the middle of the night and when security checked, there was a full on business running there. Security suspected an illegal gambling den but not sure. When security inquired with Edith about it, she said it was nothing, just a temporary short term renter who‚Äôs going to be gone soon. By the time the family could look into it more, the renters were gone. 

After a year, Feb 2025, my father demanded to return to work at the plaza because he said we were keeping him a prisoner at home doing rehab. So we let him go back to work with Edith. We even hired on a new additional Manager to help. His name is Sean. He‚Äôs suppose to be the main manager that takes care of escalated situations at the plaza like late rent, problems, lawsuits, repair stuff. 
It became a struggle because Edith didn‚Äôt want to relinquish many of the managerial tasks to Sean. She allowed a lot of tenants to pay rent late. And even caused a lawsuit regarding a leaking ceiling. When we tried to give Edith instructions for running the plaza, she would flat out just ignore us. That‚Äôs why we hired on Sean. 

Anyway, after my dad returned to the plaza part time and about 2 months in, the security team reported another incident of noises from an ‚Äúempty unit‚Äù in the middle of the night again. He confronted the ‚Äútenants‚Äù this time and they said they had permission to rent the space from my father, using his name specifically. But it was not disclosed what kind of business it was. This time we asked my dad directly about it, he said he knew nothing about it. So then my dad and Sean asked Edith about it. She told them both‚Ä¶.ohhh‚Ä¶,it‚Äôs a short term tenant, they‚Äôre just paying cash and will be gone soon. And there was no rental agreement/contract either. And she claimed she didn‚Äôt tell my dad nor Sean about it cuz they were all so busy. And she didn‚Äôt get around to it. But somehow she got paid ‚Äúcash rent‚Äù from it and she gave that to my dad. My dad told her never to do that again and decided to just let it go and still kept employing her. 

Here‚Äôs our dilemma. We don‚Äôt have evidence of what exactly Edith is doing. Nor how long she‚Äôs been doing these strange temporary night-time tenants. And if she‚Äôs been pocketing the cash rent. We don‚Äôt know if my dad‚Äôs brother YC is involved or not either. The immediate family members all have their own jobs and don‚Äôt really have time to really investigate nor to gather evidence. We don‚Äôt even know how to report it as a crime. Is it even a crime? Or elder financial abuse or fraud‚Ä¶cuz my dad seems to just allow it to happen. Since his stroke, his logic and rationale have been somewhat compromised even though he insists it has not been. He seems to trust Edith and listen to her more than his own family members. And refuses to terminate her employment. 
I‚Äôd appreciate any input or advice. Thank you.

stories.title: Real estate agent code of ethics
stories.story:
I‚Äôll leave this as short as I can
My Mother at 81 years old decided she didn‚Äôt want to live in an independent senior living home. After 6 months. 
So without my blessing, (her caretaker, only kid who took her) she found somebody to change & take me off of the POA while she purchased a villa for cash. This is called extortion which is illegal. 
Immediately, after finding out I went to another lawyer and I own everything and I‚Äôve changed her POA, etc, warranty deed, to me.
I have compiled her medical records to prove that she has Alzheimer‚Äôs and some other neurological issues.
Time flies and she is now 86 and I‚Äôve had to move in with her after losing everything I had taken care of my parents. And now she has full-blown dementia.
I‚Äôve talked to several lawyers nobody will take my case. 
Clearly, the real estate agent should lose his license. 
And I should be compensated for the years I‚Äôve had to lose my life over, taking care of my mother who belonged in a senior living home. 
Any advice?

stories.title: I am so mad at my mom.
stories.story:
I'm sitting by my 83 year old mom's bedside while she sleeps. She's in congestive heart failure, (EF: 26%), AFIB, and beginning stages of dementia.   It's been 23vdays since she was initially hospitalized. That's when we (family) found out about the AFIB and CHF. The little memory lapses we had seen here and there over the last year are suddenly much worse. She still doesn't know why she was in the hospital, or comprehend fully that her heart is not in a good place. A week ago Sunday she was transferred to the SNF where she has been living g a long time as independent living. We have already arranged for her to move into ALF when she leaves the SNF, but she still thinks she's going back to her apartment. Not gonna happen. Fortunately, my dad made sure that my mom was financially provided for, so that's not an issue. 

The reason I am so mad at her right now is yesterday I was going through her mail and saying bills (I am her POA and executor) I found a referral letter from her GP to a cardiologist for, yep, you guessed it, AFIB! I just want to scream! It was dated August 4, 2024. I've been running on autopilot for the last three weeks trying to get shit arranged for her, manage my own life, and take care of my family, and, oh yeah, worried if I'll have a job after black Friday due to a company merger. I just had to vent somewhere.

stories.title: Smart Pill Dispenser with Remote Monitoring
stories.story:
Hi everyone, 

I‚Äôm based in Malaysia and have been trying to purchase a smart pill dispenser with remote monitoring features for an elderly family member, ideally something like LiveFine or DoseControl that allow me and my family members to track my Father-In-Law‚Äôs medication adherence via an app. 

But I‚Äôve run into two roadblocks: LiveFine doesn‚Äôt ship to Malaysia and most local options only have basic alarm functions and no remote access. I thought of using parcel forwarding services but afraid that the device might get flagged. I‚Äôm also checking with customs about possible import restrictions. 

Has anyone in Malaysia (or Southeast Asia) successfully bought a small pill dispenser with WiFi app support? 

Any recommendations for local suppliers or resellers? Any parcel forwarding services that are reliable? 

Would really appreciate any advice and tips. 

Thank you!

stories.title: How to reduce doctor visits
stories.story:
My 87-year-old mother has diabetes and high blood pressure, but no complications from either.

Her regular doctor is now sending her to a diabetes nurse, and between him and the nurse, they are constantly wanting her to try new meds, then come in and get her BP and A1C checked, then readjust the meds, then come in again. She just wants to be left alone. Says she feels fine.

My brother lives with her and has his own issues, and he's getting tired of trying to keep up with her change in meds and visits.

The doctor tells him she won't be able to get her insulin and needs paid for by Medicare if she doesn't comply.

My question is, would a gerontologist be able to handle all of this with one or two visits? Is there any other way to simplify things? Or should I look into palliative care (even though I don't think she qualifies for in-home nurse visits. She's still mobile enough to go to doctor visits).

\[Edit: Just realized I made the cardinal sin of not mentioning this is in the U.S.}
