stories.title: I didn‚Äôt expect a decline this severe this fast
stories.story:
I‚Äôm sorry if my punctuation is awful and my spelling is awful English is my first language, but I just suck sometimes. I have a lot on my plate. So please bear with me.
  I I am the school caregiver of a 75 year old now bedbound Vet. I am his POA and he decided he didn‚Äôt want to do any more therapies. Occupational therapy twice a week physical therapy twice a week the nurse twice a week and he has a catheter so catheter care every other week. We were hoping he would bounce back after this latest UTI.  That is not the case..
  So I immediately informed the agencies that we were discontinuing all therapies and he wanted to rest. So hospice was suggested to me immediately. I agreed. The next week there was people in and out, people making sure his needs, making sure he has the proper equipment, the correct bed and thumbprint meds. Since that decision, he has declined so fast. I get so scared and consumed with sadness often on throughout the day every single day. A little over a week ago, I can hold a conversation with him. Now he doesn‚Äôt make a whole lot of sense. And I am hurting so bad. I want to obey him to fight to fight for me to fight for himself, but I know he‚Äôs tired. And I want to follow his wishes. And no matter how hard I‚Äôm going to follow his wishes.
  Hey, it‚Äôs just a waiting game, I get such high anxiety every time I go into his room to check on him because I‚Äôm afraid of the inevitable. And if something does happen where I would need to call 911 I can‚Äôt. I am not too. I am to call the hospice number. Daddy is going to be my biggest test. I have family and professional people for support, but I feel so alone. I am so so sad and I kind of just autopilot through the day. Heartbroken and trying to pretend I‚Äôm OK. Everybody knows I don‚Äôt know what I expected from this. The universe, maybe somebody will read it and this will resonate and I won‚Äôt feel so alone. Family, I don‚Äôt work for an agency. I take care of him for many years.

stories.title: Has anyone had success with pain control with elderly people who can't take NSAIDS?
stories.story:
My elderly (85) mother has complex chronic health conditions. She takes heart meds, blood pressure meds, diuretics, blood thinners and thyroid meds. In total over a day including supplements she's at 20 pills. She is also allergic to ASA. 

She's in a lot of pain lately due to problems with a foot. Tests show its arthritis and bursitis in the toes and unfortunately her pain while walking has now caused issues in her lower back and down her leg. 

Due to her meds she can't take any pain killers except for Tylenol (acetaminophen). When she's had issues in the past they tried to give her gabapentin but she could not tolerate it. She has osteoporosis so she's quite fragile. The pain has made her very uncomfortable and one day her BP spiked so high due to the pain that I took her into the ER for help. They ran tests and looked over her records and confirmed that the only thing she could do was to, sparingly, use some topical analgesics and take Tylenol. 

She's miserable. She woke up in tears today from the pain. She's been able to sleep and when not she takes a small dose of lorazepam. I don't know what to do. She has help with hygiene from an aide but she is so afraid of falling and so tense from the pain I have trouble even convincing her to shower. 

Does anyone have experience with something that reduces pain in the elderly who can not take the normal type of anti-inflammatories?

stories.title: Poa of aunt
stories.story:
So I storyed before about becoming poa for aunt with radiation induced decline what is very similar to dementia. She had delirium and likely still does from her past uti. I admitted her into a nursing home as she requires 24/7 care and I couldn‚Äôt get enough coverage at home. She‚Äôs not taking meds regularly and her mood is all over the place. She‚Äôs very sad and irritable and becoming aggressive with staff. She scratched someone the other day. She wasn‚Äôt like this before so we are struggling to figure out how to help. If she continues to lose weight and doesn‚Äôt respond to rehab we will be moving onto hospice. Currently my mom and sister go for breakfast and dinner everyday to try to get her calories but not working. It was a Hail Mary of sorts. What do they do with patients who become aggressive? Do they send them to psych wards? Can they un-house them? She‚Äôs feeling so depressed and abandoned even with us visiting everyday and we hate leaving her there but we all have babies and can‚Äôt house her. I‚Äôm wondering if morphine will take off the edge for her cause she‚Äôs not taking all meds consistently. Giving her shots would make her even more upset. She‚Äôs the screamer crying a lot most days. She‚Äôs trapped in her head so when someone comes to give her meds or change her she‚Äôs caught off guard but throughout the whole process cause her attention span is so bad now. She‚Äôs also not speaking as much English as before which doesn‚Äôt help. Always asking us what she needs to do next like every 40 seconds. 


Sooooooooo yeah, do they get rid of patients like this?

stories.title: Christmas Gift Giving Drama
stories.story:
Got a weird but ultimately pretty low stakes question for y‚Äôall today and I‚Äôm interested in your opinions. Basically, what do you do about an older relative that stresses themselves out about Christmas?

I have an older relative who gets so stressed about Christmas. She is on a fixed income that hasn‚Äôt really kept up with the cost of inflation, so the past couple years have been a tighter and tighter squeeze for her even though she lives fairly frugally. She stresses a lot about Christmas - specifically gift giving for her large family. It‚Äôs important to her that everyone (kids and adults) receive something from her. Over the past few years, the increase in family members and the tighter pinch of inflation have really started to stretch her thin. The gifts last year were mostly just‚Ä¶sad. The consumables were either unlabeled mystery chocolates from who even knows where or items bought on super clearance that had been expired for a couple months. Everything else was from the dollar store or Ollie‚Äôs and was, for lack of a better word, junk. 

Normally I wouldn‚Äôt care what people do with their money but it kills me to watch her do this every year. Every year it‚Äôs the same cycle: around September she starts getting major ants in her pants about affording Christmas gifts. Myself and the others adults my age will say some  assemblage of ‚Äúwe don‚Äôt need gifts we just want to see you and the kids want to see you‚Äù. This falls on deaf ears. She will then spend the next months scrimping and saving to afford the present stockpile, getting gradually more stressed about whether she‚Äôs doing enough. She will give the gifts to her relatives, and we will open them and smile and thank her. Then once she‚Äôs gone we will throw away the expired snacks/candy and pile the rest up for donation. It‚Äôs just a giant waste. 

Is there anything I can do to ask her to stop without being cruel or hurtful? So far the gentle approach of ‚Äúdon‚Äôt bring us anything we just want to see you‚Äù has been totally ignored, like she‚Äôs convinced we are just saying that to be polite. ‚ÄúThe kids have plenty of toys ~~and they don‚Äôt need a vat of bright blue dollar store slime~~.‚Äù is also a non starter. 

Anything you‚Äôve got would be appreciated!

stories.title: Simple video call device for elder person living in another country

I've been looking into a simple device that would allow me to connect via video call with my grandma who lives alone in a different country. So far, I've looked into Amazon Echo Show and iPad auto receiving FaceTime call feature. My research led me to this subreddit, so I'm storying in hope that you guys could help me answer some questions I have or share your experience with using smart devices to connect with old family members who are not familiar with smartphones.

After one day of researching online, I have a few questions left unanswered:
- Does the Amazon Echo Show drop-in feature work internationally outside of the US? 
- Does the iPad auto answering feature work even if the screen is locked? 

These will perhaps be best answered by Amazon and Apple, but I would still appreciate if you guys could help me answer my questions or recommend what devices/setup worked for you.

My use case:
- My grandma doesn't know how to use a smartphone, so I need a device that allows 0 interaction from her side (or as least as possible). That's why a drop-in/auto-answering feature is key. 
- I need to see her and I figured she'd want to see me too, so a device with a camera AND a screen will be best (we already have a monitoring camera inside her house)

Some concerns:
- I imagine the device will sit still and be plugged in a day for charging, so she doesn't have to manually plug in and out to charge. That being said, I'm a bit concerned about how bad this would be for an iPad (screen and battery life)
- Setup: I live in the US and she lives in Vietnam. I do have family members in Vietnam that I could ask to help me go though the setup. But there may be stuff that require a local phone number or something that could make all this not work. I just need to make sure it can work, so it would be helpful to hear if/how people have successfully achieved this

Stretch: a nice-to-have would be to control what the screen displays. I'd love to send her messages that would be projected on her screen or reminders or share some photos with her throughout the day.

Thanks so much!

stories.title: Need Advice
stories.story:
This is going to be long, but I feel I need to give some background so this makes sense.

My mother-in-law is 71 years old and has had 2 strokes (1 major and 1 minor) but can talk just fine, she can walk with a rollator, doesn‚Äôt drive anymore and has help coming to the home 3 days a week to take her to doctors appointments, clean the house, do laundry, etc. Her mother is 92 years old and lives with her because it‚Äôs just not safe for her to live at home alone. She uses a walker for mobility, and is incontinent, using Depends, but is otherwise quite healthy. The same lady coming 3 days per week helps bathe her and change her bed, clean her room, etc. Meals on Wheels comes 5 days per week and brings lunch and weekend foods, and the helper grocery shops, and sometimes we do, so they are well fed and the house is stocked. When the helper is not there, they can usually do pretty well for themselves, considering, and we live a few blocks away and she calls us quite frequently for help when they are home alone.

We installed 3 cameras in their home a few years back, so we can check on them when she doesn‚Äôt answer the phone, or when she‚Äôs gone to a doctors appointment and her mother is left alone, etc. She calls us periodically and asks us to check the cameras to see where she put something she has lost, etc, so they are both VERY AWARE the cameras are there. It is no secret and it‚Äôs for their safety.

Now, to today. Her mother has been complaining about an earache so they made a doctor‚Äôs appointment for her today and the doctor prescribed some ear drops for her.  The pharmacy delivers their medication, so it came this afternoon. MIL tried to get the cap off the ear drops but was having difficulty because of the weakness in her left hand from the previous strokes, so she called my husband to come and assist. He told her he would be there in a little bit. Usually, if you give her some time, she can do whatever she wants to, so I clicked on the camera in the living room/kitchen area so I could see if she was getting it open or still struggling.

This whole scenario below unfolded as soon as I started watching:

MIL: Now, mama, I‚Äôm gonna give you some Tylenol but don‚Äôt you touch the damn bottle, do you hear me? If you need Tylenol, you let me know and I‚Äôll give it to you, do you hear me?

GMA: Yeeeeaaaaahhhhh‚Ä¶‚Ä¶ (in a meek voice)

A few minutes passes and she finally got the top off the ear drops bottle. She walks over to GMA‚Ä¶.

MIL: Why did you push your walker right in front of me? When I move something out of the way, you don‚Äôt touch the son-of-a-bitch again, you hear me? Don‚Äôt touch it. (proceeds to shove her walker 3-4 feet away from her)

GMA: (just watching, didn‚Äôt say a word)

MIL: Lean over so I can put these drops in your ear.

GMA: Oh, you got it open?

MIL: Yeah, mama, I told you I did, now lean over!  Lean your head over, mama!

GMA: (tilts her head about 1/2 way down)

MIL: That‚Äôs not enough, mama! Lean your head all the way down. Dammit, Linda, what the fuck is wrong with you lately? You don‚Äôt do a fucking thing right. (Screaming at her, and proceeds to take her good hand and shove GMA‚Äôs head toward the table multiple times, very roughy) Now, hold still!

GMA: (never speaks a word, leaves her head on the table)

MIL: (puts the drops in her ear, still fussing at her mother the whole time.)

(I didn‚Äôt hear exactly what was said here because I was furious and had gotten up to go find my husband and show him. When I got to him, GMA was up and walking back to her room. To my knowledge, she never responded to her daughter at all.)

At this point, I was hoping the camera had recorded it so I could show my husband but he told me when you view it live, it doesn‚Äôt record. Ugh.

I told my husband that I‚Äôm pretty sure this is elder abuse (coming from another elder, no less) and that GMA didn‚Äôt deserve to live like this. We knew she‚Äôs always pretty short with her and fusses at her a lot,  but that‚Äôs the first time I‚Äôve seen her cuss her like a dog and put her hands on her physically. She‚Äôs told us her mama is a bitch to her and doesn‚Äôt love her, but we‚Äôve never seen a stitch of evidence of that. Ever. She always talks to us about how good her daughter is to her, and how grateful she is to live there.  I would never treat my mother this way or she‚Äôd probably back hand me at 92 years old and I would deserve it if I did!

Hubby listened to me and just responded that the only option is to send GMA to a nursing home and he knows she doesn‚Äôt want to go there. She likes being able to get up, wander through the house, get something to snack on when she wants, she has her own room and big screen TV, just doing her own thing. He didn‚Äôt say much else. I told him I was going to ask GMA tomorrow if she wanted to go to a nursing home. I‚Äôm debating about telling her what I saw on camera. Maybe I should confront MIL about what I witnessed as well, but it will cause an uproar in the family, right at Christmas, and it will be a dang mess. I don‚Äôt even know if hubby would want me to say anything to his mother, but personally, I think HE needs to speak with her about it.

It just makes me wonder now what all does go on that we don‚Äôt see. The cameras record every few minutes or so, when we‚Äôre not watching it live, and it‚Äôs possible some issues may have been recorded, but unless we know when to look for it, it‚Äôs like a needle in a haystack with hundreds of video snippets every hour.

I don‚Äôt know how to approach this. I feel confident it doesn‚Äôt need to be swept under the rug. How much worse can this get? I‚Äôd like to get some feedback on this dilemma. Thanks for reading this novel. It‚Äôs 3 am and this is bothering me bad, everybody‚Äôs asleep but me, so I needed to get it off my chest for tonight.

stories.title: Struggling with resentment today, trying to feel hope
stories.story:
I work full time, often well over 40 hours per week, in a high stress job. I am also the caretaker for my 88 year old father. With a lot of support, he can live alone. I have hired a cleaning and lawn service. I do all his cooking, shopping, pay the bills, take him to med appts, get him to social things, etc. I have a brother who does nothing. 

  
Now we are in the holidays. I have to host Thanksgiving - at his house because he has mobility challenges, which is a lot harder than doing it at your own house. I have to host Xmas - at his house, same thing. Relatives insisted they wanted to visit him, so now I have to cook and clean for a fancy lunch at his place tomorrow. I have to do the Xmas shopping and wrapping and all the prep and put up his tree, and of course he wants Xmas cookies too. My brother has medical conditions and is unemployed, so there is a lot of expectation there that I financially support them and provide other benefits. My sister tries to help, but she has to have a major surgery next week and there's no one else to take care of her. So I have to step up there too.

  
In the meantime, my dad keeps falling prey to salesmen. First it was one of those "let me inspect your roof for storm damage." Now its major changes to his phones and communication tools. Both of which end up on my shoulders to fix when it goes wrong because he's 88 and doesn't think so clearly anymore. I hate those sleazy salesmen with the fiery hot passion of a thousand suns.

  
I'm tired and frustrated and burned out and resentful. I miss having a life. I miss being able to meet a friend for a cup of coffee or go on vacation. I miss feeling like my own life mattered. I hate feeling resentful. I keep trying to be in the moment, knowing dad won't be here forever. I keep trying to focus on giving him the best life possible. I know you are doing the same thing for your LO.

  
The holidays just add so much extra burden on everyone. I know all of you reading this are or have been in the same situation. So please know that I see you. I see how much you are doing for others. I see how much you are giving up in your own life to give them a good life. I know how invisible your labors are to everyone else who find it so convenient not to see it.  You are doing a good thing, a huge act of love. You act with grace in a situation you wouldn't be in if the world was a fairer, kinder place. I wish I could give you a Christmas present you didn't have to buy yourself. I wish I could give you a quiet night with no worry. I hope your LO sits up one day and notices all you do, and thanks you. I hope your family suddenly step up to support you. But if they don't, we thank you. We know how hard you work and how much you do, and how you are holding the family and the world together for you LO.



So, for all of us tired, resentful, still-trying caretakers, bless you. Bless all of us, and our loved ones too. We deserve it.

They took care of themselves, not exactly that well but much better than she currently does, until about 7 years ago. She also has extensive history of being victim to abuse - physical, emotional, sexual. 

Currently she works full time but experiences extreme amounts of pain with working and I‚Äôm concerned she may face termination whenever her employer find just the right time. They don‚Äôt like her much but she‚Äôs been with the company for 20+ years. She has many physical problems - prediabetes, overweight, struggles with falling over, osteoarthritis, multiple disc bulges in lumbar spine. 25-50% spondylitic anterolisthesis (basically vertebra in spine has slipped forward) as well as foraminal stenosis (spinal condition that compresses spinal nerves), some type of foot / ankle injury in addition to plantar fasciitis. Also, she has multiple mental illnesses. 

She is not able to take care of herself. I predict I may get the response that‚Äôs her children are for - I can‚Äôt do it either for numerous reasons I won‚Äôt take the time to list here. I have a sibling who‚Äôs done a lot over the last several years and they are at their breaking point. We need to determine next steps that provide her with a good quality of life but that support her. Here‚Äôs some of her troubles - she struggles with bowel incontinence and creates messes that she doesn‚Äôt clean up / doesn‚Äôt clean up properly (sanitizing, etc); she doesn‚Äôt take care of herself - daily tasks like brushing teeth, showering, doesn‚Äôt clean herself properly and deals with consistent yeast infections / UTIS; she doesn‚Äôt / more leaning towards is unable to cook / eat proper foods and typically resorts to a bowl of cereal. Struggles to clean up after herself, wash laundry, daily chore tasks. A huge pro though is that she takes her medication daily for the most part. 

She doesn‚Äôt seem to care to do anything, although she enjoys certain things she doesn‚Äôt want to make friends, learn / do a hobby, socialize, exercise. She will do things like get her nails done because she likes it, and she will go to the movies with us but she won‚Äôt attend a class even if I volunteer to go with. 

I am looking for any and all suggestions and advice on how I can help her. What environment may be best for her. What resources are available. Anything. Thank you.

stories.title: When to enact financial POA
stories.story:
When was your tipping point for taking control of your aging parents‚Äô finances?

Over the last couple years I have been increasingly concerned with my mom‚Äôs cognition and handling of her finances. Last year, I visited her and (with her permission and full cooperation), we got her affairs in order while she was still ‚Äúwith it.‚Äù Financial and medical POA. Will. Funeral arrangements. Copies of her various accounts, debts, deeds, etc. I went down the list from various elder care websites for what I needed to collect. 

At first I let things go back to normal. No need to step in yet. She‚Äôs only 70; I thought we had plenty of time. Well, her bank account showed up when I logged into my online banking (we have the same bank and I was added to her account). I ignored it, but a couple months in I noticed her account was in the negative. I looked at her account. I was shocked. She goes into the negative multiple times a month, racking up overdraft fees. I called her; I thought her account had been hacked. There were so many Amazon and Temu purchases. No, she admitted she has had a spending problem her whole life. 

Things got worse from there. She asked me for help, so I tried. I tracked expenses. Suggested she slow down on spending. Told her to slow down on spending. Laid out her spending categories to her. Got into screaming matches. Went through periods of not talking. Last, she told me to butt out of her business and we haven‚Äôt talked in 7 months. 

The investment company that manages her retirement account (that she‚Äôs also draining quickly) has called multiple times to see if I‚Äôll intervene. They say she will run out of money by end of next year. 

I don‚Äôt want to get back into the boxing ring again, especially right before Christmas. I have the time to help her with her finances now but I don‚Äôt have the time in the summer. My job is all consuming in the summer, and I don‚Äôt even have time to balance my own checkbook let alone my mother‚Äôs. It‚Äôs my dream job, and I won‚Äôt leave it. We‚Äôve had an enmeshed dynamic my whole life; I really don‚Äôt want to get caught up in it anymore. 

People have suggested I let her fall on her face‚Äîshe‚Äôs her own adult and all that, but I am an only child to a single mother. There is no one else. When she runs out of money, she will turn to me. She has turned to me for small amounts of money here and there over the years. I don‚Äôt have money to give for caregiving. She actually (pathetically) has more income from social security and pensions than I do from working, which adds to my resentment over her spending. I don‚Äôt have a room to give her in my house, and that would absolutely ruin my marriage. We don‚Äôt have money for a retirement home. She has given no thought to the cost of hospice or end of life care. 

I guess I‚Äôm ranting, but I mostly I need to know when is the big blow up fight worth it? Do I do it now to hopefully stretch out her retirement account for another 5 years maybe, but she‚Äôll still die in the poor house? She‚Äôs only 70!

stories.title: How can I get my grandma to eat more?
stories.story:
My grandma was in the hospital about a month ago due to a pericardial effusion. She lives in Mexico and I live in the U.S. so I don‚Äôt know about everything that went on while she was there. I‚Äôve been staying with and helping care for her for the past month.  

My grandma told me they had her on a liquid diet for the 3 days she was in the hospital and that she hasn‚Äôt had an appetite ever since. My grandpa passed away from a heart attack about a week before she was hospitalized. So she‚Äôs definitely severely depressed as she‚Äôs stopped doing nearly everything she enjoyed. 

She has a lot of other health problems, but she‚Äôs always had a good appetite. She complains about feeling nauseous often and when we went to see her doctor he explained to her that a big part of it is because she‚Äôs taking a lot of meds, but not eating enough, other than that he wasn‚Äôt very helpful, because he said to try not to push her to eat more than she‚Äôs willing to, but I‚Äôm very concerned. 

The only things she‚Äôs been eating are a couple cookies with coffee (I found her a chicory root blend that has no caffeine and she really liked it) in the morning with her pills. Some fruit, a scrambled egg or an Ensure around noon, she doesn‚Äôt have dinner often but when she does, she‚Äôll ask for a fruit smoothie and she‚Äôll drink a very small amount. She won‚Äôt eat anything else no matter what we offer her. 

I just ordered her an unflavored plant based protein powder and I‚Äôm gonna try to put it in a smoothie and see if I can get her to just sip on it throughout the day. I can‚Äôt think of what more to do right now, so any help/ideas are very much appreciated.

stories.title: Feeling terrible for losing temper with elderly mom
stories.story: My elderly mom and I occasionally bicker, and we've had some real arguments, but all in all we have a very loving relationship. But today I was feeling overwhelmed by responsibilities of caring for her, combined with stress and what I felt was her picky attitude. I was so angry that I really yelled, really raising my voice and using some ugly cuss words, naming my resentments and accusing her for being difficult, demanding, picky, unappreciative.  She is a lovely person, and is her own person. But she's also dependent on me a lot. She has been through several bouts of very rough sickness and is home now, in my care. But today's blasty yelling really hurt her, I'm sure. Of course, I apologized, and she forgave me. Has anyone else done this and struggled with the guilt? I have heard of support groups for caretakers, and will look for one. But in the meantime?

stories.title: "Life Alert" type system for slightly remote locations?

stories.title: Elder Isolation
stories.story:
Hi everyone! Warning: This is long. Sorry.

Wondering if anyone has suggestions for my situation. My mother was diagnosed dementia in 2022. At the time, my older sister and her two adult children were living with my mom. My mom owns her home. No one's name is on the mortgage but hers. She did give my sister a general power of attorney to help her manage paying bills. This is because my mom doesn't drive, and she wanted to be able to send my sister to her bank as needed. Now, I have never seen this POA, but I did speak with my mom about it before her diagnosis and that is how she explained it to me. So, my sister can pay HOA fees, bank, etc. Immediately after my mom was diagnosed my sister wanted to put her in a facility but we (my younger brother and I) didn't feel that was the best option due to knowing my mom's wishes about her care. However, we offered to help. I, having been a caregiver for 20 years, already know how difficult this journey can be. I stayed opened to hearing what my sister needed or wanted and have been offering to help. Knowing my sister has a mental health condition that she refuses to take medication for (her choice and I supported her on that always), I recommended that we create a plan where my brother and I can take turns helping with appointments or just giving my sister a few days off by taking my mother with us. She Immediately became combative when I offered this suggestion. My brother's son offered to also help out but she refused his help. Yelled and screamed at him to a point he will no longer try to contact my mom or come see her. 

About 6 months into my mom's diagnosis, I was listening to my sister talk about how hard everything was and I reminded her I am here to help. I work from home, I can be there at any point to assist. I told her it is okay to ask for help. She told me she didn't need help and became very belligerent to the point I got up to walk away and leave, she followed me around not letting me leave. She cornered me in my mom's room and my mom was standing at the door and she pushes the door on my mom. I told her my mom was there and she kept doing it. This hurt my mom. I don't know if it was more her feelings or physically but I did check to see if she bruised and she was fine. My sister's behavior escalated until she spit on me. At this I told her she had just assaulted me and mother, to which she said she didn't care. Her son pulled her away from me, and I took my chance to leave. My first mistake happened here because my husband wanted me to press charges. I did file a report but I told them I didn't want to press charges, I just wanted an officer to talk to her about what she had done. I should have pressed charges and I was so upset about what she had done to me, I didn't even think to report what she had done to my mom beforehand. 

After that she started refusing to allow me and my brother to see my mom. Every time we go over there she threatens us, won't open the door, and we have to call for a wellness check to get them to help us see my mom for all of 5 mins. It's an hour drive over there which isn't a lot but it is tough on me because I have my own mobility issues and family to care for. In January this year, I filed my first Adult Protective Services report because I had called for a wellness check twice at that point, my sister doesn't return calls or respond to messages, and she was presenting the same behavior every time we went to visit. They closed the case, and of course they don't give you any feedback or let you know anything. I reported her again a month ago because my mom had called tell me her arm was broken and ask why I hadn't come to visit. I asked her how her arm got broken and she said she fell outside. She had broken her arms years ago and I thought it was the dementia because I kept asking when and she would hesitate and then just say, "Oh, you know." After I hung up with my mom, 5 mins later my sister calls to tell me it happened 2 weeks prior. So, yes, she was listening to our phone call. When I asked her why she didn't tell me earlier, she says because I wouldn't have helped anyway, to which I told her I cannot help you unless you tell me what help you need and then allow me to give that help. I told her we need to get to a point where we can sit down and have a conversation to make a plan on what kind of help is needed. She then starts yelling and screaming at me on the phone, calling me the devil and all sorts of other things. My husband was standing there listening to her, and her son , who was home with her, had to take the phone from her to get her to stop.

I went to see my mom that weekend and noticed she had a really nasty swelling in one leg and nearly black foot. I asked my sister if it happened when she fell and she didn't answer me. She let me stay 5 minutes and any time after that she has repeatedly done the same behavior of not letting me in and threatening me when I show up. So, I filed again with APS and the case manager called me and asked me what was my problem with my sister, and I explained everything but then he made it sound like this was simply a family dispute. I don't know what she told him but it doesn't give me much hope. When he called me that day, he even told me my mom was in a nursing home for physical therapy and had been for weeks and would be there a few more. He gave me the information so I could go see her, and the next day after I saw her, my sister pulled her out of the nursing home and took her back home.

Now, for Thanksgiving I texted my sister and told her I would be coming by to see my mom for a few hours and I told her a week in advance. She didn't respond and luckily I thought to bring a friend with me to just witness the behavior. I didn't give her too much info on what I had been dealing with only that sometimes she will let me see my mom and sometimes she won't. No surprise, same reaction. My friend had me call for a welfare check, cops suggested my sister be on psych hold but they couldn't do it themselves because when they got there she didn't display the behavior we had witnessed. It was like night and day how she acted when they got there like she had not just been yelling and cursing up a storm. And she again told the police I was harassing her, no one wanted me there because I always caused drama when she was the only one being belligerent. The cops did not ask anyone else in the house anything. My sister stood in the door and didn't let anyone else come to the door, but I did get to see my mom. She was crying and shaken and even told the cops she got dressed up because she knew I was coming and she was sad because my sister wouldn't let me in.

Outside of reporting her for isolating my mom from us to APS, I have consulted a lawyer about guardianship and I cannot afford it, so I would have to file on my own. I'm currently in school full-time, working full-time, and a family caregiver for my husband. I think pursuing a psych hold makes sense, I'm just afraid if she can manipulate them into believing nothing is wrong, it will only escalate to make things worse for my mom because I don't know how she's treating her when we're not there and based on how she is treating us, we are very worried. But I am very disappointed with APS, the process, and how they've been handling things because things are only getting worse not better. I gave them the number to talk to my husband, my brother, and my nephew on both reports and they all say they've never been contacted. And this is the 2nd report! Which will prove that this isn't a me vs my sister situation that they're making it out to be. I'm just frustrated and not sure what to do next or how to do it.

Anyone have to pursue guardianship without a laywer? If so, any tips?

Anyone deal with a family member like this with a mental health concern who is responsible for someone's care? How do, or did you, navigate that situation?

If you're in Arizona, any suggestions for how to get myself a case worker to help manage this situation with APS and my sister?

Any and all opinions, suggestions, or referrals are welcome.

stories.title: Need Advice re: Dad with Dementia
stories.story:
Hi, my dad was diagnosed with dementia 3 months ago. I live in PA, and he lives in CT with his wife of 3 years (they've been together about 7 years). He and his wife are 78 years old.

Dad's wife, me, and my husband made the decision to move him into memory care in CT, his dementia progressed very quickly. It took over a month and a half to get him placed there. But due to his physical limitations, the facility called the day he moved in and said he was not appropriate for them due to mobility problems like almost falling and falling, even with a walker. We had a nurse from a facility that provides only memory care come evaluate him, but they said he was not appropriate for their facility either. And we contacted skilled nursing facilities that said he could be admitted there, but he would still need a one-on-one aide due to wandering and mobility problems.

After that, we moved dad back to the home he shares with his wife and hired in-home aides. Two aides per day, each with a 12-hour shift. It's only been a month and a half since my dad moved back into the house, and his wife is struggling greatly with feeling overwhelmed (even with the aides there) and spending time over the holidays with her adult children and her grandchildren (one adult child lives 15 minutes from them, one lives 7 hours from them).

Since late September, I have traveled to their house 4 times to help out and do what I can. I still work so going there every week is just not possible (the drive can take nearly 6 hours each way with weekend traffic). My dad's wife wanted me to come for Thanksgiving, but my husband can't get days off easily as a law enforcement officer. So her daughter canceled her plans to go to Florida and went to my dad and her mom's for Thanksgiving. I visited last weekend instead of on the holiday. Now my dad's wife wants me to come for Christmas so she can go visit her son for a few days. I would have to go alone, my husband can't go, and I wouldn't bring my 19 year old with me. I told dad's wife I understood she didn't want my dad alone with an aide on Christmas, and neither did I, but he won't know it's Christmas on December 25th. I suggested my son and I visit a few days before, celebrate Christmas, then she go visit her son and grandsons. 

Sorry this is so long. My question for you all is, should dad's wife and I be comfortable leaving my dad with his aides (who are great and who he recognizes) on a holiday? I feel like he could be like this for years and I can't spend half of the holidays away from my own family (including my mother, who had no family other than me, my husband, and our son). For those of you living far from your loved one who has dementia, how do you handle being helpful while still living your own life? I'm wondering if dad's wife may want me to take over and move him close to me, but that is such an awkward conversation to have. Any thoughts are very much appreciated.

stories.title: Nursing home drama
stories.story:

My grandmother was just admitted in a nursing home yesterday. She's always been very afraid of going to one but we got her to agree to go. She has cancer and needs constant care. stories.title: Mom's friend in Mexico

Looking for support and guidance. Thank you!

stories.title: Grandma giving all her money to new husband/pastor. Help.
stories.story:
Advanced apologies if there are gaps or anything seems nonsensical as I am livid. 

So, my grandfather was the sole provider. He died in 2012. My dad was an only child. He took his own life in 2016. I am an only child. My dad was living in their old house since my grandma moved to an apartment after my grandpas passing. My parents divorced in 2012 as well. I have been living in my grandparents old house since my dad‚Äôs passing. It has been paid off and established in a trust that now has my grandma, myself, and my uncle (her brother) on it (something about needing 3 parties). Basically I took my dad‚Äôs place. In addition to that she made me her power of attorney and put me on her credit union account. 

My parent‚Äôs divorce was hard for me. The loss of my grandpa and dad have been very hard for me, and especially very hard for my grandmother. We have always been pretty close but a certain kind of close. I love her dearly but can‚Äôt fully be myself around her. This has made keeping as close more difficult as an adult, especially since she has kind of tried to replace my dad with me. 

She found a lot of solace in her church community. And for that I am thankful. But church has never been for me, and especially hers. I have never been able to stomach her pastor. It is a Wesleyan (some weird form of Baptist) for context if it matters. 

Her pastor had a wife and family, the only one that I know of. In 2019/20 (can‚Äôt exactly remember) his wife got sick. My grandma did a lot to help take care of her. She died within the year. 

Less than a year later I had suspicions her and her pastor were ‚Äúdating‚Äù. Months later she sprung it on me that they were engaged to be married. I was shocked and very very not happy. Wondering why legal marriage was needed even if they just wanted to enjoy each other‚Äôs company. Or just have a spiritual ceremony. (I really wanted her to not have anything to do with him but also cant‚Äôt/ don‚Äôt want to control her life. Don‚Äôt want her to be lonely. Don‚Äôt want my decades of suspicions about this guy to be true). They wanted to travel and share a bed, and in their religion there is not separation of church and state basically is what I was told. They are in their late 70s and based on their health I‚Äôm guessing and hoping that sharing a bed is literally just that. 

I was told that her moving into his home would mean she is no longer having to pay $700+ in rent. He is not in debt. She would not have to pay anything. The trust wouldn‚Äôt be chanced for my/our house and same for his house going to his kids. No idea where life insurance stands at this point. 

Fast forward 2-3 years- 

I see on her account every month checks written to him for $1-2k. Every month. Anytime a house or vehicle expense comes up she pays it. Just in the last few months an extra $1500 for a porch renovation. $600 for tree service. $500 to get his van repaired (she still has her car as well). This is in addition to what I call his ‚Äúallowance‚Äù. She has also in several occasions written him LARGE checks for $5k, $10k, and now last week I have just seen $15k. Her checking account now has only about $3k in it. 

She does get over $2k per month in social security. She also has investments in stocks/bonds. They were not wealthy by any means but my grandfather was smart, hardworking, very frugal, and certainly not expecting to pass before age 65, and I‚Äôll venture to guess not expecting all his investment to go to the guy who read the Bible to him on his death bed. He never went to that church but gave religion a go after battling cancer for so many years, as many do. The pastor was simply doing his job and my grandma thinks he was truly saving his soul as she brings it up like he did something out of his way or miraculous. 

This is so long and I‚Äôm sorry but the story is long. Basically it really seems like she is being manipulated and/or taken advantage of. I‚Äôm afraid I can‚Äôt convince her to stop. I‚Äôm wondering what legal rights I have or action I can take if any at all. I have the name of the senior advisor at the credit union. I have the name of the lawyer/ elder law group the house trust is in. I‚Äôm okay with giving some money/ sharing expenses with her husband even if I hate the guy (would make story much longer but maybe can elaborate in comments) but these amounts are insane. I‚Äôm afraid he is setting his kids up with her money. I‚Äôm afraid my house is somehow going to get taken from me. My finance and I are planning on moving soon because we are expecting and it‚Äôs a one bedroom. The money is supposed to go to me from the sale, and I‚Äôd be fine with my grandma keeping some‚Ä¶ but for HER and any care SHE may need and not to get weaseled from her into his account. 

This is also obviously a big point of awkward contention in the family so I have been avoiding the issue admittedly but I simply cannot anymore and don‚Äôt know what to do, especially without any knowledge of legal back up. I don‚Äôt know if I should talk to her, the bank, or the lawyer first. Probably her but the stress of that is killing me. Especially since he is so manipulative and will know even if I speak to her privately.

stories.title: AI Companions and the Future of Elderly Care
stories.story:
"Elderly care is undergoing a transformation with the introduction of AI companions. These companions can provide reminders for medication, schedule doctor appointments, and even detect changes in the senior‚Äôs health or mood, ensuring timely interventions.

Beyond practical tasks, AI companions offer emotional support for seniors who may feel isolated. Through daily conversations and personalized activities, AI can help reduce loneliness and improve mental well-being among the elderly.

While AI is an excellent addition to elderly care, it‚Äôs not a substitute for human relationships. Combining AI support with family and caregiver involvement ensures seniors receive the holistic care they need."

stories.title: Grandmother with declining health, being manipulated and endangered by her stay-at-home son (my uncle)
stories.story:
Hi all - Hope all is well!

I am currently witnessing an interesting time in my family, and am very concerned about the wellbeing of my 84 year old grandmother. I would love any insight, advice, prior experience, or just a friendly ear to vent to. 

My grandmother has COPD, is recovering from lung cancer chemo and surgery, is on full-time oxygen, requires a walker to get from one room to another, is having bathroom accidents, and is showing clear signs of dementia.

She currently lives in her family home that she has lived in for the past 50+ years. 

Her son (now 50 years old) moved into the house 15 years ago after a divorce, and has been living there rent free for all 15 years. Prior to my grandmother getting sick, she cleaned the house, cooked all of his meals, paid for all of his groceries, did his laundry, etc. 

For the past year now, my grandmother‚Äôs memory has been completely shot (forgets what day it is, forgets names of relatives and close friends, forgets plans and events, etc) and after her cancer surgeries, has a very hard time getting around and can barely use stairs, and spends most of her day sitting on her couch watching TV. She also is on multiple medications that are meant to be taken multiple times daily. 

Recently, my uncle began showing signs of some form of mental illness (I don‚Äôt believe in diagnosing people as I am not a physician) but he seems to have clear symptoms of mania, bipolar, and schizophrenia. 

He was recently fired from his long-time job for trying to fight his boss after being confronted about sitting on a chair outside of his building during working hours, and tanning instead of doing his job (he has had multiple issues at his job over the past fee years, and I believe this was his last strike) When confronted, he got in his boss‚Äôs face and said he ‚Äúdeserved respect‚Äù and that he knew ‚Äúeveryone was plotting against him.‚Äù (this information was obtained by a town official that I inquired with as I was suspicious as to why every time I visited my grandmother during a weekday, my uncle seemingly was always home)

Since being fired 3 months ago, he has referred to himself as being ‚Äúretired‚Äù and has stopped paying child support to his ex wife. He also had his son removed from his health insurance, and told his ex wife to ‚Äúreach out to his ex employer to figure it out, as he wasn‚Äôt handling it‚Äù

He spends every day smoking marijuana in my grandmothers basement, blasting music, and created fake ‚Äútasks‚Äù to do around the house (ie- ripping up perfectly fine carpets, pulling out shrubbery and bushes (which have ruined the landscaping of my grandmother‚Äôs home), and throwing out perfectly fine furniture items). He also randomly screams to himself for hours on end, pretending to be speaking or arguing with someone.

Lately he has also gotten very aggressive with my grandmother, screaming at her, threatening her, and manipulating her thoughts about multiple family members with delusional stories. 

He refuses to go grocery shopping for himself or for her, refuses to clean the house, and constantly fails to give her the daily medications she needs. My mother, her siblings, and the grandchildren have all chipped in to do weekly grocery trips, constant checkins, and ensure she‚Äôs taking her medicine - however this is not feasible for long term as if she misses enough of her medication (that she frequently forgets to take, she wont be around much longer) and in the hours when nobody is there besides my uncle, anything could be happening behind closed doors

He has also begun creating these false and delusional situations, wherein he thinks the house and himself are being targeted by felons, and has gotten rid of all spare keys, constantly locks the entrance doors to the house, and is very skeptical whenever my grandmother has visitors (including family members). 

As he refuses to clean the house (will not do dishes in the sink, refuses to run the dishwasher, has never touched a vacuum or mop, etc) we hired a housekeeper to help keep things clean. The last time she tried to come on a scheduled day, my uncle locked her out and told her not to come back, as he stated he didnt trust her and that ‚Äúher services were no longer needed as his sisters would clean the house instead.‚Äù

Recently, my grandmother left the house and I took to visit a relative, and he promptly left to go out to a bar, locked the house doors knowing my grandmother was out and would be returning, and removed my grandmother‚Äôs spare house keys from their usual hiding spot. She was left outside in the cold rain while I had to wait for my mother (his sister) to bring a key and let us into the house, because he claimed he was ‚Äútoo busy to come let us in‚Äù - as he was 5 minutes away, out at a local bar.

As she can no longer drive, he recently sold her car without consulting with her or any of his siblings (my mother and his 2 other sisters) and pocketed the money for himself. 

When confronted about this or any other of his irregular actions, he immediately reacts with anger, violent screaming, throwing things, and threats, then claiming he is going to call the police on his sisters for ‚Äúharassing‚Äù him. 

As it has become extremely evident my grandmother can no longer live alone (and living with my uncle is at best, not having a positive impact on her quality of life) we have started the process of discussing selling her home, and finding alternative options for her to live. This has resulted in my uncle going into more manic episodes, as I believe he knows his 15 year free ride is potentially coming to an end.

He has since started trying to convince my grandmother that family members are out to get her and that she needs to safeguard her home and money, and can‚Äôt trust anyone.

His latest absurd act was convincing my grandmother to withdraw $30,000 from her annuity fund, and write a check in that amount to him so he could ‚Äúwork on making the house better for her‚Äù - he did not consult with anyone else in the family prior to this, and in a normal state of mind my grandmother would never in a million years do such a thing. 

He has also been using her credit and debit cards to fund his day to day (along with his newly found $30K) and has made it clear that her house is ‚Äúhis house‚Äù and he will be staying there.

Some additional facts below:

- My mother (my grandmother‚Äôs oldest daughter) is the executor of her will.

- My grandmother is not ‚Äúof sound mind‚Äù but has no medical diagnosis for dementia or anything memory related

- My grandmother is the sole owner of the home, and my uncle has no legal documentation claiming any type of ownership (i also don‚Äôt think he knows anything about squatters rights or whatever that is) 

- My grandmother‚Äôs last will and testament states that upon her death, the house and all the funds and all of her savings etc, will be split evenly between all of her children (but in the meantime she needs her money to be able to support herself and any future medical needs)


I guess my question here is - what the hell can I do to save the wellbeing of my grandmother? 

- Can she be diagnosed with something that will allow my mother to become her POA, to give atleast some sore of safeguard to stop my uncle from convincing her to take more money out of her annuity and investment accounts and gifting them to my uncle? 

- Can anything be done to get her in-home medical care without the possibility of my uncle turning them away or locking them out of the house due to his delusions? So she can be given medicine, food, bathroom help, etc on a normal cadence?

- If we decide we would like to sell the house, and our uncle has a manic episode (without physically threatening or hurting someone) and refuses to leave, what can we do to get him the hell out? 

- When confronted with authority or people outside of the immediate family, he typically puts on a ‚Äúnice guy‚Äù act, and is very good at convincing my grandmother and others that she is totally safe and fine in her current state and that he is looking out for her

Please feel free to sound off with any thoughts, opinions, experiences, etc.

I just feel like I am going crazy watching my grandmother decline day by day, when she could have such a better quality of life, while her son refuses to feed her, give her medicine, lives in her house rent free, screams at her and manipulates her, and genuinely puts her health at risk. 

Thank you all in advance, I greatly appreciate it, as well as my entire family

stories.title: Need Help - Grandma Advanced Dementia
stories.story:
Hello,

Grandma is 84 y/o, American and living in Florida. One daughter is living(?) but estranged, currently living alone, no spouse/partner.

Her grandchildren have been attempting to stave off the inevitable (moving her to a nursing home), but that seems to no longer be an option. We attempted in-home care with visiting nurses, live-in family, etc. and over the past 12 ish months she has fired / kicked out all of them. I think the count is 3 professional agency home nurses and 3 family/friends (the most recent being paid rather than a live-in free rent situation). 

She has grown increasingly nasty, aggressive, and uncooperative. And that's in addition to her memory, continence issues, sentience, etc. further degrading. All despite her insisting she is fine and living independently (bills, grocery shopping, etc.) despite that not being the case.

So...it's time.

I (eldest grand child, 37 years old), live across the country and travel a lot due to active duty military service. I am also the executor of her will, medical POA, etc.

The other grand children (27-36) live adjacent to her (one is a brilliant and successful nurse who has gone utterly above and beyond over the years taking care of our grandma).

**Questions:**

**1) Finding a NH:** Any recommendations on how to quickly find and vet? Other than a google search, we aren't really sure where to start

**2) Transitioning Gma to the NH:** it's increasingly clear that gma will not willingly go, and will need to be forcibly removed from her home and/or tricked (i.e. "let's go to lunch" and we take her to the NH unbeknownst to her). Any recommendations?

**3) NH Costs / Financing:** She has some cash squirreled away (that we manage, not her), so she would likely be able to afford decent living for several years. But is any of this covered via Social Security, Medicare, Medicaid, etc. I believe she gets a partial SS benefit from her late (first) husband who was active duty for a few years a long time ago. I mention this only because I remember her saying she got a SS paycheck boost (not much) when he died 10 years ago. Not other major life insurance, investments, etc. that we are aware of. 

**4) Medical POA:** Like I said, I am her medical POA, but have no idea what I'm doing here. I am aware of the need to call the laywer's officer that drafted her documents, but can anyone provide any guidance as to what this entails, next steps, how to properly "deploy" this power, etc?

**5) Reverse Mortgage:** She placed her home into a R Mortgage about 10-15 years ago. So, what happens when she moves out to the NH? Is it abruptly taken by the bank since she would no longer reside there? Or is that only upon her death? 

**Thank you all for your time and attention.**

stories.title: Feeling super lost about what to do with my father.
stories.story:
(Oregon)My father has truly slid downhill since my mother died four years ago. He is 69 but he looks 90, half his old body weight, can barely get around. He is not treating his diabetes the way he should be and for that reason he is unable to get a necessary surgery on his back and shoulder that would relieve his aggravating pain. He cannot clean up after himself very well because of it, or cook for himself often.

He's also making bad choices due to mental decline. He has lost upwards of 50k to scammers using apps like cashapp and paypal. He fundamentally doesn't understand how to keep his information safe, he trusts every email and text he gets. His bank is constantly freezing his accounts due to fraudulent acitivity, which has caused him to miss a mortgage payment. He is also now on some $20 a month phone plan using a flip phone because he couldn't afford a regular phone. Not sure where his smart phone is 

His cognitive health is on the decline as well. Alzheimers runs in our family, and he is starting to show signs. He loses time a lot, forgets he has appointments, and is apparently showing up hours late to places he was supposed to be because he gets lost or forgets where he needs to go. He tries to hide this from me and lashes out at anyone who brings it up. And this is on top of severe anxiety and probably depression. He has called me to complain about having to care for the family dog while calling his name outside, but I adopted that family dog two years earlier because he was neglecting him and the dog was next to me the entire time.

He's also turned pretty confrontational and angry since my mother's death. He has alienated a lot of family and has made himself unwelcome in many family spaces, which has limited how much help I can ask for from his family. Hard to ask someone for help with someone who cussed them out on Christmas last year.

And if all that wasn't enough.... it seems like he is on some illegal drugs. He was waking up disoriented and unsure where he was, thinking my mom was still alive and it messed with him bad. So he started to try to find ways to stay awake. He met a horrible woman in his town who introduced him to cocaine to help him stay awake. He ended up having an episode after staying awake for 3 days where he had some sort of break from reality and forgot that certain loved ones had died 15 years ago. He had to be hospitalized overnight and they said it was just sleep depravation.

Because of the cocaine, he failed a drug test at his doctor took him off his pain medication. My dad has real, demonstrable, crippling pain. Being taken off his meds cold turkey like that, even though it was his fault, was devastating. He has admitted to me that he is buying them off the street.

He was staying with my aunt yesterday and he dropped his stash and a glass straw with cocaine residue so she kicked him out. She called and now we know it's finally time to force him into help.

I live across the country and my dad and i have a very contentious relationship, we have never gotten along even in the "Good Times". It's gotten to the point where his sister thinks that he needs to be put under a conservatorship and forced into assisted living, if necessary.

I just have no idea where to even begin. I am living paycheck to paycheck and recovering from cancer treatment, and my partner is about to enter the police academy. I have been advised to contact elder law offices in my dad's state and to look into medicaid-financed assisted living facilities. But i don't know how I would pay for the lawyer or what to ask, I don't know how to get his medical and financial records to prove his decline as part of my conservatorship case. I have also been advised to call Adult Protective Services but I am worried they will find something illegal in his residence and report him to the authorities instead of getting him help.

And i don't know what kind of responsibilities I would have if i did become his conservator. It's all incredibly overwhelming.

Has anyone dealt with anything like this? What do I do first? What CAN i do from a completely different state? How do I tell my dad that i want to get this conservatorship over him? I dont think its safe to be driving, I dont think he is fit to control his own finances and if he goes into a home, he won't be able to own his firearms anymore and i know that will be a huge deal for him.

I'm sorry for the vent story along with the request for advice. I'm at my wit's end and both scared for my father as well as furious with him for letting himself get so bad and doing literally nothing to stop it. Every bad choice he could have made, he has and now I am in this position.

Any guidance would help, any push in the right direction or words of advice would be much appreciated.

I thought when I visit her on Thanksgiving we would do a little footprint/hand print turkey craft.  I have no idea how that will go off, but I think she might enjoy it.  We will try.

I figure I can do her nails every 3 weeks, but need some fun easy silly activity suggestions for her in between weeks.  Affordable too.  I'm on disability, so it's not like I can go hog wild, but she needs joy in her life.  I'm going to do my best!

*A silly dice game called pig.  I've got some very large dice that I think she'll be able to see.  I hope.

stories.title: Need input on an idea I have for a nonprofit
stories.story:
I've been my mom's primary caregiver since 2020. I cared for my dad for a month in 2019 while he was transitioning, until he died in 2020. I've learned so much throughout this process, and I feel like I've aged at least ten years. My mom is now under hospice care at home, but I'm still providing the majority of her care, and I'm literally hanging on by my fingernails at this point, which brings me to the purpose of this story.

My mom had a friend visit her today, and as I opened the door, she tried to hide her obvious shock over my raggedy appearance. It was almost 2pm, and I hadn't even looked in the mirror, let alone brushed my teeth or fixed my hair. I was braless, wearing raggedy shorts and a stained t-shirt, and I was holding a broom, a measuring tape, a garbage bag full of wet adult diapers, and some room spray. It was obvious from the look on her face that I looked like an absolute fright, but once we got over it, I led her through the extremely unkempt living room and through the even worse dining area and kitchen into my mother's spotless, clean smelling and lovely oasis of a room which I had spent the morning deep cleaning and organizing, in addition to changing her diapers, her clothing, her bedding, fixing her hair, massaging her with lotion, and just joojing her up for her visit. After I got them settled, I realized that I hadn't yet eaten or even had coffee, so I brushed my teeth, dragged a comb through my hair, splashed some water on my face, popped an adderall, and made myself some oatmea and coffeel. As I was choking down my food, I realized that this friend of my mother's hadn't even asked me how \*I\* was doing as she made a beeline to my mom, ready to show her with hugs, and gifts, and how are yous.

Now before you launch into what a selfish a-hole I am, I'll just say that I love my mom dearly, and she deserves every bit of love and care that she gets. (which is a LOT) But this all got my gears turning and I realized that NOBODY CARES FOR THE CAREGIVERS! And often times, it's the caregivers who need it most! Sure, there are lots of support groups and organizations that provide respite info., and tips on self care, etc., and I can't speak for all of you, but the daily "hang in there" and "I wish I could be there to help" calls and texts just don't cut it. And  most of us are either too exhausted to network with other caregivers, or too exhausted to shower, let alone drag our asses to Great Cuts, (my hair is something similar to a mullet and a mohawk) or to call some organization for aging on the phone only to get transferred 20 times and having to repeat why you're calling 20 times, only to get transferred one more time before you get disconnected.

What we really need is an organization that can provide the actual care! Right? Because, I don't know about y'all, but because I haven't been able to work, and my mother has no retirement savings, we're barely surviving on her monthly social security check, and we are broke ass broke. I mean, digging quarters out of the couch broke. But I am in such desperate need for some pampering, that I would sell my soul right now for a massage, or a pedicure, or even for someone just to play with my hair for 30 minutes. It's been so long since I've received any care or direct attention that whenever someone does say a kind word or gives me a hug, the tears are right there at the edge of my throat, and I have to struggle to keep them at bay, because if I start to cry, I fear I may never stop!

So maybe not right this moment, but eventually, I would love to start a nonprofit organization to provide free self-care and wellness services to low-income caregivers, using a pre-established network of health and body care professionals in my area such as massage therapists, aestheticians, Reiki practitioners, acupuncturists, chiropractors, yoga instructors, life coaches, hairdressers, colorists, nail techs, makeup artists, personal stylists, and even clothing stores and boutiques that may want to donate clothing. Most businesses and practitioners benefit from offering a certain amount of pro-bono work per year, not only from a business standpoint but from a personal philanthropic standpoint, as well. So I would start out by contacting these people (in person if and when possible) to explain my mission and see if they'd be interested in participating by donating their time and services, and/or even becoming a board member.

I would then have to come up with a user-friendly application system and max income guidelines to determine eligibility for services. And also a lot more, but this is the general idea.

What I'd like to know is are any of you aware of similar organizations that exist? If so, can you point me in their direction? Also, would YOU be excited to know that such an organization existed in your area? If so, would you feel comfortable applying? And lastly, do you agree that caregivers are under-appreciated, overlooked, and underserved? If not, can you explain why?

I would really appreciate any and all feedback - positive or negative (please try and be nice though, as I'm very fragile at the moment. LOL) Thank you in advance for your input!

EDIT: Admins/mods, since this isn't a formal survey or market research, but just an informal feedback request, I'm hoping that you'll let it slide. Pretty please?

stories.title: Tamper-proof pill dispenser?
stories.story:
I'm at my wits' end.  My poor mom (78, widowed and lives alone) has severe chronic pain, primarily her back, and severe memory loss.  It just feeds into itself - poor sleep due to pain and multiple meds daily can't be good for her memory.  It's an awful existence for her right now.

She's being treated for all of it but our primary issues is the pain.  One of the types of treatment is narcotics.  It used to be going really well - she was staying on top of taking her pain pill as directed 3x/day.  Been doing well w/ it for years.  These past few months she has been getting confused so I have taken over managing the meds.  I had put her midday pain pill in a locked automatic dispenser.  It has a note I have taped to the front telling her not to mess with it if there was no pill in the open compartment.

This woman has cracked the system.  She has apparently figured out how to force the dispenser to advance and give her pain pills ahead of time.  (It's one of those round ones that advances like an analog clock to put the pills in an open compartment to be accessed.)  Like, she's already taken today's midday pill AND tomorrow's midday pill, and it's not even time for today's pill yet.  The problem is, she doesn't ever remember doing it.  She never does. The desperation for pain relief is causing her to seek it out.  The pills apparently don't give her enough relief which is why she keeps going back and messing with the dispenser.

I realize that we're going to have to make tough decisions about caring for her.  But right now I'm just desperate to get this meds thing under control and get her pain addressed before we do anything else.  I'm scared surgery won't help AND may further exacerbate her memory issues.  And I do not have the capacity to go to her house every afternoon to give her a pain pill, and i don't want her to go without.  

I think I am mainly just venting because it all seems to be without a solution, but if anyone knows about a foolproof automatic pill dispenser that won't kill my wallet, I'm all ears.

stories.title: Theoracare wearable or other solutions for parents w dementia?
stories.story:
Hi, there- glad to have found this community

my father-in-law has parkinsons-related dementia, and my mother-in-law has early but clearly progressing alzheimers. they live a 3 hour flight away from us and are not willing to move to the city where we live, so we have not yet worked out all the kinks in their care.

because they were mis-managing their medications, we use a lockbox for their pills and hired a service where a home healthcare professional comes out at scheduled times to administer their medications. in theory, this is a great idea-- no more missed doses, no more double-doses.

unfortunately, they often forget to stay home so that the healthcare aide can give them their medication. Normally, my husband calls them about half an hour prior to their medication time to remind them to stay home and not go out until after their aide gets there to give them their doses. A new challenge is that sometimes they will either already be somewhere else, OR they might be home when he calls to remind them and then forget about the reminder 15 minutes later and go out to the grocery store. Or, sometimes, they forget where their phone is and don't realize he's calling to give them the reminder.

another challenge: sometimes they will know that one of them has an appointment with a doctor, and my mother-in-law, who insists she can still drive b/c she can still pass a driver's test, will insist on driving instead of taking a Lyft or an Uber, will drive them to \*A\* doctor's office, but it's rarely to the right doctor. They often get lost on the way or the way back. It's not great.

We are planning on taking her car keys; we are researching assisted living and memory care facilities (and how to pay for them, which is a whole other barrel of... well, of something).

IN THE MEANTIME... we are looking at tracking devices. Airtags and Tiles are affordable, but i think something that can a) set "zones" so that if they leave a zone -- like their house, when we need them to stay put at home for meds-- it :

* alerts us on OUR phones so that we can call them, 
* function as a wearable, so that they are more likely to have the device on them b/c they often lose their phones, 
* have a voice-calling function/ cell capability so that we can talk to them through the device and tell them to go back home b/c the aide is on the way, and 
* have a reasonably long battery life and/or remote battery monitoring so that we can know when to tell them to charge the thing 

  
A device that seems to fit the bill that i found online today is the Theoracare watch-- has anyone used it? Has it lived up to claims?

It's not cheap-- about $250 for each device, plus monthly service (about $30)-- i could get a refurbished apple watch and use a different app (boundary care?) for that much, so i'm also curious about similar setups that might be slightly less expensive but which have similar features. Both my father-in-law and mother-in-law are typically together, so I think we might be able to get away with starting with just one device/plan for now, but still- it's a chunk of change, esp given the monthly cell charge.

all suggestions are welcome! -- thank you!

stories.title: How to get help for an elderly hoarder relative so it's unknown who "started it"
stories.story:
TLDR- 94yr old relative is a hoarder in physical rehab that should go to assisted living (IMO and a few others in the know) and does not want to. How do I get that to not be an option for him without it being known I triggered it? 

\-NY state

Long story-

94yr old relative (not Medicaid eligible) has been living in hoarding conditions for 30+ years. He has me as his health care proxy, so I have power of attorney. I live well over an hour away and cannot take him in.

 I knew the house was a mess but did not know the extent until he ended up in the hospital and then rehab. The house is BAD! All rooms and halls packed; new stuff, old food, books, just random stuff. With all of this, rodents have run rampant and it's a disaster. He thinks it's just a mess and due to a part time roommate, but I see this is all him. He insisted he could go back but I knew a LOT of work would be needed to get him there. So after a full dumpster and 3 dump runs with a pickup; the front room and areas he'd need to navigate are 85% ready to go. I did this all to try to keep him content as he wants to be home but realistically, he is much better off in an assisted living facility as he still has a few hurdles that he insists are fine. I know it's a downwards slope (Physical Training, meals, help getting up and occasional toilet help all needed) if he goes home as he wants no help in the home...

Due to the nature of the home, it seems I can get the current facility to contact adult protective services to do a home inspection if I feel it is unsafe. While I want to do that if that'll force into a place where he gets proper care I do not want to be the one listed as why it all started. 

Based on my findings today care cost would be about $4400/month all in which he'd be able to afford by using savings. 

This might be more of an AITAH story but I am just trying to take care of him in any way I can. 

Any way to approach this other than adult protective services? He has a few more weeks before planned discharge.

stories.title: My nerves are frazzled dealing with my family
stories.story:
My mom has dementia. My dad had a head injury that needed to be operated on in the hospital. I very suddenly got thrust into everything two weeks ago. I called my parents after hearing from others that my dad was not in great shape and realized he needed to be taken to the hospital immediately. I drove 90 minutes to get to my parents to get them to the hospital.

Since that moment I jumped into my car, I've hardly had a moment to relax. Every time I feel like I might be relaxed, I try to get some basic task and realize I'm feeling jumpy because of it. This Saturday was the only time I was able to even sit down and focus on a tv show for more than five minutes at a time.

The problem is really my family. Here are the issues:

**My mom-**She was a very frustrating person to deal with even before her dementia. Now with her dementia, she has gotten even worse. We tried to visit my dad in the hospital, and she was doing things that should have frustrated him. Whenever he said he wanted something, she would tell the nurses or physical therapists he wanted the opposite. She would also come and tell him things that were aggravating like how she expected the presidential candidate they dislike due to various reasons. She also wouldn't stop talking about random non-sense things the entire time I was with her. It made it really hard to even accomplish something as basic as getting us food to eat. At one point, I just walked away from her, and she screamed, so my nerves were even further on edge. She's also refused to see any specialists about her dementia which means there are no support service in place for her. Now that we want to bring somebody to the house to help them out, she is saying she doesn't want it.

**My dad-**He has been afraid to go against my mom's wishes. Because of that it's hard to get them any help. The doctors say he is at a point where he is competent to make his own decisions. Yet when I try to talk to him, he seems really confused about basic ideas that he would have understood immediately before. It makes conversations with him difficult to understand. He also was driving the day after he returned from the hospital even though the doctors told him not to drive for two weeks.

**My uncle-**I don't really know this uncle as he lives overseas and hasn't visited in over 40 years. It just so happens that his visit coincided with my dad's hospitalization. He brought along an entire family of four other people with him. Since I have social anxiety, I was really stressed out about seeing all of them even before all of this. I've met with them a couple of times now hoping I could at least cross one thing of my to-do list. Each time, he comes back to say he'd like to see more of me. These phone calls often come late at night and stress me out as I'm trying to sleep. Since he works as a physical therapist, he thinks he knows what treatment my dad needs. He's put my sister and I into a panic on a couple of issues saying the doctors or physical/occupational therapists at the hospital are mistreating my dad, and we have to step in and argue with them

 **My sister-**She is a bossy older sister. I thought this would actually be helpful as I don't like to be the one in charge in these situations. The problem is she pushes things that aren't really helpful. For instance, she asked my dad what each of us should do to help. My dad was confused and asked me to put together a list of home care agencies even though I'd just shared a list with him. I was ready to move forward with contacting the top-rated agency from the list. Instead of being supportive of me moving forward, she was insisting that my dad said he needed a list so I should come up with another list. There have been a number of requests like this which aren't useful and only seem to stress me out more.

The only saving grace is my sister's husband. He came over with my sister to help a few days in and has been really useful. He and my sister say they have to leave in a couple of days. I really don't know what I'll do as far as caring for my parents. I live an hour and a half away and have a job and a cat that I'm supposed to be responsible for. I just feel like I need down time to breathe and get my head straight. It seems like every time I try, something happens to get my head spinning again. 

I don't know if anybody has any thoughts or suggestions, but I feel like I could just type this out. I just realized I haven't even gotten into the poor financial decisions my family is making recently. That is a whole other story that could take just as long to explain.
