stories.title: 91 YO dad needs more care
stories.story:
UPDATE: Writing this story must have manifested something great because I visited my dad tonight and spoke to him again about assisted living and, long story short, he gave me his LTC insurance info and asked me to call them and the person at his retirement home who handles levels of care, and start the process! It helped that his one close friend there recently moved to AL and seems to enjoy it. 

Also, thank you for your thoughtful replies. I read them before I left to see him and incorporated some of your advice into our conversation. I‚Äôm so relieved! 

‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî-

My dad is 91 years old and is in independent living in a local retirement home that has three levels of care, however it is clear that he really needs to move to assisted living, but he isn‚Äôt ready yet. This is his situation. 

- He has mobility issues and struggles to get up from a chair and uses a cane everywhere except in his apartment where he will use his walker (he‚Äôs too proud to use a walker in public though he can barely shuffle and is very unsteady). He says that it takes him an hour to shower because he has to be so careful of falling, and has actually fallen a few times in his kitchen. 

- He forgets to take his medications often and has to be reminded. 

- He has severe curvature of his neck and a paralyzed vocal cord which have created issues with swallowing, choking, and limits how much he can eat. 

- Despite receiving visits from me, my sister, her husband, and my two adult sons regularly, as well as daily calls from several of us, he complains about being lonely, and frequently says he wants to die. (He has an RX for antidepressants but won‚Äôt take them, nor will he accept therapeutic help.)

- He is growing more confused, agitated, and forgetful every day. 

- He still drives but he shouldn‚Äôt. He used to stand tall at over six feet, but now I can lean down to kiss his forehead and I‚Äôm 5‚Äô4‚Äù, so he barely can see over the steering wheel due to how much he hunches forward. Additionally, because of his neck, he can‚Äôt turn to see over his shoulder, let alone behind him, and his reflexes are slow. He also has a bad left shoulder and only uses his right arm to drive. (This matters in general, but is related to assisted living, because if he transitions to it, he‚Äôll have to give up driving.)

I know I can‚Äôt force him to move to assisted living from independent, but I wish I could. I worry constantly about him choking, slipping in the shower (or anywhere, frankly), etc. I believe he can stay in his same apartment, but there is also an AL-only floor with openings for identical apartment layouts. He just says he‚Äôll consider it, and then months go by and he gets more and more feeble. Is there anything I can do to help persuade him?

stories.title: My mom is being denied medical care
stories.story:
. My mom 84 has age related memory lost but NOT difficulty in orientation, critical thinking, problem solving, abstract thought, etc., but was wrongly dx with Alzheimer's.  They found a mass in her lung. I have found out that her husband told medical providers that she has advanced dementia, and set her up for hospice home care. She was never presented with any options or information. I am on her Hippa forms and her primary doctor was talking with me but has not stopped responding. She is not sure if she wants cancer treatment until she knows the pros and cons but surely wants other medical care. 

this is part of the note I sent to her primary care:

^(She expressed concern to me the her husband has made some medical choices for her without her knowledge. She consistently maintains that she was told about hospice but not much about other choices. She told me (and I heard from both the husband and caregiver Donna) that her husband Fred insists that he is the person to communicate with hospice and that they are in charge of everything now and she is not to have any other medical care.)

^(The hospital note in the file says this: CM ASK TO TALK W/PT AND PT'S SPOUSE FRED -- PER MD FOR HOSPICE AT HOME PT HAS DEMENTIA SO CM TALKED W/FRED-MPOA AND SPOUSE. HE STATED HE HAS CAREGIVERS FOR PT 8AM TO 6PM 5DAYS AWEEK. PT'S SPOUSE FRED AGREEABLE FOR HOSPICE D/T PT HAS COPD/DEMENTIA AND POSS NEW DX OF LUNG CA. REVIEWED LIST OF HOSPICES W/HUSBAND D/T PT HAS DEMENTIA CHOSE GENTIVA HOSPICE REFERRAL SENT DEVIN FROM GENTIVA WILL CALL HUSBAND AND GET SOMEONE IN HOME TONIGHT TO SET PT UP PT HAS CARE GIVER DONNA AT BEDSIDE WHO WILL DRIVE PT HOME)

^(During my visit, it was clear that Donna and anyone else there as private hire was there for Fred, NOT my mom, She was taking her to appointments and will do a favor here and there, but that is his caregiver. She also just repeats Freds opinions and wishes. They both treat my mother like she has dementia and is sicker than she is. He is restricting her from going out sometimes even.¬† So I am fighting like hell to make sure my mother‚Äôs voice is heard!)

^(We had multiple discussions on what she wants and I hope you can help me get these respected. She wants information! Although she recognizes there may not be great treatment options she wants to know what they are and¬† what the pros and cons are! She wants to understand more about this disease, how it will impact her and what to expect.¬† Even if she chooses not to aggressively fight cancer she wants ongoing medical treatment!! Currently the hospice nurse and not even checking her blood pressure. She comes 2x a week asks my mom a few basic questions and goes out in the garage to chat with Fred. She wants to be talk with a counselor or therapist about her feelings and anxiety over all of this but is afraid Fred cause a problem about it.¬† It is clear that she is not getting the care she needs, wants or deserves!)

^(I assured her that I would contact you  and reminded her that she had her followup appointment with you this Wednesday on 10/23. She became distraught and told me she was worried about that Fred won‚Äôt let her attend that.)

*I then went online to sent this and see that her appt was canceled! Can't see by whom and doctor not responding to this note.* 

I am in PA. mom is in SC. and it is hard for me travel. My mom is meek and intimated by husband, if reported as elder abuse and she is questioned she may very well defend him.. any ideas? help? I am hesitant to contact hospice as I am not on their contact though on Hippa and if they report to mom's husband I called it will cause her lots of stress with him.

But she obviously needs a better scooter, and I suspect a power chair would be even better.

stories.title: Frontiers | The effects of pulsed electromagnetic field therapy on muscle strength and pain in patients with end-stage knee osteoarthritis: a randomized controlled trial
Resentment building with my mom over how to handle care for my dad
stories.story:
Little backstory: Me, my parents, and my sister all live in the same city. Sister has a few kids with a new baby literally yesterday. My parents are both retired and live in an apartment. My wife and I both have full time jobs. My parents moved to this city because my dad's mental health was declining (Alzheimer's) and so we could all be closer and help my mom(65yo) look after him, as well as get more time together.

About 7 weeks ago my dad(73yo) had a massive hemorrhage stroke and was in the ICU for 3 weeks, we did a shunt to save his life, and we did a feeding tube to try to get him strong (I kind of regret these actions now, and feel the doctors pushed us that direction with no explanation about QOL, but that's another thing). From the stroke his left leg and arm became parallelized. His speech luckily remained fully intact as well as his swallowing ability. After the ICU he went to a regular room for about a week where we had a mixture of days. Basically, the cycle looks like this:

Dad is lucid and himself, understands to a degree what is happening and where he is, who we all are, and has a strong sense of self (knows his career and his life)
Dad is delusional and sees hallucinations, as well as tells stories about things that didn‚Äôt happen. He will say "I flew to San Antonio last week and a bunch of guys laid on top of me and beat me up" all kinds of stuff
Dead asleep and peaceful
Physical agitation where he sort of flails his body parts around kicking his leg and swinging his arm involuntarily
Now he‚Äôs at a SNF and supposed to be getting rehab. ***Only ONE SNF would even take my dad*** so that tells me he must be in pretty bad shape.

Right now, we get those 4 versions in kind of a cycle. He can't get up or do anything for himself at the moment. He is at a SNF where he is supposed to be getting rehab (SNF is a whole other story) but we haven't seen any progress with the rehab that he is doing. He is still on the feeding tube, but it‚Äôs turned off during the day and he almost never wants to eat food, despite being able to.

Okay that's a BRIEF backstory. In 8 days, insurance will more than likely stop paying for his treatment at the SNF, and we will have to take him somewhere else (we could leave him and pay out of pocket, but the place sucks). so, my mom wants to put him in Hospice at a facility citing that he won't feed himself, and she believes his body is shutting down. For a while I agreed with her about Hospice because I hadn't seen any signs of improvement from him and most days he was in the bad parts of the cycle. Yesterday was an amazing lucid day where he was basically himself and begging to go home, to see his dog, to get out of here ETC.

I am now trying to convince my mom to let him come home and do some kind of palliative care or hospice if the doctors allow that, but she has all these bullshit reasons why he can't; "There's not a lot of space (they have 2 bedroom apartment)" "we have the dog, and it would be tough with a nurse coming and going" "he weighs too much and I can‚Äôt lift him" "we don't have any of the stuff to take care of him/ I don't know how" So my wife and I are talking about taking him in, which isn't ideal because we both work full time ( I myself work about 54 hours Monday to Friday) but I feel a huge amount of resentment building towards my mom if I am the one who has to take him in when she is retired and is his partner (40 years of marriage). I don't want to destroy the relationship I have with my mom over this, but I feel like it could. Does anyone have a similar story or and advice here? I can provide more detail as this is just a mere snippet of the story.

***TDLR: Mom doesn't want to take Dad for Palliative/Hospice care despite being retired. My wife and I are talking about taking my dad despite both working full time jobs. Worried resentment towards my mom is going to happen and ruin our relationship.

stories.title: Elderly relative abandoned. What can I do?
stories.story:

He lived in their house, drove the kids to/from school, cooked them meals, etc. In exchange for these years of servitude, my sister and BIL had agreed to take care of him in his old age.

In his old age my uncle has developed dementia, and is extremely belligerent. My sister and BIL drove him across the country and left him in a nursing home near where I live, in an attempt to force me into responsibility for his care. The thing is, I \*cannot\* get care for him, because my BIL has power of attorney. My uncle cannot reassign PoA because he does not have any valid forms of identification. If he could, I do not think he would as he also has no idea who I am- he has not seen me in probably 15 years. As it is his care home will not let me take him out, move him to a different facility, or have any input on his care because I am not the PoA, but my BIL who is the PoA refuses to participate and has blocked my number/other forms of contact because he views my requests that he take an interest in our uncles care as "harassment."

Before leaving him here, my sister and BIL did not wait to complete the verification process for whether his veteran's benefit will cover the home they left him at. We have now discovered that his benefits do not, in fact, cover it. The uncle has been paying for the home out of his savings, which is rapidly depleting. 

What recourse do I have in order to get him care?

stories.title: Any suggestions for loss of appetite and depression?
stories.story:
I'm not quite sure what to do, so hoping someone might have some insight, thanks in advance for any suggestions :) Sorry for the long story, this kinda turned into a vent.

My 83 year old mother had a fall and suffered a closed sacral fracture (pelvic fracture). While she was in hospital they also gave her a vascular dementia diagnosis and we've noticed a rapid decline in her cognitive function and memory. After 6 weeks of not bearing weight she was cleared to start physio to remobilise to the extent it is possible and she was very excited and happy about it as she absolutely hates being bed bound and having to use diapers. After she was cleared to bear weight she really wanted to try and walk so the carer very gently helped her get up and take about 3 or 4 steps, I think this made her realise she can't simply walk around on her own as her muscles have atrophied and it seems like she has just "given up" now and has lost interest in everything, including the physio which she was excited about.

In the last week she has rapidly lost weight and is VERY thin and eats very little compared to previously and complains of being tired. We got a doctor to come round and check for obvious things like her blood oxygen levels, blood pressure, listen to her lungs, heart, etc - all fine. She is not in any pain or discomfort. (Side note - the doctor was really drunk - I know, it's crazy, but that's a whole 'nother story, we're having the worst luck with medical care, but I figured you can't really screw up a blood oxygen check and we don't have another doctor who is willing to come to the house right now).

She is also very depressed and just wants to die - she tells us this all the time and has even asked us for a gun. I completely understand, I'd probably feel the same in her circumstance (personally I think we should all have the right to die). 

We just don't know what to do - are we supposed to just watch her slowly starve to death? What's the normal response to this? Reading up on it, I think a factor is a severe lack of exercise which will cause loss of appetite as your metabolism slows down (she's basically been lying in bed for 2 months), but I don't know how we are going to get her to exercise when she doesn't even want to sit in her wheelchair or go for walks or anything. 

We are trying different foods, but she's not even eating much of her favorites anymore, she just simply not getting enough calories. The doctor suggested we try a nutritional supplement shake (https://lifegain.co.za/), any other suggestions? Thanks! :)

stories.story:
Hello all!

This is a bit of a shot in the dark but I‚Äôm not sure where else to go, and so any advice is greatly appreciated.

My mom recently (mid 50‚Äôs) moved my granny (87) in with her because of dementia. Previously she lived alone in a trailer behind my uncle‚Äôs house. My mom and her brother had an arrangement to where he was supposed to check in on her daily and ensure her everyday needs were met, while my mom would take her to her many doctor‚Äôs appointments. 

This changed due to worsening dementia and my mom‚Äôs discovery that her brother wasn‚Äôt reliable on ensuring my granny‚Äôs safety. We knew she had some mild age related dementia, but we didn‚Äôt realize how bad it had gotten till recently when my granny was hospitalized for several days to due unknowingly overdosing on medicine. My granny cannot reliably be trusted now to take medicine, as she forgets that she took it and keeps taking more, and my uncle can‚Äôt/ won‚Äôt help. My mom has now had to move my granny in with her to supervise her full time, which has been very difficult. My parents both work full time and can‚Äôt leave her alone, as she is getting to the point where it is dangerous for her to be left alone. Additionally, my parents live in a tiny house and are very low income, which makes it difficult to care for her there. 

My mom has had to take temporary leave from work to care for her, but will have to return to work next week. She‚Äôs at her wits end and is on the verge of a breakdown due to the stress and the heart ache of seeing her mom like this. She is wanting to place my granny in a nursing home so that she can have the around the clock care she needs. The problem is that my granny‚Äôs insurance (Humana) denied this because they stated that my granny ‚Äúcan be taken care of at home.‚Äù My mom can‚Äôt any longer, though, and we‚Äôre not sure what to do.

My granny had Medicaid but my mom found out last week it was canceled because her brother never completed the continued enrollment forms. She is in the process of trying to get it back but is having a difficult time with this.

With all of this said, does anyone have any tips or maybe could point me in a direction to trying to affordably place my granny in a nursing home so that she can get the care she needs? Thank you so much in advance and sorry if this is vague, I‚Äôm lost as to what to do, I will try to answer any questions if it‚Äôll help get better answers. This is in Tennessee if that helps any.

stories.title: Medicaid Waiver - Advice on Appeal for More Hours

He was only awarded 6hrs/day of care based on medical need. I requested 12-hours/day but wasn‚Äôt aware I needed to put forth detailed justification for those hours. I thought the case manager would do so. 

I have an appeal coming up but am told they are rarely successful. I‚Äôm putting together a spreadsheet breaking down his day into 15-minutes chunks so they can see what‚Äôs going on. 

What can I do to improve their odds? Any particular medical language I should include in my statement? What specifically should I ask from a doctor? They basically say he needs a nursing home. 

I‚Äôm going through this process without an advocate, learning a lot but making mistakes too. Will a lawyer help? Any advice appreciated.

stories.title: Am I on the right track with my mom? [USA]
stories.story:
She's 70 and long story short has a form of early on-set dementia she's had over the last ten years. Today was significant because it was the first time she didn't recognize my father, her husband of 40+ years. We've been caring for her so long that I feel like I need to have a check-in to keep us honest. What do you think, reddit?

She's been bedridden since January, though she wheelchair transfers for meals, the toilet if she alerts, and can sit on the couch for a bit still with visitors. Beyond that she isn't going anywhere, and I don't know if she can handle a whole lot of car trips to doctors. Her oncologist (she's been in remission 10+ years) said not to bother bringing her back after a visit a few months ago. He wouldn't treat her if they did find anything and it wasn't worth putting her through the tests. 

She's also pretty quiet these days, and doesn't have much to say unless prompted directly. And what she can say is a few words that trail off into those twisting stories that go nowhere. I don't mind, her voice is still there and I like hearing it. Emotionally, she is happy when asked, and feels safe. She isn't afraid, or argumentative. And she never complains. She's really comfortable and I hold onto that. 

I feel like she is well looked after - she's got someone around the clock changing her, moving her around in bed as needed. She hasn't a single bedsore or raw patch of skin on her. Bless these women! She has a good appetite, she kind of just eats whatever you put in front of her, and is a healthy weight and had healthy blood work (except some anemia). Healthy bowel movements. Nice skin color. But she is certainly more and more frail as well as almost entirely gone mentally. 

So what do you think? Stay the course? Am I missing something?  Any input at all is appreciated.

stories.title: Where do the residents go when a care home is sold?
HELP! I think my brother might be mismanaging / misappropriating  my parents' estate
stories.story:
I am in way over my head and could use any advice.¬†

My mother passed away very unexpectedly in July. When she died, my dad was in the hospital after having had a stroke. He has been steadily declining since then - he is bedridden, not super verbal, and has pretty impaired cognition.¬† Dad is recovering but not in his right mind. He is currently hospitalized and his doctors have concluded he is in the early stages of dementia. After being discharged from the hospital, he‚Äôll go to a skilled nursing facility. Once he is discharged from skilled nursing, he‚Äôll likely go to assisted living or memory care. As recently as June, both of my parents were living independently at home. It has been a huge shock to me and my family.

Here is the issue: My mom was a woman of some means. She owned a very successful small business that operated for many decades. She died with no will other than a handwritten piece of paper saying she wanted to leave everything to me, my dad and my older brother. My older brother is an attorney and I was pretty gobsmacked that he never prepared an official will for my late mom. Apparently she‚Äôd asked him to and he refused because it was tough to think about her dying. After my mother‚Äôs death, my brother assured me he would get power of attorney for my father, but I recently found out he never did and frankly, I think it is too late. (This now might mean getting the courts involved.) Since then, my brother has really checked out from dad‚Äôs care. He hasn‚Äôt visited him once during this most recent hospitalization, and it seems like he is just ready for dad to die.¬†

Since my mom died I have had no transparency into the estate, and I am realizing what a mistake it was to trust that my brother would have it under control.¬† I don‚Äôt know how much was in any of my mom‚Äôs accounts when she died, or where that money is now. My mom left my dad a million dollar life insurance policy which my brother says he deposited into my dad‚Äôs account; I have seen no paperwork to this effect.¬†He physically has my dad's bank card and wallet. 

I am worried my brother is at best mismanaging and at worst misappropriating the estate. For most of his life my brother‚Äôs finances were very much wrapped up with my parents‚Äô (my brother and his family live for free in a house my parents own for instance ) and I suspect my brother just sees my dad‚Äôs money as his money, too, and doesn‚Äôt expect anyone to challenge that. (He is the oldest boy,  ‚Äúthe Golden Child,‚Äù so he has a lot of entitlement if you know the type. So I am also up against a lot of old family dynamics that make my brother feel like he should defacto be in charge. ) So far I have been managing the day to day of my dad's care despite living three hours away, while my brother just expects to manage the finances while doing nothing and providing no transparency or communication.  ¬†

As I‚Äôm starting to have to sort out dad‚Äôs long term care situation, I will need more transparency into the finances of the estate because this is how we‚Äôll be paying for his care, but I don‚Äôt even know where to start or what I am asking.¬†

I am talking to a trusted relative who is also an attorney tomorrow who is suggesting we hire an estate / elder attorney to help sort it out (I agree.) But I am not even sure what, specifically, I should be asking my brother for transparency about.¬† If I have no visibility into any of this, how will the estate/elder attorney know where to start? I was thinking I might have a frank call with my brother and ask for whatever information he can give me about the estate and go from there, but I don‚Äôt think my brother will play ball. In fact, I think he‚Äôll be hugely threatened that I am pushing this at all.¬†

Any and all advice appreciated. Brother, dad and mom all live(d) in Virginia and I'm in the District of Columbia

stories.title: Great uncle needs full time care
stories.story:
So just for a little back story, my great uncle bought the house next to my grandparents house about 15 years ago for a vacation home during the winter when he visited all of the family. 

About 2 years ago his wife died and he moved here permanently to be closer to all of his family who lives in state, especially my grandmother who lived next door. 

About 6 months after he moved here, my grandmother passed away, who was his closest relative at the time. He has no children or really any close relatives other than myself (his great nephew), my mom, and my 2 aunts. We have all pretty much taken care of him since he moved here, because he has shown signs of dementia and wasn‚Äôt able to completely take care of himself (mainly my mom & aunts). 

It is now getting time for us to get him in some sort of assisted living or nursing home, because he is too much for us to care for alone & we have no idea where to start. We don‚Äôt have power of attorney over his health or finances or even know if we can. 

He is retired from the army & navy. He also has a pretty large nest egg from selling his house in CA as well as his retirement and SS.

My biggest questions are: How do we start to get the ball rolling as far as being able to make decisions for him and to provide these care facilities with financials if needed? This is in Georgia if that helps. Do we need to get power of attorney? Do we have to take him to the doctor to deem him incompetent in order to do this? Any and all help is greatly appreciated!

stories.title: When the hygiene is really bad...
stories.story:
Caregivers: What do you do when the personal hygiene gets *really* bad? Like body odors that make you gag? Horribly stained sheets and laundry? Fingernails like dirty bear claws?

I (52M) care for my dad, 75, who is in Stage 4 Parkinsons.  I don't fault him for anything because of his condition, but today set me off. 

Saturday is laundry day, so I changed the sheets on his bed as I normally do, but I gagged as I did it. Normally I change his bed and collect his laundry every weekend, but last week I was twisted up with work stuff and it got away from me. Just being in his bedroom was tough because of the smell. When I came home from the grocery store, the stench about him was unbearable. I insisted he shower and put all his clothes in the wash because he smelled like the bathroom. Later he admitted to dhaving iarrhea all day.

His hygiene has been off for a while. He has uncontrollable drooling because of his condition. He has difficulty eating, so his clothes are always stained and his face and hands are usually a mess after meals. He has no control over these things, so I accept that and I help him of course.  But he has no awareness of it, and only washes hands and bathes when I force him to do it, like he's a preschooler. I'm not convinced he actually uses soap, or the body wash in the shower, because nobody who washes semi-regularly should smell this bad. Maybe he's depressed and resigned to living in filth? 

The fingernails gross me out. He won't trim his finger- and toe-nails despite getting an assistive device that I know he can use, because I watched him use it with the PT who gave it to us. His nails are always long and black with crud. I don't let him handle any food that we both might share unless it's packaged, and I won't handle his feet, it's just too gross.

Hoping to learn about some ideas, and also need to vent, and just commisserate.
